PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: FINANCIAL AGREEMENT BILL 1994Cognate bill:NATIONAL DEBT SINKING FUND REPEAL BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 10 May, on motion by Mr Elliott:

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on the Financial Agreement Bill and the National Debt Sinking Fund Repeal Bill has been rather long coming. The bills are not profoundly important but, as I remind the House, they do update the financial arrangements between the Commonwealth and the states. The principal provisions of the bills will abolish the restriction on the states borrowing in their own name; remove the Commonwealth's explicit power to borrow on behalf of the states; remove the need for future borrowing by the Commonwealth or

SPEECH.PARA: the states to be approved under the agreement between the Commonwealth and the states; and, I am glad to say, admit the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory as signatories to the financial agreement between the Commonwealth, states and territories. These are all updating measures that bring into line with current practice the statutory framework for the financial agreement between the states and the territories.

PARA.TAB: It is ironic in a way that we are debating these bills the day after the budget was brought down because they are to do with one of the important elements of financial arrangements. I want to touch on one issue directly related to the subject of the bills, that is, the level of government debt in Australia. One of the facts that are least well known about the Australian economy is that we have very little national debt. In fact, the Commonwealth, the states and the local governments combined have less debt as a proportion of national income than do other Western countries. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a graph which demonstrates that.
Leave granted.
The graph read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: [GRAPH OMITTED FROM DATABASE - SEE HARD COPY PAGE 609]

TALK.START.PARA: —This graph was taken from the figures published in the June 1993 Economic Outlook of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, the OECD. It shows that Australia has less debt as a proportion of national income than any other Western country. The graph shows that government debt—the debt of all governments of Australia—as a proportion of national income was only 35 per cent in 1993. That is the lowest figure amongst the countries with which we usually compare ourselves. For example, Germany's total debt as a proportion of its GDP was 45 per cent; the United Kingdom, 47 per cent; the United States, 64 per cent—almost twice as large as Australia; Japan, about 65 per cent; Canada, 86 per cent or close to three times the figure in Australia, and some would say that Canada is the country with which we can most directly compare ourselves.

PARA.TAB: There are several points on this. First of all, it is essential that we know of that fact: people are oppressed by Australia's level of overseas debt. That is a problem for us. It makes our exchange rates and current account more vulnerable, and we have to be concerned about that. That is why it is very valuable that our manufactured exports have been growing so strongly. But, quite often, particularly members of the opposition remark that the government should not be running a deficit. It is asserted that that builds up debt and creates problems for us in the future.

I would make the point that, at a time of high unemployment, it is entirely responsible for the government to borrow in order to invest in infrastructure that will be productive in the future, that will increase the efficiency of the economy, that will improve private sector productivity and that will directly contribute to growth of employment; and that we can afford to do that because our debt is so low. Of course, we do not want to run deficits any longer than we need. The government plans, of course, as was announced here last night, to substantially reduce that deficit as the recovery occurs. But at a time when unemployment is still over 10 per cent it is entirely responsible to borrow—in fact, it would be irresponsible not to borrow—in order to invest, in order to stimulate economic growth and growth of employment. We are very fortunate to have the capacity to do that. It is essential that we recognise this central fact of our economic life and build that into our consideration of appropriate economic policies.

One other dimension of this is that the figures I have been quoting are the debts of the Commonwealth and the states combined. The fact of the matter is that the states also have relatively low debt. This is not at all well known. In Victoria, the Kennett government has been projecting a sense of crisis and emergency because, it asserts, Victoria has high debts. In fact, Victoria has very low debts by international standards. Victoria's estimated debt in 1992-93 was 31.3 per cent of gross state product. There is not one OECD country that has a debt as low as that as a proportion of its national product. It is legitimate to make that kind of comparison.

It is true that several of the states have even lower debts still. New South Wales, for example, has a net debt of 16 per cent of its gross state product; Queensland, about seven per cent; Western Australia, about 21 per cent; South Australia, 26 per cent; Tasmania, 45 per cent, far above Victoria; and the Northern Territory, 32 per cent, which is about the same as Victoria. So it is true that Victoria is at the higher end of state debt. It is also true that any level of debt involves debt servicing payments, which are a drain on outlays. One does not want any government to have any more debt servicing than it can possibly avoid, but it is important to get this level of debt into accurate perspective. That is what has been completely lacking in the Victorian debate.

Another way of showing the situation in Victoria is that in 1992 its debt per capita was about $7,000. That is less than the level of per capita debt, in comparable price terms, at the beginning of the 1970s. Between the war and the mid-1970s Victoria's debts came down, but even now they are no higher than they were in the early 1970s. So Victoria does not have a debt crisis. It is important that Victorians know the facts about their own financial situation and not believe the misrepresentations that the Kennett government is trying to force on them.

Those are the central points I want to make about this bill. This bill does increase the maturity of Commonwealth-state financial relations, but that is happening at a time when Australia's government finances are in an extremely strong state. We should remember that when we are considering the budget because the budget itself is a particularly economically responsible financial document and is built on an entirely sound basis. That means that it is very well judged, in my view.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Financial Agreement Bill 1994 and the National Debt Sinking Fund Repeal Bill 1994. The sinking fund really draws into the mind of the Australian community, I guarantee, a description of the current government's management of the economy, the whole economy being part of a sinking fund presided over by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). We have come through the worst recession Australia has had since the Depression, and at great cost.

PARA.TAB: The sinking fund, in the terms we are debating it today, is about debt and the way Australia manages its debt. I disagree completely with the propositions of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), in regard to the state of the Australian economy—as he would expect. The fact is that Australia has a debt larger than that of any comparable country in the world and he is saying that we can manage that.

We look at South American countries and say that they are banana republics. What prophetic words they were from the present Prime Minister when he said that we would become a banana republic. We are a banana republic, if we look at our national debt and the way we have managed it. We have gained nothing from that national debt. The point you make is that we should have gained something from it; we have gained nothing from it. The infrastructure you so sorely want, that you crave for—the works programs, the big projects that you think will employ people and encourage Australian skills—has been lost, and your government lost it. I did not hear you crying out, `Change direction!'

I am disappointed that that voice was not raised. It is passionately raised now when we are looking at the size of deficits and the amount of money borrowed. What an opportunity we have had over a 10-year period, but you borrowed all that dough and frittered it away. More crude terms for what we have done with that opportunity are used in hotels, but it is a proper description of what has happened to the Australian people.

If we analyse the debt structure of the states, local government and the Commonwealth we can see that little has been done except to retain the position of Paul Keating, both as Treasurer, with his ambitions to succeed Bob Hawke, and then as Prime Minister. That is what has driven the Labor Party. That is what has driven many people on the opposite side—not the well-being of the Australian community and the fact that they ought to know what a hire purchase agreement can do to any family if they overcommit themselves. The government is prepared and has been prepared to overcommit the Australian people and then, in order to resolve the problem, do what it did in the budget last week: sell the farm off, start getting rid of the assets. Well, there are not too many assets left to sell.

Foreign capital is being invested in Australia. An attractive climate for investment is being consciously fostered in order to have investment of any sort made—not selective investment. Any investment in Australia is good investment; it helps to balance the budget. It helps to make the Treasurer (Mr Willis) and the Prime Minister look good. That is what the debt management of Australia has been about. There has been no gain, no purpose for it. If we borrow money, we need to have a purpose, an objective, for it—to put on an addition to the home, to build a new factory or to improve pastures. Australians have seen no objective, no purpose, in the huge debts that the government and Australia, as a nation, have run up.

The government is proposing a changed relationship between the Commonwealth and the states in the way in which debt is managed. I am indebted to the Department of the Parliamentary Library for a quite erudite expression and explanation of the historic progress of financial agreements between the Commonwealth and the states, starting in 1927 and moving forward to this day. We have fluctuated in the way in which we have looked at the relationship between the Commonwealth and states in relation to the various powers, the Commonwealth borrowing powers, to borrow globally for the nation, and the way in which we have distributed to the states their preferences as far as the amount of money that has been borrowed is concerned.

The normal process is through the Australian Loan Council. It says how much the states may borrow and then borrows it for them. That has been the practice, except in the late 1970s and early 1980s. The Prime Minister of the day, Malcolm Fraser, said, `Why don't we take the shackles off the states and make them a bit more responsible? Why don't we let them borrow what they need to borrow?' We can imagine the sort of response that we would have received from the then opposition and the current Prime Minister about fostering a sense of responsibility in the management of state governments. We can imagine what support rational and thoughtful economic management would have brought from the then opposition.

It is sad to say that any rational consideration of what was done by the Fraser government was rejected by the current Prime Minister. The Hansard of 15 May 1985 records the summary of what the current Prime Minister, the then Treasurer, felt was wrong with the Fraser government's attitude of encouraging states to be responsible. What Fraser said was that, if states go out on the market and borrow more than they can afford, they will wear the penalty. Australia has had two notorious examples of that—the Victorian government and the Western Australian government. The Victorian government could not carry on its programs, let alone carry them out, because of its overborrowings and its poor management.

So Fraser saw this and said, `Let us make these guys responsible for the money they borrow and the way in which they repay it. Why should the Commonwealth tell them how much they should borrow, raise the loans and then see that the funds are properly repaid by state governments?' So that was a step to a competitive federalism where good management is rewarded, which I and my colleague the honourable member for Pearce (Mrs Moylan) endorse.

I tell those people in the gallery that the honourable member for Pearce comes from a state where good management has been put in place—Western Australia. It is salutary to see a change in attitude in that state and good sense, a sense of responsibility, drive and integrity for once. What a change! The person who was heading that state is now a minister in the Commonwealth government. The government has added a gem to the crown of financial management; it really has.

The financial management that Fraser wanted to encourage amongst the states was for the states to carry full responsibility for their decisions—a system of competitive federalism. In 1985, Treasurer Keating said of that approach:

SPEECH.PARA: In a cowardly way, the previous Government gave the States the borrowing approval to raise the necessary loans. That is the story of the Fraser years. That is the story of fiscal management during the Fraser years.

I could read page after page of what the Prime Minister thought about giving the states some freedom to manage their own affairs and borrow the money they needed from overseas or within Australia. Fraser clearly said, `If you guys as state premiers and state governments are going to overborrow, you're going to run your state into hard times and you'll be seen by your people as having done so.' But the Prime Minister condemns that. On 21 August 1985 he said:

Who let the States out of Loan Council control, the big electricity instrumentalities and the large State authorities' borrowing programs? Who let the rabbit out of the bag? The Deputy Leader of the Opposition—
I assume at that time that was the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard)—

and Mr Fraser let it out of the bag. With a global limit we have got it back in and we have tried to get some discipline in borrowings, which we have been able to effect in the last two years. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition is to blame for the blow-out in the public sector borrowing requirement when he had his mad railway program, his mad coal loader program, and every other mad thing he had when Malcolm Fraser decided that he would play Santa Claus to the States.

That is the Prime Minister's opinion, yet today we are passing legislation that reverts exactly to what Fraser did. It wipes out the Commonwealth's responsibility to control state borrowings. Ten years have been wasted. That is the story of the Labor Party. You guys must be the slowest learners in the world. They bring in an ex-premier of Western Australia who was part of a cabinet that wrecked the finances of that state and promote her as though she will be the next Prime Minister. In 1985 the Prime Minister condemned the fiscal responsibility that had been placed on state governments, but nine years later he is prepared to restore that responsibility. We wonder why we have this massive overseas debt. It is because the debt has been irresponsibly managed by the federal government.

PARA.TAB: One has only to look at the budget papers to understand where the funds have gone. A greater proportion of finances to state governments has been tied and a greater proportion of borrowings approved for specific purpose grants than there has been freedom of general purpose grants. The specific purpose grants have risen from 34 per cent to 41 per cent. If one looks at page 11 of last year's Budget Paper No. 3, entitled `Commonwealth financial relations with other levels of government 1993-94', one can easily assess the Commonwealth payments to the states and the way in which the Commonwealth has bled the states of direct finances so that it can use the huge amount of money it had borrowed itself. Page 71 refers to the borrowings program that was approved by the Loan Council for its replacement, the gentleman's agreements and all of those other arrangements having gone by the board. The Loan Council borrowings were reformed.

In 1992 the Loan Council came to a new agreement, a reform, that served three main purposes. Firstly, the new arrangements were to take account of practices that extended states borrowings and the imaginative application of those borrowing capacities and would allow closer monitoring of jurisdictional borrowings practices by other jurisdictions without the need for Loan Council approval. Secondly, per capita requirements were considered to be poor indicators of the jurisdiction's overall debt position. Thirdly, there was a requirement for provision of detailed information concerning jurisdictional net debt positions to the Loan Council. That was the 1992 position.

In 1994 the Loan Council reconfirmed its commitment made in 1992-93 to abolish the restriction on the states to borrow in their own name; remove the Commonwealth's explicit power to borrow on behalf of the states; remove the need for future borrowings by the Commonwealth or states to be approved under the agreement; admit the ACT and the Northern Territory as signatories to the agreement; and replace the existing agreement with new arrangements.

That has resulted in this legislation. The sinking fund has gone and we have the establishment of a new arrangement, the Financial Agreement Bill. The process has taken about four years, with high interest rates, hard management for state governments and with the Commonwealth clawing back its budget with no real sense of responsibility, just dragging money out of the states to its own advantage. Then, finally, the light dawns: `It gets so hard we have to make the states responsible.' Ten years have been lost. Once more the states are to be responsible for their own borrowings. If they blow it, the people of that state will count the state government responsible for blowing their budgets. That is a brilliant learning curve! It has taken the Commonwealth government 10 years to learn that.

I turn to the borrowing programs over the last five years of the states and the Commonwealth. I refer to the 1993-94 budget paper No.3, page 71, headed `Global New Money Borrowings by Commonwealth and State Semi-Government and Local Authorities'. If one looks at New South Wales, Victoria, Western Australia and the Commonwealth, one sees that there has been a pretty consistent and responsible attitude by the New South Wales government on borrowings over the period. We see a doubling in Victoria's global borrowings in a period of two years and even beyond that from $1,100 million to $3,100 million, a threefold increase in a period of four years. It is no wonder Victoria was in trouble; it increased its global borrowings by threefold over that period. I remind the House that that was in a period of high interest rates.

In Western Australia it was not so severe. Its borrowings increased by about 50 per cent over the same period. The Commonwealth's global borrowings clearly show the impact of the domestic deficit. The 1993-94 global borrowings total for the Commonwealth was $18,000 million, which includes the debt for the first time being brought into the global figures. As percentages of gross domestic product, the states' borrowings have increased, except for New South Wales. Victoria has doubled its borrowings, as one would expect. The total for Australia has massively increased, with the Commonwealth jumping from 0.4 per cent to 4.3 per cent as a total figure.

It all indicates poor management. So we have here today the sinking fund being abolished, the Commonwealth government saying that state governments are going to be responsible once more, the Prime Minister saying over a period of some years as Treasurer that it is irresponsible for the states to be given the opportunity to enter into borrowings in their own name but, having now decided that days are so desperate, that they must be given the right to borrow in their own name. I believe that is the story of this government. The Labor Party and the Australian people to some degree have been greatly misled by the Prime Minister with his loud-sounding, high flown phrases which indicate that he does not understand that the Commonwealth must take responsibility for these matters.
So after 10 years the states will now be responsible for their own borrowings. On 9 November 1988, Treasurer Keating said:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 7 of the bill is intended to make it a condition of the payment of general revenue grants to the states that all states should adhere to the global borrowing limits agreed to at the May Loan Council meeting by all states except Queensland. The Treasurer may reduce grants to any state exceeding those limits.

There is the strong hand, there is the whip to make states adhere to what the Commonwealth wanted to do. A few years later the government is throwing all of that out and saying, `That does not apply any more. We will let the states borrow in their own name. We will take the Loan Council responsibility out of the whole show.' The then Treasurer went on to say:

The amendment expands on the definition of `new borrowing' given in clause 3 . . . which . . . exclude any borrowings from the Commonwealth and include only borrowings that were the subject of the global approach resolution agreed to at the May Loan Council meeting by all States except Queensland, other than borrowings for refinancing purposes.

One can only conclude this debate by saying that the Commonwealth government has been derelict in its management of borrowed money. It has been careful to borrow as much as it can and has forced as much downstream as it can on the states. That has been done purely for the political purpose of making things look good for the Commonwealth government. There has been no gain. The Commonwealth cannot name a single major project, program, innovation or social change that has cost the amount of money that has been borrowed by it. It has been purely for the maintenance of government and for programs that make the government look good.

PARA.TAB: It is shameful that Australia has wasted so much time and will be held accountable in the long run to repay the money that has been borrowed. Australian people need something to show that their government is accountable, that their government is predictable in the way in which it approaches its problem and that ability and integrity, both in state governments and in the federal government, is rewarded. Too often we have seen states that have frittered away their funds rewarded by more grants or by a greater loan capacity. We need to see those that fritter away their resources and put people into unpayable debt penalised rather than encouraged. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I am pleased to have the opportunity to sum up on the Financial Agreement Bill and the National Debt Sinking Fund Repeal Bill, which have been debated first of all yesterday afternoon and now today. I thank the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) and the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) for their contributions to the debate.

PARA.TAB: These are important matters. They are a continuation of the evolutionary process of federal-state relations and a reflection of agreements that have been reached after quite detailed discussion by the Loan Council and, more recently, the Council of Australian Governments, with the agreement that was reached in February this year. Because of the contributions the honourable member for Mitchell made in the debate, people could be excused from thinking the bills do not reflect the change and the strategy that has been adopted of accountability, more scrutiny and transparency. That is precisely what these provisions and changes will mean. That is one of the fundamental consequences of the change to the introduction of the Financial Agreement Bill and the change from past practice in those areas.

So far from this being an exercise that could be construed as providing less scrutiny as far as state finances or borrowings are concerned, the very opposite will be true. It will put more onus and scrutiny on the states and, at the same time, it will bring into reflection the current day needs as far as federal-state programs and federal-state relations are concerned. I think the agreement signed in February is one that should be welcomed and passed through this parliament. As has been said already, it needs complementary legislation in each of the states for it to come into effect. I am sure that, based on the discussions that have been held to date, that will be forthcoming.

Federal-state relations bring in all sorts of issues, and that is the way the debate inevitably went—far beyond the provisions of the two bills. If we look at the period since 1901 in relation to the way federalism and programs have moved in that time, of course there have been changes. But when the constitution was drafted, the powers were drafted in a way that gave certain specified powers to the Commonwealth. Residual powers and a range of concurrent powers remained with the states.

I think the founding fathers of the constitution understood that there would be evolution in those arrangements. I do not think it should be assumed that they were all just concerned about incremental federalism. I think there was an acknowledgment that changes would evolve over time, and that is precisely what has occurred. The honourable member for Curtin referred to the changes in general purpose grants to the states. The fact is that under the current arrangements there are real term guarantees in relation to general purpose grants to the states. I think the most recent agreement was generally viewed as satisfactory as far as the states were concerned.

Since the mid-1970s there have been general purpose grants with real terms guarantees to local government as well. So these are trends that have occurred over that time. The Whitlam government introduced those measures. Pleasingly, they have been continued by government since that time. They have become an important part of the funding arrangements at that level as well.

When we compare the range of programs that governments provide these days with what was provided by government in 1901 or 1927, when the changed Loan Council arrangements came into effect, of course things have moved dramatically since then. We have assumed much more of a national identity than we had at that time. This is reflected in the types of programs that are adopted.

The honourable member for Curtin made the comment that in relation to education and schools, for example, the Commonwealth should just opt out. A good example of why that would be quite inappropriate is found in last night's budget. The Commonwealth has taken a very important initiative in relation to Asian languages in schools.

Unless we have a national initiative, a national approach to those issues, recognising Australia's national needs and imperatives over the next few years, in terms of the Asia-Pacific region and in terms of the opportunities the region offers to young people, clearly the Commonwealth would be abrogating its responsibilities if it did not take important steps in those programs. That is why there has been special purpose funding and why the specific purpose funds ratio has increased. But that is not something that I think we should reflect on in a negative sense; it reflects the Commonwealth looking to meet its international obligations in those areas and at the same time maintaining in real terms our commitment to general purpose grants.

The bills before the House recognise the development that has occurred since 1987 in relation to what Commonwealth borrowings have been and what state borrowings arrangements have been. They go further to give effect to more transparency in those arrangements for borrowings into the future. They recognise the states and their important obligations to meet their own financial objectives and to be accountable for them to their communities. I think it is a step in terms of consolidation of those federalism provisions and one that should be welcomed by the parliament.

In relation to some of the matters that might be of concern to honourable senators, given Senate committees and so on, again I think the point has to made that these arrangements were subject to agreement at the Council of Austrailian Governments meeting in February. I think the sorts of matters that the Senate select committee has suggested should be followed through need to be taken into account when we consider that this is what the states have been prepared to sign up for. They do give a very strong sense of accountability. They do give the states a sense of independent purpose in the way they do things, while being strongly publicly scrutinised.

For each of those reasons, I believe the bills are an important passage in that inter-governmental process of change so that evolution does occur. Despite the broad ranging comments of the debate and the attempts to move to the budget and other matters, which I could spend time on, we will have ample time to do that in the appropriations debate and so I will not do it now.

These bills are not about authoritarian control. They are not about breaking down the federal compact, as was suggested during the debate. They are not part of some centralist agenda, which was one of the other phrases that was used during the debate. They are complementary legislation that deals with the market realities of state borrowing and finances. They should be supported on that basis. I am pleased to recommend that the bills proceed to the second reading.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill gives legislative effect to several measures announced in the context of the 1993 budget and to a number of other changes. Some people with disabilities are unable to find jobs in the open labour market because their disability prevents them from being able to do the job to the level expected of people without disabilities. Under the existing award wage system, they have to be paid full award rates.

PARA.TAB: As announced in the 1993 budget, a new payment type, disability wage supplement, will be introduced from 1 July 1994. The supplement will be based on the qualification and payability conditions for disability support pension, and will be available each year for up to 1,000 people who enter the supported wage system administered by the Department of Human Services and Health. The supported wage system aims at assisting persons with a disability to enter the work force and will provide that the person may be paid less than the award wage based on his or her productivity compared with a person in the same occupation who does not have such a disability.

Disability wage supplement will be available at the same rates applicable to disability support pensioners and will be subject to similar rules, including the income and assets tests. As a result, income earned under the supported wage system by a disability wage supplement client will count as income for the purposes of determining a rate of disability wage supplement.

As part of the 1993 budget process, the government agreed that, from 1 January 1995, the maximum rate of additional family payment payable in respect of children who have not turned 16 should be increased by $1 a week per child. This bill gives effect to that agreement. Approximately 800,000 low income families will benefit from this measure at an estimated cost of $45 million in 1994-95 and $46 million in 1995-96.

To qualify for age pension, a woman currently must be 60 and a man, 65. This bill provides for amendments to be made to the Social Security Act 1991 to increase the pension age for women from 60 to 65. As announced in the 1993 budget, the increase is to be phased in over a 20-year period, starting on 1 July 1995, in recognition of any remaining labour force disadvantages incurred over the years by the older women affected by the proposal. By 1 July 2013, the women's age pension age will be 65 following pension age increases of six months every two years.

As mentioned previously, this bill gives effect to a number of non-budgetary measures. Firstly, the Social Security Act 1991 will be amended so as to impose a cap of 50 per cent on the rate of return for shares and managed investments for ordinary income assessment purposes. It will also be amended so as to provide that the rate of return of a managed investment or listed security that has not been available for the whole of a 12-month assessment period is to be calculated on the basis of the performance of the product to date without extrapolating that performance over the 12-month period. These are beneficial measures for social security clients.

Secondly, as a result of amendments made by the Migration Reform Act 1992 to the Migration Act 1958, major consequential changes will be made to the Migration Regulations by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to take effect on 1 September 1994. In turn, there is a need for amendments to be made to the Social Security Act 1991 to allow the Minister for Social Security to take account of these changes by way of disallowable instrument.

In a general sense, these amendments will ensure that relevant provisions in the Social Security Act will either refer to visas specified in the Migration Act or, if this is not possible, allow the minister to amend references to the Migration Regulations by way of disallowable instrument.

The third set of minor amendments are to overcome an unexpected loophole in the Social Security Act 1991 that has arisen as a result of a recent decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Social Security Act has always required that, for most social security payments to be payable, the recipient must provide his or her tax file number to the department if requested to do so by the secretary.

In 1993, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in Re Malloch and Secretary, Department of Social Security held that the principal act does not prevent payment to persons who refuse to provide a tax file number to the department on the basis that they do not have a tax file number and have no intention of getting one. Amendments in respect of all relevant payment types are included in this bill with a view to preventing payment in the situation that arose in Malloch's case.

Finally, the bill before the House provides for several minor amendments to be made to the Social Security Act 1991, the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 and the Farm Household Support Act 1992 that are consequential upon the introduction of the new home child-care and partner allowances by the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moylan Mrs J.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition does not intend to oppose the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994, which includes a number of amendments. Several are consequential or of a technical nature. However, some amendments concern us as a coalition. The first measure in this bill is the disability wage supplement. It was a 1993 budget initiative essentially designed to create a substantial saving for the government estimated at $4.49 million over three years. The agenda appears to be not so much concern for the placement of the disabled in the work force but for improvements to be made to the government's budget.

PARA.TAB: The government has stressed that the disability wage supplement is aimed at assisting people with disabilities to enter the work force. It would appear, though, that this is not much more than a pilot scheme. It affects only 1,000 people in 1994-95, in that there are only 1,000 places available. There are plans to increase that to 1,000 placements every fiscal year thereafter. Given that the government has not allocated funds in forward estimates, we question its ability to fund an ongoing program.

The coalition will not oppose this provision; however, we are concerned at the level of confusion between peak disability groups, people with disabilities and the businesses which employ the people with disabilities. It appears that some confusion may be due to the involvement of peak bodies being limited to the final stages of the negotiation process. Many groups working with the employment of disabled people have expressed concern regarding the supported wage system. There is also some anxiety among employer groups that those selected for this program will lose their right to self-determination and that, rather than implementing an integrating process, the provision makes a greater distinction between those with disabilities and other workers.

The provision that the disabled must undergo an assessment every 12 months serves only to widen the gulf between the disabled and other workers, and, in addition, builds distrust of the employer groups in a scheme which relies very heavily on the goodwill of such people. We believe unions will provide some of the assessors. There is a notion that union assessors, unlike others, will not have to undergo any specific training for that task.

The disability sector has raised a number of concerns with us. The low number of places in the scheme will not dramatically reduce numbers on the disability support pension. The disability statistics provided by DEET, DHSH and DSS back up this assertion. A total of 159,693 persons with disabilities were registered at CES offices at the end of July 1993. Of this total, 96,692 people with disabilities, or 60 per cent, were registered for more than 12 months. These figures exclude approximately 20,000 people with a disability already working in sheltered workshops. These estimates are from October 1993. A total of 406,729 people were in receipt of the disability support pension administered by the Department of Social Security at the end of June 1993.

The cumbersome and bureaucratic nature of the placing of the thousand people gives rise to the question, when we talk to people who are working in this area, of whether this is the most appropriate use of what seems to be very scarce resources. This measure involves a substantial addition of staff through the DHSH and the cost of employing a team of assessors, some of whom will have to undergo special training.

These continue to be some of the concerns that have been related to us from the disability sector. There is confusion regarding the level of DWS payments. There is no provision to assist employers with regard to the ongoing costs employers of disabled persons may incur. The government has made provision only for the initial outlays. There are insurance implications that do not seem to have been well considered.

The marketing strategy for SWS, the supported wage system, as being a source of cheap labour for business is another concern that has been raised with the coalition. There have been individual concerns raised from people who fear that the supported wage system will mean an immediate loss of their part-time income. Therefore, whilst not opposing this measure, I foreshadow the coalition's intention in the Senate to refer this provision to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Services.

The next measure in this bill involves family payments. This amendment which came about as a deal with the Greens last year to get the budget through. It amounts to $1 per week per child. This will not sufficiently compensate low income earners, who will suffer the most from Labor's regressive increases in wholesale sales tax announced in the 1993 budget. Nevertheless, it was part of the budget negotiations which will be of some, although limited, benefit to those on low income. We will not oppose this measure.

A further measure in the bill relates to managed investments. The government's original motive for bringing down measures that penalise self-funded retirees was based on the usual standard, slipshod practice of saving a few dollars at the expense of those people who have been able to build a nest egg for themselves. The government struck a blow against a prudent form of self-provision.

The two measures in this bill are designed, fortunately, to lessen some of the difficulties experienced by 100,000 Australian pensioners. Both measures are beneficial in that they alleviate some of the very worst effects of the legislation. The first measure imposes a cap of 50 per cent on the rate of return for shares and managed investments for ordinary income assessment purposes and acknowledges that high rates of return cannot be justified in assessing pensions.

The second measure deals with the experience arising from the Commonwealth Bank float where shares were acquired at a price which was considerably higher than the price at which the shares were originally listed. However, the initial list price was the figure used for the 12-month assessment period resulting in an exaggeration of the true performance of the investment. The amendment will ensure that this will not occur, particularly in cases where there is active trading in shares or units within a short period of time.

The Australian Stock Exchange believes the amendments seem to ameliorate two of the more extreme of the illogical effects of treating unrealised capital gains as income for the income and assets test. However, it maintains that the whole system remains fundamentally inequitable. I made the following point in the House last year and I reinforce my assertion:

SPEECH.PARA: The government has no understanding of the motivation of small investors. It proceeds on the ignorant collectivist assumption that the stock market is a giant lottery where the punters scan the newspapers for the right moment to seize a windfall capital gain. It does not wish to understand that so many Australian shareholders have no interest in speculative gains but hold shares in blue-chip industrial companies that provide them with a fairly steady income and modest dividend income. Such investors are often likely to sell their shares only in the event of a takeover, and to them the whole question of nominal gains and losses is an irrelevance.

I have had constituents in my office who, due to these provisions, have not found the notional capital gains helpful when it comes to paying the telephone bill or the electricity bill. A paper gain is an absurd premise on which to base the determination of pensioner entitlements. While the coalition supports the amendments, we continue to strenuously oppose a system that treats unrealised capital gains on shares and investments as income for pension income and assets test purposes. We maintain that this legislation is inequitable.

PARA.TAB: This change has the hallmark of a government that knows it has made a bad decision, but lacks the courage to admit its mistake and return a measure of social justice to the pension income test. It is a supposed compromise that admits error but does not alter the basic problem. It simply illustrates that the government lacks the courage of its own conviction. We are hopeful that, when the review into the income and assets test brings down its findings, it will recommend that the current treatment of shares of managed investments be abolished. To that end, I move:

That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for its iniquitous treatment of unrealised capital gains on shares and managed investments as income for the pension income and assets test".

The next provision in this bill relates to migration law. The amendment in this respect will help to reduce the lag which occurs between changes to migration law and the Social Security Act. Lag occurs because most changes to migration law are regulatory, whereas social security amendments are not. These amendments are largely technical in nature and not unreasonable, and we do not intend to oppose them.

As for the amendment in relation to an increase in pension age for women, this provision is another Fightback initiative pinched by the government. It is simply another episode of political larceny that this government has elevated to an art form. On 7 August 1992, after the coalition announced its decision to bring the pension age for women into line with that of men, the then Minister for Social Security, Dr Neal Blewett, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition move to increase the women's pension age to 65 within 5 years is premature, ill-considered and unfair . . .
Women who have faced greatly restricted opportunities and discrimination during their lives are being offered last minute equality to save the Opposition money.
Dr Blewett then said:
It's the sort of two-card trick you wouldn't expect anyone to play on the elderly, but it's just one of a huge range of hidden "nasties" in the Fightback package.
He went on to say:

The lower pension age for women is due recognition of the fact that many older women devoted most of their lives to their families and sacrificed employment, savings and superannuation in the process. When women of pension age have had similar opportunities as their male counterparts, that will be the time to equalise pension ages, not before.

Opposition policy would see women in their forties and fifties having to alter their retirement plans drastically. For many it would mean a substantial loss of income and late-age entry onto the unemployment queues.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has changed since then?

—Nothing. To claim that the government was opposed to this measure at the election and then to announce it in the next budget only five months later shows the complete contempt in which this government holds the Australian electorate. The government's backflip has been strongly criticised by the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation, the Combined Pensioners and Superannuants Association of New South Wales and the Catholic Women's League of Victoria and Wagga Wagga. In fact, only yesterday I received a position paper from the Combined Pensioners and Superannuants Association of New South Wales on this very issue.

PARA.TAB: The concerns of many in the community about this particular amendment relate to those women who were born between approximately 1934 and 1959 and who had little opportunity, due to the social context of the time, to accumulate savings and to contribute to superannuation funds. Pre equal opportunity and affirmative action legislation, including equal pay for equal work, many women received lower wages for equivalent work than men, and many of the women in this age bracket did not work at all. Even today, a question arises because all of the figures show that women are still earning less than their male counterparts. Until we redress that situation, it would seem to me that perhaps not enough thought has been given to those who will be disadvantaged by this particular amendment to the social security legislation.

It appears that the government has done nothing to either determine how many women fall into this age bracket or how they might be adversely affected by the measure. We do not oppose this measure; we advocated it at the last election and will continue to do so. It is the way in which that measure is adopted. It is a shame that the government lacks consistency in regard to its own policies.

The next measure in this bill is the refusal to apply for a tax file number. This provision, as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mrs Crosio) has already pointed out, results from an Administrative Appeals Tribunal decision between the department and Mr John Malloch, when Mr Malloch's disability support pension was suspended due to his refusal to provide a tax file number and his refusal to provide authority to request a tax file number from the Australian Taxation Office. The purpose of this amendment is to allow the secretary to the department to refuse assistance payments to individuals who do not have a tax file number or have no intention of applying for one.

The coalition is aware that one of the triggers for this amendment is the high cost of fraud in the social security area, and we are aware of the heavy burden fraud places on the Australian people. There are some doubts, though, that the continued foray into the private lives of Australian citizens via the use of the tax file number provides the total answer to fraud control. That is very heavily supported by an action recently involving Leonard Teale, the actor.

The Australian newspaper on 16 March this year reported in an article headed `Teale in dogfight over pension' some of Mr Teale's concerns—and just by way of background, Mr Teale served his country, Australia, as a young Royal Australian Air Force pilot in Jerusalem in mid-1944. He got into a scrap over not providing his tax file number. He refused to give his tax file number because he felt that, as a person who had risked his life to save his country, had come back, was entitled to receive a pension, and was asked for his tax file number, he should not be so shabbily treated by this government. His pension was suspended because he stood his ground and refused to supply the number. The government backed down later on and restored his pension even though he had not provided his tax file number.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing to do with his high profile?
—I am sure, yes, absolutely. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: A stand-off has developed, with Teale refusing on principle to provide his tax file number and the Government refusing to pay his pension until he does so.
In the article, Mr Teale said:
It is really an extraordinary invasion of a person's privacy.
We were prepared to give our lives in the war for Australia to remain a democracy. In a democratic society you do not have a dictatorship.
For a person to be forced to give information which is private for no good reason is the actions of a dictatorship and should not be happening in a democratic country—it is a matter of principle.

While we as a coalition are distinctly uncomfortable with the expansion of the tax file number system, it is an issue that continues to give rise to considerable concern to this community. In 1988 there was a spirited debate about the merits of introducing a tax file number system. The honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) agreed on behalf of the opposition to support that legislation only because of changes made by the government to the original bill which sought to safeguard the privacy of citizens by a voluntary tax file number system. The honourable member for Kooyong said:
. . . what we have convinced the government to accept is that the tax file number system has to be voluntary. It cannot be some sort of licence to exist.
The then Treasurer, Mr Keating, said in response:

The amendments the government has agreed to accept are designed to guarantee that the tax file numbering system is completely voluntary. They ensure that taxpayers will in all circumstances retain the right to elect to have tax withheld at source rather than quote their tax file number. The government has always recognised that this is an important element in the set of privacy safeguards which attached to the tax file number system and these amendments will enshrine that principle in legislation.

It appears now that the government is using jackboot tactics to force people into applying for a tax file number through the social security department. It is understood that the privacy commissioner has some concerns regarding this aspect of the bill and his preference would have been for the amendment that:
. . . made clear that the decision as to whether or not an individual provides or applies for a tax file number, in full knowledge of the consequences, rests with the individual.

Matters of privacy and identity cards have long given rise to deep public concern, and the coalition makes it clear that we would, in government, re-examine this issue, carefully weighing the arguments. We are concerned that frequently the reason given for using the tax file number system in this way in the Department of Social Security is to counteract fraud.

PARA.TAB: That is only part of the picture. I think the loss of personal privacy and liberty by all Australians is too great a price to pay to counteract the small amount of fraud that is detected. In any event, it would appear that tax file number systems do not entirely correct the difficulties in detecting fraud. We suggest that perhaps the government should use its imagination a little and look at other ways to administer the affairs of the department to counteract those difficulties experienced in detecting fraud, rather than eroding the rights of Australian citizens, treating all Australian citizens as the lowest common denominator and assuming that they are going to try to rip the system off. I do not believe that. I believe that the majority of Australians are decent, honest people who do not attempt to rip the system off. I do not think there is a need to pass legislation that makes that assumption. I think the tax file number system is starting to head that way.
The coalition will not oppose this provision, but we do note, on departmental advice, that the government will be introducing amendments into the Senate which the coalition will be closely examining.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't they do it here?

—That is a good question. The other aspect of this amendment bill that I want to mention deals with compensation. The coalition does support this provision, which is a result of measures which have been endorsed by us. It effectively removes the exemption from the definition of compensation for personal sickness and accident insurance payments where the policy contains an offset clause. The offset clause enables the insurer to only be liable to pay the insured person the amount which would ordinarily be paid under the policy minus the amount of social security payments the person received during the relevant period. This measure is obviously beneficial and the coalition will not oppose it. The other amendments in this bill are consequential, minor or technical in nature. We do not intend to oppose any of those measures.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! During the honourable member's speech, she moved a second reading amendment. Is the amendment seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

—I am pleased to participate in this debate this morning and to support the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). I welcome the contribution by the honourable member for Pearce (Mrs Moylan), acting in the role of shadow social security spokesperson, and I welcome her to that position. On behalf of members of the government, I express our sincere condolences to the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) in the recent loss of his mother, which is the reason why the honourable member for Pearce is acting in his role.

PARA.TAB: I thank the coalition for its support for this bill, even though it has raised a number of questions and has proposed an amendment to the bill. As the honourable member for Pearce outlined, there are a number of different clauses in the bill. These cover the introduction of a disability wage supplement; a measure to increase family payments; a question on managed investments, which is the subject of the proposed amendment; amendments to take account of migration law; the measure to increase the pension age for women gradually over the next 20 years; the question about the refusal to apply for a tax file number; and some other consequential amendments to various acts.

I would like to concentrate my remarks this morning on two key parts of the amendments proposed in this bill: firstly, the introduction of a disability wage supplement and, secondly, the question about the gradual phasing in of the raising of the retirement age for women. If I have enough time, I might make some comments on a couple of the other measures that the honourable member for Pearce has expressed views about.

Firstly, I refer to the question of the disability wage supplement. As with all the other measures, this is a very positive measure which is welcomed by honourable members on this side of the House and the community at large. I acknowledge that it is a small program, that it needs to be expanded and that it is, in some way, acting as a pilot, as are a number of measures that the government is introducing with regard to assisting people with disabilities to enter the work force. But that is very much the way in which the disability community would like us to react. It wants us to introduce a range of initiatives and to find out what is the best way to manage this issue.

The decision to introduce this disability wage supplement was announced in last year's budget. Under the disability wage supplement, employers will be able to employ disabled people at less than award rates where their productivity is deemed to be less than that of a non-disabled person. The government will then provide a supplementary payment similar to a part rate disability support pension. The program has the support of peak employer and employee bodies and aims to increase the employment opportunities for disabled people without their being financially disadvantaged.

A number of difficulties are involved in Australia in determining the extent of disability and the effect that that disability has on people's employability, their skills or what their rate of pay should be for their contribution in the work force. The surveys of the Australian Bureau of Statistics use a wide definition of `disability', while that used by the Social Security Act 1991 is based on a person having at least a 20 per cent impairment. As all honourable members would know, that tends to be a very subjective measurement. It is very hard to determine what is a 20 per cent disability. I am sure all of us have had constituents come to us with concerns about the fact that they have applied for a pension based on disability but have been refused because they have not been deemed to be 20 per cent disabled. It is an issue of ongoing concern for a lot of people.

The focus of government actions in relation to people with disabilities since the 1980s has altered from providing specific institutions for disabled people to greater integration with the community. That is something that should be applauded, and I know it is supported by both sides of politics. This can be seen from programs where we have been closing institutions for people with mental disabilities and replacing them with community accommodation. There has also been a similar trend with regard to people with other disabilities.

One of the many changes in this area has been the movement away from large institutionalised sheltered workshops to schemes that encourage disabled people to participate in the mainstream labour force. Currently, such schemes are based on finding employment at award wages through the competitive employment, training and placement program; supported employment where the government directly employs disabled people, usually in small work groups; and the provision of training through special programs and mainstream programs such as jobstart and skillshare.

I note that the honourable member for Pearce indicated the opposition's intention to have this matter referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. I draw her attention to the fact that the employment of people with disabilities was examined by the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs which released its report in April 1992. The report examined existing schemes which assist disabled people to gain employment and it made a number of recommendations for improvements to the situation. This disability wage supplement is part of the committee's recommendations. We are implementing recommendations of that Senate standing committee.

The committee made a whole series of recommendations, all of which I support, which went to a range of government agencies who are involved in assisting people with disabilities to get into the work force and to stay there. The committee recommended that the Commonwealth government implement a wage system to meet the income needs of people with disabilities unable to work full time at or above award wages and that the Commonwealth direct resources towards ensuring that at least a living wage, which may be made up of part pension and part wage, should be the basis of pay received by people with disabilities in paid employment, even though this may not be an award wage.

So it is clear that the government's introduction of this disability wage supplement is consistent with the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. It was supported by both sides at the time. It is now being introduced in this legislation and should be supported.

The question of people with disabilities gaining access to employment is one that I have been personally involved with for the whole period that I have been a member. I have been working very closely with the various ministers for human services and health and whatever various titles we have had for that department over the last four years to try to improve access for people with disabilities to the work force.

Of particular concern to me have been opportunities for people exiting school, finishing at special schools and then, at the age of 18, being left virtually high and dry with nowhere else to go. There does not seem to be a lot of coordination by the various government agencies to assist those people to then go that next stage into further training, further employment, assisted employment or whatever. It is not just the responsibility of one government agency; a number of government agencies both at the Commonwealth level and at the state level are required to get their act together to assist these people. At the Commonwealth level, the Department of Social Security, the Department of Human Services and Health and DEET all have a responsibility.

The Department of Social Security and the Department of Human Services and Health have been reasonably good. There is some room for improvement but they have basically been pretty good in providing assistance for people with disabilities and coordinating government support. My biggest area of criticism is with DEET. I do not think DEET has met its responsibilities in assisting people with disabilities to enter training programs and get employment. DEET has expected other government agencies to do that for it. It has been one of my criticisms that I do not seem to be able to get much of a response from my DEET officers in trying to tackle this problem.

In my area I have at the moment some sixty 18-year-olds with a range of disabilities attending special schools who will be seeking to leave those schools and who will have no place to go. It is a matter of some concern to me that I have great difficulty in getting DEET to accept that it has some part to play. I have no problem getting the disability sector of Human Services and Health to be involved and to try to assist, but it also needs the support of DEET. We need to make sure that the regional officers of DEET can coordinate access to training programs, to TAFE colleges, to other private providers of training and to assisted employment much more than they do, instead of expecting the Department of Human Services and Health to do all the work.

Early this year the government announced a new program called jobnet, which is designed to coordinate the provision of vocationally oriented assistance to people with a disability. Again it is a program under the Department of Human Services and Health. It appears that Human Services and Health has had to assume the responsibilities that DEET has of providing vocational education and training assistance. It is unfortunate that we cannot get a coordinated program amongst the three departments for people with a disability as we have so successfully been able to achieve with the JET program, where we have been trying to assist people on single parent pensions to get back into the work force. It has been a very successful program of coordination between DEET, DSS and Human Services and Health to identify and coordinate the various needs of those people so that people can get training and then go back into the work force. We should be getting a much better coordinated program in place for people with disabilities. DEET needs to pick up its game there.

The one problem I have with the jobnet program is that it only concentrates on the vocational orientated assistance. It is not picking up other areas of support that is required. The family of a person with disabilities needs somebody not only to help get that young person a job or into training but also to assist with the transportation needs of that person, with further nursing or support that may be needed when the person is in an institution or workplace and assistance with accommodation. A range of other assistance measures may be needed, not just training. Therefore, we need to get a program in place that appoints case managers. In the white paper we had a lot of talk about appointing case managers to help young people get jobs. People with disabilities probably have an even greater need for a case manager that can coordinate all of the government agencies at a Commonwealth and a state level to fix up all of those needs.

One of the complaints that families of people with disabilities make to me all the time is that, whenever they want to access any sort of program to help the family member progress to the next stage in his or her life, they have to set up a committee and lobby to get money to do all these things, whereas a normal, able-bodied person can go straight in. They ask, `Why do we always have to fight, form committees, write submissions and lobby just to get access to those basic things?' I agree with them. It is not just the Commonwealth responsibility, because half of those things I talked about are state responsibilities. We need to get both levels of government working together and appointing case managers so that, when a child reaches 17 or 18 years of age and leaves a special school or a mainstream school, the family can go to this person and say, `What is the next stage?' This person can then coordinate all of the various levels of assistance.

That program works to some degree in Western Australia, the state the honourable member for Pearce comes from. We in the caucus community services committee have looked at that model and have been urging the government to consider it. I understand that a pilot of that model will be introduced in this financial year. I am not exactly sure where, but I understand some funding will be put in place for the appointment of such a coordinated program. I think that case management process would be a very successful program for people with disabilities. It can then bring together all of the various streams of government assistance that is provided through the Department of Social Security and the Department of Human Services and Health. Maybe it will get DEET off its backside to do some more work, as it should be, for people with disabilities, and also coordinate state government agencies to provide transportation, accommodation, health services, et cetera. So that is where I would certainly like to see further assistance provided by the government in the future.

The other area I would like to comment on in this bill is that of the phasing in period of the retirement age of women, which is to increase to 65. The honourable member for Pearce made a lot of play about the fact that this was a proposal put into Fightback, that the government opposed the opposition's proposition in Fightback and then, six months later, introduced it in the budget. The honourable member for Pearce failed to compare the two proposals. The proposal in Fightback was for an almost immediate introduction of a retirement age to 65 for women, phased in over five years.

The government announced this last August and gave two years notice of its intention to do this. It brought in a phasing in period which is very gradual—a six-month stepped increase each two years, so it takes 20 years for it to be fully introduced. That was a far more reasonable and sensible proposition. The government clearly opposed the opposition's proposal, because it would have been unfair, too fast and would have created enormous difficulties for a lot of people. The government's proposal is a much more reasonable and realistic way of introducing it. That is why there is quite a contrast.

The second and probably more important point that we need to make concerns the reasons why the government believes that it can go down this way. Through this government's policies in labour market reform and in the introduction of a superannuation guarantee, we are ensuring that women have much greater access to superannuation coverage than they would have had under a coalition government.

Let us not forget the other plank that was in Fightback. The opposition intended to abolish the superannuation guarantee charge. That would have had quite a negative impact on women's capacity to access superannuation. Superannuation coverage has increased from 40 per cent in August 1988 to 94.1 per cent in August 1993 for women employed full time and from nine per cent to 45.7 per cent for women employed in part-time positions. That has been achieved under this government.

The opposition's policies, in attacking the superannuation guarantee charge, would have destroyed that success. They would have eliminated in large measure superannuation coverage for those women who had it. It is because of our work on superannuation and the fact that we are phasing this in gradually over the next 20 years to the year 2013 that we can confidently predict that it will have very minimal impacts on women in their access to superannuation and other forms of income through the work force.

It has been under this government that we have seen quite significant improvements in the participation rate of women in the work force. Over the last 10 years that participation rate has increased dramatically because of our policies, which have assisted women to re-enter the work force through increased access to training programs, employment programs and work force programs. This government has also assisted them by the massive increase in the provision of child-care support.

One needs to look in total at the policies that the opposition was proposing and at its past performance compared with this government's performance. When we look at what we have done in superannuation, in workplace training and in giving women much greater access to the work force and to child care, we can see that this government has been responsible for ensuring that many more women have opportunities to work, to earn larger amounts of money and to raise their own personal retirement benefits through superannuation and other means. Therefore, this is a reasonable policy that we are introducing in allowing a phasing-in over 20 years.

Let us look at the international situation. I have a list of about 15 OECD countries with similar economic development to Australia that have equal retirement ages for men and women. The retirement age is 65 for men and 65 for women. This is not some dramatic change that we are introducing that is contrary to international experience. It is supported by the women's movement and it is supported by the Council on the Aging. In fact, the Council on the Aging had a proposal which was a more dramatic introduction than the one we are introducing. I think both measures should be supported. I commend the bill to the House. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth Ms P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) gives effect to several measures announced in the 1993 budget and to a number of other changes which will have a significant impact on the elderly and the disabled in particular. Despite the strength of this impact, the federal government has once again dumped many measures together in one bill.

PARA.TAB: The bill requires careful scrutiny as it covers a wide area of far-reaching administrative and policy changes. It revises the wage setting framework for the disabled. It increases the pension age for women to 65. It caps the deemed return from listed securities and managed investments at 50 per cent. It allows greater administrative flexibility in response to change in immigration laws. It increases the rate of family payment by $2 per fortnight. Also it puts beyond doubt that receiving a social security benefit is provisional upon submitting a tax file number. Many of these measures will be beneficial to Australians and have coalition support, but there will be winners and losers because the federal government often gets things wrong at the start.

Some amendments are nothing but a knee-jerk reaction to legislation which has been denounced as unfair and fundamentally flawed at the start. There are others that could fail miserably despite the best of intentions. The introduction of the disability wage supplement, for example, aims to broaden employment opportunities for the disabled in the open labour market, but the coalition notes that many sensitive issues remain unresolved. Under the supported wage system, the disabled will be paid less than award wages based on a formula calculated to measure and compare their productivity with a `normal' worker doing the same job.

This will form an assessed wage paid by the employer, which will then be supplemented by the disability wage supplement paid by the Department of Social Security and based on the qualification and payability provisions of the disability support pension. But many within the disability industry, while pleased with the concept, have doubts about the administration and outcomes. As a result, we believe these concerns about the disability wage supplement should be heard by the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs when the legislation reaches the other house. In light of the feedback from advocacy and disabled groups, it is important that the bill faces further scrutiny.

I note that the previous speaker, the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson), who sadly is not here to hear me say this, spoke very sensitively about the needs of the disabled. They are obviously important to him, and he understands the role of carers and the way they are disadvantaged. I am also well aware of the earlier Senate inquiry into this matter and its recommendations. The honourable member mentioned that the disabled groups are bringing up concerns relating to the administration of this area, and I think it is entirely appropriate that their concerns be heard by the Senate committee. Perhaps some small amendments will be made to help the disabled.

Assessment procedures may leave the disabled open to exploitation in the workplace. How and who determines what is 60 or 80 per cent of a standard worker when there is no benchmark measurement? According to Disabled People's International in South Australia, there are concerns that disabled people desperate to secure work will trade off a lower assessed wage in return for employment and therefore not receive any financial benefit. Disabled People's International does not want sheltered workshops simply broken up into the community; it wants a proper program which will take the disabled beyond where they are now.

Prevailing economic and labour market conditions mean that opportunities for the disabled are low. In a country where the number of long-term unemployed has exceeded 300,000 and where the unemployment rate hovers around 10 per cent, surely opportunities are already limited for all Australians, not just the disabled. The emphasis is on increased productivity, international competitiveness and enterprise bargaining, which must marginalise opportunities for those who cannot work at the optimum rate. What about the cost for the employer? It is important that the Senate standing committee be allowed to examine these concerns, even though the scheme is due for introduction across Australia on 1 July. There are only 1,000 places available and 80 of those are earmarked for South Australia.

This bill also brings the pension entitlement for women in line with that for men. This government, in cheating and scaremongering its way back into power at the last election, made some fairly outrageous claims. In campaign material to residents of the electorate of Kingston, the then Minister for Social Security said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has gone very quiet on its heartless policy to lift the pension age for women from 60 to 65. But it's still there. Is it something you really want?

Yet it was something that the federal government secretly did want. The August budget announced and endorsed this very `heartless' policy that the minister had denigrated less than six months before that, and today it is enshrined in this bill.

PARA.TAB: This is another demonstration of the dishonesty, distortion and broken promises from a government which campaigned on removing pensioners from the tax system and then reneged days after the election. In principle, I support the concept of men and women being treated equally. People are now living longer and women live longer than men. Broken work patterns resulting from child rearing and family responsibilities mean that women do not have the same capacity as men to plan financially for their retirement.

It has only been in recent times that women have had access to superannuation, so they will need another five years of earning a salary to avoid poverty. But this is only an advantage for those women in the paid work force. Again, there are losers. Even the government has acknowledged how difficult it can be for both men and women to be aged 60 and out of work. Although it has only a two-year life span, these people aged 60 and without work are currently entitled to the mature age allowance.
