This relieves them of having to go through the activity test associated with newstart. It also has the effect of removing them from the published unemployment figures. There would not be a member in this House who has not had contact through his or her electorate with those who are of mature years but who are too young for an age pension and, realistically in the current economic climate, too old for a paid job.

The provision of the bill that deals with managed investments and listed securities and assessing non-realised capital gains as income for pension purposes is the subject of the amendment moved by the honourable member for Pearce (Mrs Moylan) which I was pleased to second. The only good thing that can be said of the provision to cap deemed income at 50 per cent is that 50 per cent is better than anything higher than 50 per cent. The fact remains that these changes are subject to an independent review of the pensions income and assets test, which is now under way.

Those in the community who have been thrifty and anxious to provide for their retirement have been patiently awaiting the outcome of this inquiry, which the coalition has sought since 1988 and which only this year has been taken up by the government. The 1988 legislation which dealt with managed investments was flawed. The cap is a compromise in commonsense to what was a bad piece of legislation in the first place.

The age pension is the cornerstone of independence in the retirement of older Australians. But it is universally acknowledged that it is cost prohibitive to provide a pension to all retirees regardless of their income and assets.
As a nation, our long-term objective must be to ease the burden on age pension payments. This means that people must be encouraged to save. But the government sends all the wrong messages.

Older people need predictability. The 50 per cent cap goes some way towards avoiding the wild swings in pension payments. But the reality remains that pensioners cannot eat their capital gains. In their desire for a predictable pension, part pensioners will be excused if they follow the message `Squander your savings, sell your assets and then you will qualify for a pension and a predictable income'.

There are significant concerns about the inequities, inconsistencies and inefficiencies in the current system. This system is resulting in older people making decisions not on the basis of the investment product but on the basis of its impact on social security entitlements. While it is impossible to fix every anomaly or inequity, current decisions by the government always seem to be reactive with no firm ground rules or underlying principles. We now have the totally inequitable situation of separate classes of pensioners receiving different treatment regardless of their income and assets but dependent upon the time they purchase their investment. There is also the need for complex calculation and record keeping, which means higher administration costs for the government and unstable pension rates for recipients.

With an ageing population, there is a real need for sensible legislation and planning. The Economic Planning Advisory Council's latest report, Australia's ageing society, predicts that the number of aged people will rise from 1.9 million in 1991 to more than 5 million by the year 2051 when more than one person in five will be over the age of 65. There will be a six-fold increase in people aged 80 and over from 373,000 to more than 2 million by 2051. According to one of the report's authors, Ross Clare, this means that the proportion of the over 80s will jump from 2.2 per cent in 1991 up to eight per cent by 2051.

Understandably, it is this age group which calls upon a disproportionate amount of money via the public purse. The report also said that by 2051 part pensions will need to be provided for about 75 per cent of the aged, who will not be able to rely on adequate superannuation payouts.

When consulting with groups and individuals in my electorate about this legislation, I receive the constant advice that this provision of the bill is further tinkering with what was originally bad legislation. In reality, this is tinkering with the lives of people, many of whom have worked hard in supporting their families and paying their taxes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Allow me to congratulate you, Mr Deputy Speaker Rocher, on being formally installed as the second deputy speaker. You will no doubt do your job in the chair in your usual very efficient and impartial manner. The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 has a number of purposes. Some of these are to give effect to measures announced in the 1993-94 budget and other major changes. I think it is fairly ironic that it has taken eight or nine months for these amendments to come before the House in legislative form. Indeed, it is particularly ironic as a very disastrous budget was handed down by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) last night.
—Not even you believe that.

—I do believe it and I am pleased that the honourable member for Prospect is indeed laughing at the Treasurer's pathetic efforts last night. This bill aims to do a number of things: introduce a disability wage supplement, increase the pension eligibility age for women from 60 to 65 years, increase the rate of family payment by $2 per fortnight, cap the deemed returns from listed securities and managed investments, and allow more administrative flexibility in response to changes in immigration laws. In the time allocated to me, I intend to concentrate mainly on the aspect of the legislation dealing with shares and managed investments, an area of Labor government which has sparked an angry reaction from pensioners and retirees not only throughout my own electorate of Fisher but indeed throughout the entire country.

PARA.TAB: Before I do that, I mention some other matters included in the bill. There is an amendment to the Social Security Act relating to the disability wage supplement. That was part of the 1993-94 budget. The disability wage supplement is a payment which will be available to disabled people who enter the work force under the supported wage system, a program administered by the Department of Human Services and Health. Under the supported wage system, disabled workers are assessed by employers and the union or an accredited assessor to determine the amount of work they can do as a percentage of the work a person without a disability can do. It is a laudable aim that we give every opportunity to those who are disabled to perform a worthwhile role in the work force. Those people will then be paid a percentage of the award wage based on productivity.

The disability wage supplement, which provides additional income support, is paid under the same eligibility conditions as the disability support pension but differs in some areas. These include that persons remain qualified for DWS for 12 months after gaining full award wages, enabling them to receive the income supplement if their wage falls below award. The disability support pension is restricted to people unable to work full time at full award wages.

The government has allocated 1,000 places under this scheme in 1994-95. This amendment has caused confusion and concern amongst groups and businesses who train and employ disabled people. In other words, the government is making it more difficult for the community and business to assist those people who are indeed the object of assistance under this legislation.

To avoid further confusion and misunderstanding, I very strongly support the suggestion from this side of the House that this amendment be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs for further consideration. Far too often, Mr Deputy Speaker—you would know this as you have been here for many years—we see legislation that is processed through the parliament as if it were a sausage machine. The legislation is defective, with the result that the minister must enter the parliament to seek further amendments. I think an ounce of prevention is better than a ton of cure and I really think our request that this matter be referred to the Senate committee is indeed very appropriate.

For a number of years employer groups, unions and the Department of Human Services and Health have been negotiating the supported wages issue. The whole issue has emerged as a result of efforts on the part of the Department of Industrial Relations, the Department of Human Services and Health and the former minister to move people with disabilities out of sheltered employment and into open employment. There are many groups in the community who have serious concerns about the placement of disabled people in the open work force. I imagine that we could talk to any number of people in the community and get differing views. There are some who say that it is beneficial and appropriate that disabled people be as much as possible in the general workplace. There are others who feel that disabled people, because of their disability, are better suited to working in an appropriate sheltered workshop. I suppose that it really depends on the degree of disability.

Another concern of disability groups is the fact that the government is just scratching the surface of this problem. The number of placements available—1,000—is not enough even to fill current requirements. I understand that, at the end of July 1993, almost 160,000 people with disabilities—that is, 160 times the number of places being made available by the government—were registered at the CES. Many people also share my concern that the bureaucracy is far too cumbersome. The bureaucracy in this country has not served the people well and any amendment which seeks to hand over more authority to the bureaucracy is probably moving in the wrong direction.

There is also confusion and misunderstanding over the level of the disability wage supplement. There are no provisions for on-costs that may occur as a result of employment of a person with a disability. Insurance implications associated with employing a disabled person have been ignored. That is fairly unfortunate. I hope the government takes it on board, because insurance implications in today's litigious society are very important.

There are concerns relating to training, to assessment of disabled employees, to the use of the SWS as cheap labour for business and individual concerns that the scheme will mean that people with disabilities will lose part of their income or that the system might be abused by some employers to reduce the wages of people with a disability who are already in employment. Disability organisations, sadly, have had limited input into the negotiation of the disability wage supplement, making a mockery of the government's consultation process. Because of this and the concerns I have previously listed, it is really vital that this matter be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, which would enable the proposed changes to be very closely looked at.

Other measures in the bill include increasing the maximum additional family payment by $1 per week per child under the age of 16. This measure was part of the result that emerged from the budget negotiations with the Greens after the delivery of the 1993 budget by the former Treasurer. Neither this nor the amendments to take account of the migration law are being opposed by the coalition. The migration law amendments are of a technical nature, aiming to reduce the lag between changes to the migration law and changes to the principal act.

There has been discussion in this House over the proposal to increase the pension age for women from 60 to 65 years. As has been mentioned, this was the coalition's policy before the last election and it was condemned by the government. One need only look at the remarks made prior to the election by the then Minister for Social Security, Dr Blewett, who described the coalition's policy as `premature, ill-considered, extremely harsh and unfair'. He also said, `It is the sort of two-card trick you would not expect anyone to play on the elderly.' It is the two-card trick that this government is playing today on elderly women.

In this matter, as in so many other matters, the government is indicating its hypocrisy. We came forward with the policy prior to the last election. The government condemned it. It denied that it had a similar policy. Yet, almost immediately after the election result, the government is saying, `We tricked you again. We said we weren't going to do it before the election but we are going to do it now.' That is really a matter of very great concern. It does nothing for the integrity of the government and does nothing for the way in which politicians and this parliament are regarded by the Australian people.

Historically, the labour force participation rate for women has been lower than that for men. This has been responsible for the distinction between men's and women's pension ages. The change in women's pension age from 60 to 65 will take effect over a number of years. The government has done a complete backflip on this issue. It is about time that the government gave us honesty instead of lies, lies, lies. The coalition is not opposing this measure. It would be hypocrisy for us to do so.

The coalition is also not opposing the proposed changes relating to the provision of tax file numbers to the Department of Social Security. I have some concerns about this matter. I hope that the tax file number does not become a de facto Australia Card. The government believes that it is important for people to prove their identity prior to the receipt of social security payments, and I can understand why there would be some need for verification of identity. Similarly, I get very concerned over the fact that our electoral system is open to widespread rorting as anyone can gain enrolment on the electoral roll simply by posting an enrolment form into an office of the Australian Electoral Commission. There is no requirement to prove identity.

Any ill-motivated individual would be able to fill in thousands of enrolment cards, send them off and those enrolments would automatically be placed on the electoral roll. By the time the Electoral Commission might have discovered in a subsequent habitation survey that those people do not live there or even exist, an election could well have been won or lost. I think all parties in this place have a vested interest, as indeed do all Australians, in the integrity of the electoral system. I certainly hope that the government will look at this matter very seriously prior to the next election, because I believe that the present situation is unacceptable.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Rocher)—The honourable member has made his point. I suggest he get back to the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was about to, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—You used a wide vehicle.

—I use it very well. As I said at the beginning of my speech, I intend principally to concentrate on that part of the legislation dealing with shares and managed investments. This measure has two elements: it contains amendments which propose a cap of 50 per cent on the rate of return for shares and managed investments for ordinary income purposes, and it provides that the rate of return of a managed investment or listed security that has not been available for the whole 12-month assessment period be calculated on the basis of the performance of the product to date without extrapolating that performance over the 12-month period. I have to give the government credit where credit is due: these are steps in the right direction but, sadly, very small steps. But it is better to take steps, however small, in the right direction than to move in the wrong direction, as the government is doing in so many other policy areas.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Stock Exchange says that these two changes have the capacity to ameliorate two of the most extreme of the effects of treating unrealised capital gains as income for the purpose of the income and assets test. But the Australian Stock Exchange, like the coalition, maintains that the entire system is fundamentally inequitable. Really, what the government is doing in this policy area is kicking those people who have worked for many years, those who in many cases have gone to war to ensure that we are free and who have helped to create and forge the Australia that we have today.

I really think the government stands condemned for its whole policy in this area. We should be helping those people to whom we owe so much. That is why I am so pleased to support the amendment, moved by the honourable member for Pearce (Mrs Moylan), which says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for its iniquitous treatment of unrealised capital gains on shares and managed investments as income for the pension income and assets test.

There probably has been no single issue in my electorate since the March 1993 election which has generated more complaint. I am also referring to people who claim to have been Labor voters for their entire lives. People from Kawana and Caloundra to Caboolture, Bribie Island, Kilcoy, Blackbutt, Toogoolawah, Cooyar and Nanango have been outraged. It does not matter whether they come from the city, the coast or the country. I dare say that members on both sides of the House would have had this experience.

PARA.TAB: The electorate of Fisher has one of the oldest populations of Australia. We have 15.5 per cent of the population who are aged over 65. In neighbouring Fairfax, another Sunshine Coast based seat, 16.2 per cent of residents are aged over 65. It follows that a very large proportion of the Fisher population would be affected by the government's iniquitous legislation. In fact, this has been the case. I have received and continue to receive hundreds of letters and phone calls from pensioners who have panicked about their future since the announcement of Labor's intentions last year. It is not only full pensioners who have been affected by the treatment of unrealised capital gains on shares. With the drop in interest rates, many self-funded retirees who have been forced to become part-pensioners have also been adversely affected. A lot of those people, of course, never expected to be part of the social welfare system. They find that all of a sudden the nest egg that they have is eroded, and often the pension they are entitled to disappears.

As we know, the deeming arrangements produce only a paper income unless the person sells the shares or disposes of managed investments. Quite often, many people who were worried about what the government was saying actually sold their shares prior to the government announcing that people who held shares prior to August 1992 would not be affected. Once the government changed the rules—of course the government went down the road for a very long time of saying it was not going to change the rules—those people could not then go out and buy the shares again because they would then be affected by the provisions. What is more, in many cases some of them had to pay capital gains tax.

I am very pleased that there is now a review under way. I certainly hope that the review is going to be a serious review. I hope that the government's deeming arrangements with respect to shares and managed investments will indeed be repealed as a result of the review. It should be noted that shares held prior to August 1992 were not affected, but shares bought after August 1992 are. People who have acquired managed investments have not been so lucky. They, of course, remain affected in a very serious way, regardless of when those managed investments were acquired.

It is really dreadful to find people who have absolutely no ability to look after themselves in a financial sense, except for the small nest egg they have put aside during their working lives, actually not receiving any real income

SPEECH.PARA: from that nest egg but losing pension entitlements because of the deeming arrangements over shares and managed investments. That is why I am pleased that the government has taken these small steps in the right direction. It would be better if the government scrapped its proposals altogether. I am confident that this will happen following the results of the review. But we will just have to wait and see.

PARA.TAB: Electorates like Fisher, and indeed most of the other seven poorest electorates, are represented by conservative members and have very low family incomes. Fisher is ranked as the fourth poorest in the nation in terms of families with an annual income below $16,000; 26 per cent of Fisher's population is in this income bracket, while only 6.6 per cent of families in the electorate earn more than $60,000. So it is interesting to see that conservative members represent the poorest electorates, making a mockery of the claim that the Labor Party is the party for the underprivileged. If any person still believed that myth, it would have been exploded last year when the government brought in the deeming arrangements with respect to shares and managed investments.

I am at least pleased that the government is moving slightly in the right direction. I am hopeful that when the results of the review are handed down the government will accept that it made a mistake and that it will reverse its policy and treat these older Australians with the respect and very high regard owed to them by the community.

I think it is really important to make the point that the coalition is totally opposed to the deeming of unrealised capital gains on shares and managed investments to be income for the purpose of the pensions income and assets test. While we are supporting the amendment, as I have mentioned, upon our return to government we will scrap this ill-advised, unfair and inequitable policy totally.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) has a number of parts to it. The main part I wish to focus on this morning is the disability wage supplement, although I will touch on some of the other aspects.

PARA.TAB: I have often spoken either before or following the previous speaker, the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper), and I can recall his contributions when he was previously a member of the National Party of Australia. They have not changed much in that time. They are usually extravagant, often ill-informed and often quite fanciful.

If the honourable member for Fisher really thinks that the coalition government would change the rulings on shares and so on, then he is in for an awful shock. He is really suggesting, and some honourable members on his side have attempted to beat up, a concept that investing your money in a building society or in a bank and having the income from that deducted from your pension is valid and okay; but he is suggesting a further concept that people should invest money in shares and, when those shares are sold, the income derived from the increased value would not affect the pension. Clearly he is going to cause a major problem in the investment industry and a major discrepancy in how the government of the day would treat various forms of investment.

The fact is that the philosophy underpinning this is indisputable. There is no way that any government should favour one form of investment over another. There is always going to be an argument as to the methodology. I have said that over a couple of years now, and I still say it. The principle has to be applied. The methodology is again under review, as is appropriate. I hope that we will review it often. Whenever a system is introduced we find that a whole industry springs up around it. We have found this in the share industry. The changes on managed investments back in 1989, in turn, produced an advisory industry where people were investing directly in shares, which meant that they were therefore exempted. Those loopholes that emerge need to be corrected, and any government, Labor or coalition, would do much the same.

For the coalition to be running around the countryside talking about how it is going to make sure that the income on the sale of shares does not affect pensions is fanciful and misleading. Quite frankly, given the coalition's economic prescription for the country during the last election campaign, when it was so roundly rejected, closing the loophole would be the very first thing that a coalition government would do. Obviously, the honourable member for Fisher does not listen to his colleagues in the shadow ministry when they put forward their prognosis and solutions for cutting government expenditure and saving money.

When he suggests that this will open up a major loophole in the pension system of this nature, he is not kidding the community because obviously it did not believe it in the lead-up to the last election. This was canvassed very fully during the last election campaign; it was a major issue. The coalition was still defeated. He might believe the rhetoric, but the community certainly does not. I am sure that most people in government and in the departments would not believe it.

This legislation also lays to rest another furphy that we keep hearing. We have been hearing in recent days how the white paper of last week, Working Nation, and the budget of last night are all about shuffling figures off the unemployment queues. The reality is that in the term of this government we have transformed the nature of recognition of work. It has been politically very difficult and socially quite challenging and demanding, but it has been enormously important that we have stopped denying the notion of work to a whole range of people in the community.

This includes women who have become widows, who historically were automatically seen as being pensioned off for life, whether they were 35, 45, 55 or whatever. The notion that a widow was somehow automatically a pensioner and therefore condemned to a subsistence level of income, and not given support for employment and training, seemed to be natural to those opposite. We have said that those women are now notionally members of the work force. We have extended the work force substantially by that one act. In effect, we have increased the number of people unemployed. Rather than shuffling people off the unemployment list, we have actually put them on it. In many cases that has been very difficult. Within that context we have also tried to ensure that there was adequate support for those people.

The second group that has been dramatically affected by that is people with disabilities. Hundreds of thousands of people on disability support pensions and the old invalid pension were seen to be pensioned off, in many cases with a relatively minor and static complaint. They were given no support for employment or training. They were seen to be virtually written off for the rest of their lives.

Since the introduction of the Disability Services Act in 1988, the government has made changes to legislation in an attempt to show that disabled people have something to offer. We have to give them the opportunity to show society what they can do, rather than what they cannot do. There has been a sea change in social legislation and social support. At the same time, there has been an increased number of people who are notionally out of work as disabled people have now become part of the work force.

The size of the work force has increased by some four per cent since 1983. The work force now includes people such as women who, under previous governments, would normally have received the widow's pension. It also includes people with disabilities who previously would have received the invalid pension or the disability support pension, but who are now seeking work and, in many cases, getting it. The increase in the size of the work force has been a conscious process by the government in an attempt to achieve a fairer and more equal society in which people are seen to be supported. Over the last week, members of the opposition have claimed that we have reduced the number of people in the work force. But the facts show the opposite. We have consciously and deliberately increased the size of the work force.

The legislation establishes the introduction of a disability wage supplement, as was announced last year, which will commence on 1 July. This supplement will bring the wages of people with disabilities up to what would be the award wage for a particular position, given that in many cases they will be less productive. That is a moot point. Many of these people could be fully productive if they were given a chance. This legislation does allow for their full participation in the work force. In the past disabled people had to either get a pension or work. We are now offering them a mix of income support and wage support when they are in productive employment. This will enable people who have previously been sidelined in our society to take a more active part as full contributing members of the community, albeit with lesser productivity.

That particular change poses problems with respect to how the assessment process is determined. We have to protect people with disabilities from misuse or abuse by some employers who may not be so compassionate and thoughtful. But our experience with employment support for people with disabilities has been successful. I want to publicly congratulate businesses such as Sizzler, which at a national level has undertaken some quite major and exciting programs. People with disabilities are actually working in Sizzler restaurants in a really meaningful and productive way. That has been extremely valuable. In Newcastle we have an organisation called Castle Personnel which has been involved in open supported employment and which initiated the Sizzler program.

It has been shown that these things can work. Whilst these programs have been done in a focused, localised and productive way, the disability wage supplement is a much broader instrument which will allow a much wider range of services and a much wider range of employers. Obviously, this program will build up. To start off from day one trying to cater for all people with disabilities will not be meaningful, but the concept and the process are extremely valid.

The honourable member for Fisher and other opposition members in general have indicated that this bill also will be sent off to a committee. The poor old Senate. Lionel must be turning in his grave, having helped establish a Senate committee system to review legislation. When I ask senators what they are doing with their committees and how productive they are, they tell me that they are so bogged down with stuff being referred to them that the quality of their reporting has dropped. So it is a bureaucracy reporting for them because the senators do not have time, and delays are being caused.

The idea of referring things to committees again and again, which is what the opposition is trying to do, has become almost an art form now. Yet the same people have the audacity to criticise the government for delays and for how long things take. The hypocrisy involved in what we have been watching in the 12 months since the election is mind-boggling. I have been here for the term of this government and I have watched the opposition for that time. At times I have thought it was quite productive and constructive. In the last year, however, its performance has been abysmal, which has been unfortunate. People in the community with disabilities need positive encouragement and support, not the kind of carping, negative nonsense we heard from an earlier speaker, the honourable member for Fisher. We as members are in touch with our communities. We understand what is happening with people with disabilities. We know their needs, if we are doing our homework, and we can feed those into the process.

The earlier speaker should have been doing so for the last year. To say that it needs a Senate committee to do that means that he has not been doing his job. What is more, he is passing the buck to that Senate committee. Where has he been for the last 12 months? He has been a member of this House for more than a year now. This issue has been on the agenda for the last eight or nine months. Where has he been? This issue has been on the public agenda for years. The honourable member has had every chance to contribute to this legislation, as we all have. What he wants to do now is say, `Pass it to the B grade. Let the B grade look at it.' He cannot be bothered.

The people who have no constituents, the people who almost all reside in capital cities, are going to now have a committee look at this. And what will happen? The Senate bureaucracy will respond to it because our colleagues in the Senate are absolutely flat chat. There is no way they could get their heads around this kind of stuff in a meaningful, constructive way in a reasonable time. The cop-out by people elected to represent their constituents is appalling. Every day, every week we see members of the House of Representatives abdicating responsibility to the other chamber.

I was elected to represent my community, not to pass things off to the states representatives, who supposedly represent the states interests, who have no direct constituencies, who do not serve constituents in the way that we do. If that is what the honourable member is about—and it appears that that is all the opposition is about these days—why bother coming here? He may as well stay home. If he is shirking his responsibilities that way, then why bother pretending to represent? I asked where he has been for the last year if he has not been dealing with this issue, as most of us have been.

This change is enormously important. It is in danger of being misused and abused unless both sides of this House are supportive and constructive about it. That is why the message sending the legislation off to the Senate is so dangerous. It means that the opposition is now going to play political games with what should be a unanimously supported piece of legislation.

Whatever legislation we introduce, whatever new system we bring in, it will have its early days of teething troubles, of bedding in, of training, of getting ourselves, our departments, the community and the community organisations used to it. That is a normal part of the process. The idea that somehow sending it to the Senate will solve that or avoid that is impossible. What the opposition is really trying to do is delay it past 1 July. That is what it is about, so it cannot be brought in at all on 1 July. Then it can say that the government broke a promise. And who suffers?—the people with disabilities, whom this program would help. The cheap, shoddy manoeuvring of those opposite is absolutely appalling to a group in the community who for all of our lives has been sidelined.

The government is saying that these people are part of our community and need to be seen for what they can do and supported in what they can do. The quote being used, `judge them for what they can do', is very valid. They are being brought into the mainstream for the very first time, for so many of them. What is happening? This legislation is becoming a political football to be postponed past 1 July so that the opposition can then accuse the government of failing these people. I find that morally reprehensible and appalling. Most of those opposite should perhaps stay home during these sessions and let the Senate do the job for them. That seems to be their role these days.

I have touched on the matter of shares and I, too, welcome the review which will take place on that. As I said, it is unfortunate that those opposite somehow seem to think that, having lost the last election when this was a major issue, the community is in favour of what it is putting forward. The community in Australia is a very fair community. When it sees a possible loophole and an abuse of the pension system by shareholders, which is not available to people who invest in banks, building societies or other forms of interest bearing investments, it will in no way support that.

The amendments to the provision of tax file numbers is obviously important. The loophole that was shown up by the AAT ruling recently needs to be plugged. The fact that the legislation apparently does not require or compel a pensioner or recipient of benefits to provide a tax file number is clearly an oversight. It was not intended and, therefore, needs to be corrected. The whole idea of the tax file number in the system is to make sure that people's earnings are brought into account in assessing benefits in terms of their demand on the public purse. That was clearly a drafting flaw which was never intended, and it is very important that that be corrected soon—not be delayed, postponed and procrastinated over because of some nonsense from the opposition in the Senate.

It must be realised that the pensionable age for women will not finally be increased to 65 until the year 2013. Again, this is another example of the work force size being increased. The government is deliberately and consciously increasing the size of the work force, which automatically means the unemployment rate goes up because there are more people in the work force. So, in the year 2013, when pensions are available only at the age of 65, the work force size will be automatically increased by women who are 60 to 65. Quite frankly, most of those people want to work. A lot of people out there want to work beyond 65 as well—and very many do work. The fact is that this particular amendment, despite what the opposition says, is actually increasing the work force.

The point I want to reinforce is that people with disabilities are part of this community, and this legislation is vital. It is depressing and demoralising to find the opposition trying to push the legislation off to a Senate inquiry. That is clearly aimed at the committee not reporting before 1 July so that the legislation will not become operational. That is the wrong message and a tragic message for those people who have for so long sought recognition and a fair go.

We claim all the time that we are a fair society. We tell the world how fair we are. The fact is that we are fair only if we fit the system. It is tough luck on a person with disabilities if the system does not fit that person. This amendment makes the system fit people, and it fits those people who have been discriminated against for so long.

As I said, any delay, negating or undermining of this legislation by those opposite really is an act of a reprehensible nature. I think it is unfortunate that the mean spiritedness that we have seen in this last year is coming through on so much social legislation. It is quite tragic. The other message is that the work force size will increase. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —From listening to the comments of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris), I can tell that the only mean spiritedness around this Commonwealth in the last 12 months has come from the government. I do not agree with his analogy of what is likely to happen when certain parts of the bill go off to a Senate committee to be scrutinised. If the government were a little more open-minded about these things, it might realise there is a possibility of some of this legislation being improved, particularly the delivery of these services.

PARA.TAB: What I think is lacking on the government benches these days is the preparedness to recognise the facts that not all the wisdom in this nation sits on those benches and that there is a contribution to be made in a positive manner by other members in this place and certainly by members of the other place. I think we are all very serious about our representation of different aspects of our constituencies, particularly those that we are debating in this bill today. I take umbrage a little bit at some of the comments of the honourable member for Newcastle. I for one certainly am very genuine in my comments on this amendment bill.

As far as the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 is concerned, in particular I will concentrate my attention on three areas: the disability wage supplement, the changes to managed investments, and the changes to the pensionable age of women. Obviously they are three very contentious areas within our community which certainly are not restricted to any particular electorate or constituency. Whether the area is represented by a government member or by a coalition member, the issues remain the same.

The disability wage supplement will be based on the qualification and payability conditions for the disability support pension and will be available to people who enter the supported wage system administered by the Department of Human Services and Health. It will be available from 1 July 1994. I refer to the assumption of the honourable member for Newcastle that, just because a Senate committee may get the opportunity to scrutinise this bill, it will hold it up. It may well not hold it up; it may well make amendments that improve the delivery of these services.

Under the SWS, a person with a disability may be paid less than the award wage, based on his or her productivity compared with that of a person in the same occupation who does not have such a disability. There are 159,692 people with disabilities who are CES registered. In Port Macquarie, in my electorate of Lyne, there are 613 people CES registered. In Taree, also within my electorate of Lyne, there are 961 people CES registered.

I am very supportive of the disability wage supplement. Employer and employee groups throughout the electorate have spoken very highly of the direction of this proposal. I think this is a step in the right direction for employment prospects for people with disabilities. The trend currently taking place in our community is a movement away from large institutionalised sheltered workshops to schemes that encourage people with disabilities to participate in the mainstream labour force. Whilst I think it is important not to forget the worth of sheltered workshops in specific cases, I welcome the move towards a more integrated work force. This is definitely a step forward for all parties involved, particularly those with disabilities.

In April 1992 the employment of people with disabilities was examined by the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. The report, which examined the options available for people with disabilities to help them gain employment, made several recommendations. This is one of those Senate committees to which the honourable member for Newcastle is not overly anxious to see too many aspects of this bill being sent off. Some of the recommendations made by the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs were that adequate funding be provided to enable increased access to services for people with disabilities; that full-time employment is not appropriate for or may not be achievable by all people with disabilities; and that programs be established combining work, study, recreation and other activities.

Other recommendations of the committee were that part-time employment options be delivered for people with disabilities unable to undertake full-time employment; that the Commonwealth government implement a wage system to meet the income needs of people with disabilities unable to work full time at or above award wages; and that the Commonwealth direct resources towards ensuring that at least a living wage, which may be made up of part pension and part wage, should be the basis of pay received by people with disabilities in paid employment, even though this may not be an award wage. I therefore welcome the government's reforms as a follow-up to these 1992 recommendations. It is pleasing to see the government take note of some Senate recommendations once in a while.

A lot of the government members who speak on issues such as this one in this place seem to think that they have just arrived here and that they are all great initiatives that they are just implementing. They should be reminded sometimes that they have been in power for in excess of 10 years and it has taken them this long to start addressing these issues. So I do not think that the people of Australia should see the government as the great white knight and the saviour of these particular interest groups, because it has taken the government a long time, with these matters going through some of the more contentious committees of inquiry of the Senate, to reach these outcomes.

While I welcome this move, I do hope the government will recognise the possible areas of concern with this change and monitor them to make sure the system is not open to abuse. Maybe, just maybe, there are areas in the legislation open for abuse that have not been identified in this place—in the drafting of the bill, with the bureaucracy and the minister's department involved—that may well be picked up by a Senate committee of inquiry. I continue to harp on the point that I think it was an unfounded criticism made by the honourable member for Newcastle that all wisdom is located in the minister's office and with the bureaucracy, and that nobody else should have the opportunity to have input into the legislation. I suppose that, if the honourable member for Newcastle had a far greater background in areas outside of this place, he might understand that.

There is a real need to review the efficiency of the program coordination between the Department of Social Security and the Department of Human Services and Health. The supported wages system has been shown to be far too cumbersome and bureaucratic in the past, and this must not occur after these reforms have taken place. One local authority was very critical of the bureaucratic process involved in gaining a slow worker's permit from the Industry Commission. These issues will hopefully be ironed out with this reform but, if not, the government must examine its interdepartmental efficiency in this area.

Another area of concern that I have is the amount of confusion and misunderstanding that exists within the electorate. There have been extensive reviews over the last few years examining this area, many of them drawing completely different conclusions. I hope to see the government addressing this issue over the next few months before the DWS is introduced on 1 July this year so that everyone involved is clear about what the government is actually doing. For example, I have been contacted by one person who has a disability but has been fortunate to find full-time employment within the award wage system. This person was very concerned that he may lose part of his wage due to a disability that has in no way impaired his ability to work. These issues need to be clarified by the government.

I think the government needs to address some of the issues involved here from an employer's point of view as well. For example, the government has not yet addressed whether there are any insurance implications for business—in particular, the higher premiums involved with the employment of people with some forms of disability. I see that the government has acknowledged initial outlays for businesses employing people with disabilities, but there is no provision for future on-costs involved. These are the cruel realities of business and, until the government addresses these issues, the door into full employment will not be truly opened to people with disabilities. I also share the concerns of the Welfare Rights Centre in that the operation of the DWS is structurally faulty in the early stages. I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Welfare Rights believe that the legislation should allow people coming off DWS to be presumed qualified for the Disability Support Pension, at least in regard to the 20% impairment rating and the continuing inability to work criteria. Currently when participants leave the scheme or are faced for a suspension period in which they are now receiving DWS they will have to lodge a new claim for the Disability Support Pension. This may take up to 8 weeks to be processed due to the medical examination requirement. In the intervening period they will probably be receiving Job Search Allowance and therefore face the prospect of having to attempt to find work for which they and their medical advisers believe they are unfit.

Therefore, whilst I support the general direction of this legislation, I think a great deal of finetuning needs to be done to improve the legislation in its current form. I therefore support the move to refer the matter to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs which, I reiterate, must have some expertise in this area. There is obviously some direction it can have. The committee is made up of elected representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia—the same as we are—and I think that it would do well for those on the government benches to recognise the fact that all the wisdom on these matters does not sit on the government side.

PARA.TAB: I will now move to the issue of family payments. From 1 January 1995, the maximum rate of additional family payment in respect of children who have not turned 16 will be increased by $1 per week per child. This is estimated to help around 800,000 low income families. On the mid north coast of New South Wales—particularly in my electorate of Lyne, where the average household income of only just over $20,000 per annum is one of the lowest in Australia—this measure will be welcomed.

However, we must remember the background to this measure, which is the result of the government's deal with the Greens during last year's budget process. This measure is supposed to counteract the increases introduced by the government in wholesale sales taxes announced in last year's budget. So while it is giving with the one hand, the government is certainly taking away with the other.

The people of Australia should recognise that, although in last night's budget there were not too many baddies as far as increases in taxes, they were all announced last year. Low income earners around Australia in particular are going to bear the brunt of the $800 million increased sales taxes this year. This is only just a bit of a fob-off to the Greens to offset the government's tax and spend attitude.

The next item within this omnibus bill that I would like to cover is that of managed investments. I do not think there is an issue that has been so broadly covered within everybody's electorate as the issue of managed investments and how this government has treated it. Again, this measure was passed in an omnibus bill before I entered this parliament. It seems to be a habit of this government when introducing legislation that may be opposed or rolled over to stick it in an omnibus bill where it will not be wise to vote against the whole bill.

The government has already come up with one backdown on the treatment of shares, including the capital appreciation of shares. It diddled with that and caught a lot of people out in changing their dates. It will now fiddle with the managed investments aspect of the treatment of investments for capital gains. It is a step in the right direction, but it should be completely abolished. It is an admission by the government that it is wrong, that it is electorally unsound and that it will cost it dearly at the next election.

I welcome this move by the government that recognises, at least in part, the faults that have emerged in its ridiculous managed investment reforms. Whilst I would have much preferred to see the total abolition of its reforms on unrealised capital gains on shares and managed investments, I think this step towards improving the scheme is at least a start by the government in recognising that it was wrong. I will continue to fight—I am sure that all my coalition colleagues will also continue to fight; we have seen an amendment moved by the honourable member for Pearce (Mrs Moylan)—to see the current system of income and assets testing of pensioners totally abolished.

The two measures being introduced are beneficial. The first acknowledges that high rates of return on shares and managed investments cannot be justifiably used as unrealised capital gains for pension assessment purposes. This is particularly the case where the rate of return is calculated to be in excess of 100 per cent, meaning that the rate of income that is assessed is greater than the value of the investment.

The second measure deals with the experience arising from the Commonwealth bank float, where shares are acquired at a price that is considerably higher than the price at which the shares were originally listed. The initial list price will no longer be used so that the artificial inflation of the investment return does not occur.

I have been astounded by the number of people this issue has affected within my electorate of Lyne. Countless people in the mid north coast have vainly tried to work out the government's harebrained formula on this issue. They have been totally frustrated by the retrospective nature of the legislation and have had to completely reassess their retirement plans after they have actually retired.

This has been the dirtiest piece of legislation that I have seen in my short time in parliament. I condemn the government for introducing the provisions in the first place. I call on the government to ensure the true independence of the current income and assets test review so that we can hopefully see some changes to this legislation throughout the upcoming year.

Over the years, the government—I go back to the point I made earlier—has been in power for many years. It has made numerous changes that affect self-funded retirees, part pensioners and pensioners alike. Over those years, people have made their plans for retirement and relocation based on the policies of the government of the day. The government has shifted the goalposts. It has had an enormously detrimental effect on many pensioners and part pensioners throughout Australia.

Unrealised capital gain cannot buy bread, meat and milk. It does not pay the rates. It does not pay the phone bill. It does not pay the power bill. I believe the government is now recognising the error of its way. We certainly commend to the government that it go on from the removal of part of this legislation to the complete abandonment of it because of the devastating effect it is having on the retired population in Australia, certainly the pensioners and part pensioners.

The last aspect of the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill that I want to touch on is the increase in the pensionable age for women. This move is a complete turnaround by the government since the election in 1993—and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mrs Crosio) need not shake her head. In a minute I will read to the parliamentary secretary a media release that was put out at the time by the then Minister for Social Security, Neal Blewett. This government's tactic of tucking a contentious bit of legislation in amongst an omnibus package is starting to get out of hand: it did so with the managed investment legislation, it tried to do so during last year's budget, and it is again trying to do so today. This is a tactic of the government's which skirts the boundaries of ethics—if there are any such things left in this place.

The government is going to increase the pensionable age for women from 60 to 65 years. This will be phased in over 20 years, starting on 1 July 1995. The government said that this was a Fightback initiative, but the government has not picked up on the fact that the coalition's proposal was in line with other non-discriminatory election promises, including the abolition of the compulsory retirement age. The ironic part of this measure having been part of Fightback, however, is that we can now refer back to the government's comments on it.

One year ago the classic line and the true example of government deception at the election came from the then Minister for Social Security. He labelled the policy—the same policy that this government is introducing today in this bill—as premature, ill-considered, extremely harsh and unfair. He also said:

SPEECH.PARA: It's the sort of two-card trick you wouldn't expect anyone to play on the elderly . . .

That was part of the coalition's policy for the election last year. I certainly do not entirely agree with that policy. I do not believe that the Commonwealth will gain the perceived benefits from moving the pensionable age of women from 60 to 65. The next thing the government will do in a sop to the community to offset this change will be to introduce the mature age allowance eligibility for women of the age of 60. Men are eligible at the age of 60 now, so the real pensionable age is not 65. I go back to the then Minister for Social Security's media release. Neal Blewett said in that media release:
The Opposition move to increase the women's pension age to 65 within 5 years is premature, ill-considered and unfair.
Women who have faced greatly restricted opportunities and discrimination during their lives are being offered last minute equality to save the Opposition money.
It's the sort of two-card trick you wouldn't expect anyone to play on the elderly, but it's just one of a huge range of hidden `nasties' in the Fightback package.

The lower pension age for women is due recognition of the fact that many older women devoted most of their lives to their families and sacrificed employment, savings and superannuation in the process. When women of pension age have had similar opportunities as their male counterparts, that will be the time to equalise pension ages, not before . . .
The media release goes on:

Opposition policy would see women in their forties and fifties having to alter their retirement plans drastically. For many it would mean a substantial loss of income and late-age entry onto the employment queues.

I tend to agree with some of his comments, but within 12 months we have seen the government do a complete 360-degree-turnaround on this issue. It is going to change women's pensionable age. Maybe when this bill gets to the Senate, this aspect of it should be referred to a Senate select committee. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —As Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security, I would like the right of reply to those who have spoken in this debate. I refer particularly to the honourable member for Pearce (Mrs Moylan), the honourable member for Adelaide (Ms Worth), the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper), the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile), the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) and the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris).

PARA.TAB: The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) covers a number of details, but I will cover only those matters that have raised concern for opposition speakers today. They include: disability support, shares, tax file numbers, and women's pensionable age. In covering those matters I will reiterate why we will oppose the amendment before the House. The amendment—other than being a cheap political shot—is basically saying that the opposition is not declining to support the second reading, but that it condemns the government, et cetera. I do not see any sense in that, for the simple reason—which at least two speakers acknowledged in their speeches; the honourable member for Pearce failed to acknowledge it—that the government has set up an independent inquiry.

This amendment is really saying, `You have already set up the independent inquiry; we are still going to tell you we do not like it, but we are not going to wait for the inquiry before we take any other steps.' The government has been condemned because it has taken into consideration the concerns that have been raised. It has, through this legislation, addressed some of those concerns and has called for an independent consultant to review those concerns.

The independent consultant is very publicly going around taking submissions. The consultant is talking to both the welfare groups and the finance groups. We expect to have a preliminary report in July, and we will have a full report in September. If the opposition does not agree with some of the recommendations that come out of that, maybe then it will be time for the opposition to start saying where it should be going with that. The legislation before the House is really about addressing those wider concerns. The opposition should be involved in those public submissions.

I acknowledge that the shadow spokesperson on social security, the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) has been very much involved in this process and has been very attentive to the action that has been taken. I join with the honourable member for Moreton and convey to the honourable member for Berowra the government's condolences on the sad loss of his mother.

I would like to take up the concern that was raised by the honourable member for Pearce and repeated by other opposition speakers, and that is the disability wage supplement. Those opposite have stated that people and organisations have not been consulted. I can assure you, Mr Acting Deputy Speaker, that consultation has been going on ad infinitum. The recommendations contained in the bill came out of that consultation. We have put new arrangements into place. This is not a pilot. We are putting into place arrangements, decisions and commitments that have been made.

Those workers with a disability will be assessed either by the worker's employer and the union—so they should be—or the employer and an accredited assessor. Concern was raised by the honourable member for Pearce that an assessor is an extra bureaucratic arm that will need to be employed. That is not the case. Those people are already there. They are part of the employee system.

We must remember at all times that, whatever decision we make in regard to people with disabilities, it must be made in consultation with a particular worker. There needs to be an assessment as to what percentage of work that person is able to do and, therefore, what percentage of wage is able to be paid. Again, that assessment has to be undertaken in line with productivity capacity and it has to be undertaken with consultation. We know not only that that is in place and that we have the consent of the unions and both the employer and community groups but, most particularly, we have a large group of people out there with disabilities who want to come into the work force.

The government has been condemned in the debate here this morning. It has been said that the so-called 1,000 places is a paltry amount. That so-called 1,000 is a damned sight better than none. The government cannot be condemned for not acting to take steps to bring these people into the work force, then condemned for not assessing it and doing it properly and then condemned because there are a lot more people who suffer from disability who need to be assessed. The government, with the bill before the House, acknowledges all of that. We want to do it well, we want to do it gradually, we want to do it in consultation, and we want to do it to make sure that no person is ever going to be taken advantage of. I do not necessarily mean just the person with the disability; I also mean the employer.

I believe that, on both sides of the House, we should be commending those people who, through a lot of time, effort and consultation, have brought this particular amendment to the House. I state again that the legislation will continue to be monitored. It is not a pilot. Money has been allocated. Money was allocated in last year's budget and has been again in this year's budget. Money has been allocated, with commitments, going right through to 1995-96 and 1996-97. We will continue to support those particular programs with those particular people. As we see it in operation and up and running, we will also have other people coming forward and a commitment to ongoing involvement.

There are some other general points that I would like to touch on. On the disability wage supplement, as I stated, the assessors are existing employees of our employment agency. There is no confusion. The only confusion—the information came back to us through our very wide consultation—has been on the pension versus the wage supplement policy. That has been clearly spelt out. It has gone back to the organisations concerned, and they have agreed with it. We, as the government, have always demanded that we have a third party involved. That third party, as is stated in the bill, can be either a trade union or the trade wage assessor. We also believe that persons must be free to involve, if that is their wish, an advocate.

As to how an agreement should be drawn up with the legislation before the House, it will be drawn up by the worker and his or her employer. It will then, we understand and hope, be ratified correctly by a delegate of the Department of Human Services and Health. Why is that necessary? That agreement itself is valid for a maximum of 12 months, but it does give the right to either party to renew it, provided it is the certified rate wage that has previously been agreed to.

Lack of consultation has been indicated as confusing by some of the opposition speakers in their remarks. If those opposite say we have not been consultative, I would just bring up some of the areas of consultation that have taken place. We have had lengthy consultations with the ACCI, with the ACTU and with the peak disability organisations, as I have stated, not over the last three months or over the last 12 months but for three years. It has been quite public consultation. Nothing has been hidden. We were not running around to a little corner and saying, `Here's another little clause we want to put in a particular bill. The opposition won't notice it. We're really not going to help those people; we're really going to make a sham of it.' That has not been happening. It has been very open and the consultation has been very thorough indeed.

The parties supported what went into the budget in 1993 for implementation in 1994. They supported that quite publicly. When we talk about what is happening and about the opposition supporting a bill, we need a little bit of honesty and a little bit of openness as to what is really happening out there in the community. The honourable member for Pearce was very concerned that the budget did not supply the funds. Again I say to her, `Read it.' It was placed in the 1993-94 budget. It goes right through to 1996-97, and it will continue to be reviewed.

The other area of great division and debate from those opposite in their supporting of this bill was the pensionable age. A lot was made of this. Before I come back to some of the comments I wrote down when listening to the speakers, I would like to repeat my call for honesty—not the hypocrisy. The honourable member for Lyne and a couple of the other opposition spokespersons brought up what our previous-but-one Minister for Social Security was supposed to have said. I too have the same newspaper in front of me. It was the supplement taken out of the Herald-Sun of 6 February 1992. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Social Security Minister, Dr Blewett, said yesterday he would like to eventually see `equality in the provision of age pensions'. But he said the move would have to be phased in gradually to ensure women were not disadvantaged.

The article then went on about how, at present, men retire at 65 and women at 60. A lot of to-do was made about that. It was said that the government was back-pedalling, that the government was backing down, that the government was not really committed to what it is trying to do, that the government was breaking another promise and that the government has taken on the opposition policy. Let us be very honest here too: what a load of hogwash! The government has said, very plainly and clearly, that the phasing in of the new pensionable age of women will occur over 20 years—not over the next three or five, but over 20 years. We will give women of this country adequate notice so that the situation can gradually be assessed and so they understand and appreciate what is going on. Bear in mind that only a woman who is 64 years and six months will be affected on 1 July 2013 when the last increase occurs. Then she turns 65, of course, and comes of pensionable age on 1 January 2014.

PARA.TAB: It has been increasingly difficult to really justify the different qualifying ages of men and women in our country. When we talk in both houses of this parliament and in the state houses about qualifying ages for men and women and when we look at our domestic and particularly our international equal opportunity requirements, how can we continually say that it is right to have this inequality? Former minister Neal Blewett at all times said that equality in qualifying ages has to be achieved on a phased-in basis, that its introduction has to be equitable and that it has to be very fair. In a majority of cases women will qualify for other income support, as is the case now. I think the honourable member for Lyne touched on that. Of course, at the moment that is called the mature age allowance. Gradually the name may change, but it is always the policy of our government to make sure that people are cared for.

The Council on the Ageing supports the mature age allowance in the bill. In fact, it thought the government was being too generous. In its support for the proposal the council asked, `Why aren't you phasing it in by the year 2000?' We said, `No, that is not justifiable and we must phase it in with consent and with a gradual process.' I was particularly pleased with the comments of the Council on the Ageing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ultimately, women will lose a five-year potential benefit.

—It is very interesting that the Leader of the National Party comes into this House in the last 10 minutes of the debate, bearing in mind that it has been going on for something like 2 1/2 hours. We would expect inane interjections like that. If the Leader of the National Party has a concern about legislation before the House, as he has had previously, he should come in here and debate that legislation. If members have a concern, no matter where they sit, they have the opportunity in this House to bring—
—I've been here for an hour. I've been waiting for you to finish up.

—You have been in here for the last 10 minutes, and you will continue to wait until I do finish, because I believe that the speakers who made comments in debate on this legislation should have their concerns addressed and answered. Until I believe I have covered all the concerns about this legislation that have been expressed by those on both sides of the House, I will continue to speak.

PARA.TAB: I say to the honourable member for Pearce that at no time can she quantify the request for a tax file number in the case she referred to as a tax file jackboot operation by this government. What hogwash! The legislation before the House allows the Department of Social Security to compare only Department of Social Security recipient records with tax records under the data-matching act. It actually lessens the privacy intrusions. It is also an alternative to getting a full list of all taxpayers from the ATO and data-matching against that particular list. It is strictly intended only for detecting fraud and I am pleased that some members of the opposition have acknowledged that.

Most particularly, we have had ongoing discussions with the Privacy Commission. I do not know whether it was by way of an interjection or whether it was a comment in one of the speeches by someone from the opposition benches, but I know that someone was concerned about why certain amendments were not here. It is because of the ongoing consultation with the Privacy Commissioner, and we believe we need to spell out the situation very clearly. That is one of the amendments that will be coming into the House. I would have liked to have brought it in here, but the drafting process has not been completed. It will eventually come through this House and go through the Senate.

I would particularly like to convey my appreciation to the honourable member for Moreton. I believe he has a very true understanding, but more particularly an appreciation, of what disabilities and disabled people are all about. I particularly commend him for bringing to the notice of the House that these amendments are a result of the recommendation of a Senate standing committee. We are being told, `Let us put it back to a Senate inquiry.' A Senate inquiry is set up to investigate a specific area and that Senate inquiry makes recommendations. The government, through the process of time and legislation, takes those recommendations on board and either amends the particular bill with which those recommendations are concerned or brings in fresh legislation to make sure that those recommendations from the Senate inquiry are covered.

The government has done that. We have had a long, intensive Senate inquiry. Recommendations have come forward that we must concern ourselves with the disabled people and bring them into the work force. At the same time, we must make sure they are looked after, are assessed and have an equitable chance. After we have done all that, we are being condemned. So, obviously, those in government are condemned if they do and condemned if they do not. We are condemned because we have taken the Senate committee's recommendations on board, and have brought them into legislation in the amendment bill before the House. We will now be condemned because we have not given enough consideration to the recommendations and there may be concerns and problems. What the opposition has now stated is that it is going to send the bill to a Senate standing committee. I just wonder where the legislation is going to end up.

The statement the honourable member for Newcastle made about the Senate and its workload needs to be made again and again in this House. We are the elected representatives who have constituencies at large. We are the elected representatives who have the right to come in here and debate these bills. We are the elected representatives who have the right to move amendments and, if at all possible, have them carried. If they are not carried we have the right to make sure that our feelings and the concerns of the constituents we represent are heard in this parliament.

But when we actually have that put into practice, the opposition says, `Wait a minute. We know a Senate inquiry has gone on. We know the government has taken it on board. We know the government has amended the bill. We know the government is putting that into practice. We know the government is doing all of that with consultation. We know the government has been consulting for three years. But wait a minute. It hasn't gone far enough. We had better take it back to a Senate inquiry because Senate inquiries are the be all and end all.' I say time and time again, and without being in any way derogatory to our Senate colleagues, that really it is the people out there who are waiting to be employed—the people who are waiting to be part of this so-called 1,000—to whom we should give some consideration as well.

So regardless of what happens in the Senate—I acknowledge, and the government acknowledges, we may not have the numbers there to direct whether this goes to a Senate inquiry or not—I say to those opposite that they should also acknowledge the fact that it is the community at large which is waiting to have this implemented on 1 July 1994; the community at large which has been consulted over the last three years; the community at large which has also put submission after submission to the Senate inquiry. This community is now saying to the government and the opposition, `For God's sake, act.' That is what we are saying.

Let us look at it further, if that is what the opposition is going to do. But let us also acknowledge that the budget allocation is there to meet our commitments and let us care for those people to whom we want to make those commitments. That is something we have to acknowledge at all times. I am particularly pleased that the two speakers on our side of the House made mention of it.

I think the honourable member for Adelaide needs to have a few things cleared up for her. I acknowledge that she had, at least, acknowledged the fact that that independent inquiry is under way. Surely she has to agree that the actual amendment is nothing short of a political statement.

I was particularly interested to hear the way the honourable member for Fisher carried on about where he thought we should be going or should not be going. We cannot have it both ways. Let us at least give consideration to the disabled. The statement of the honourable member for Fisher with reference to the then Minister for Social Security, Dr Blewett—I suggest honourable members read it in the Hansard—was nothing but bare-faced, two-faced hypocrisy.

I am particularly pleased with the commitments made by both the government and the opposition. I believe that at all times we have a right of free debate in this House, but, as I said in the House to the Leader of the National Party of Australia, I think I have a right, on behalf of the minister and the government, to answer some of the concerns that have been expressed by the opposition.

I reiterate that we oppose the amendment. The amendment is a cheap political shot in which the opposition tries to reiterate its policy. Sure, that is the opposition's right, but the government would rather support the bill and will support the bill before the House.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mrs Crosio) read a third time.
Consideration resumed from 4 May.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca The Hon C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 re-introduces the amendments proposed in the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1993 with the exception of part 7. Part 7 of that bill dealt with amendments to the managed investments legislation. The 1993 bill was laid aside by the House of Representatives on 24 February 1994 following disagreement between the houses about the inclusion of part 7. Aside from renumbering to take account of this omission, the remainder of the 1993 bill has been duplicated in the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1994.

PARA.TAB: The government proposed the amendments to the managed investment legislation as they are beneficial to service pensioners with this form of investment. There are not `winners and losers', as the opposition tried to argue during the debate on the 1993 bill. There are only winners. This is reflected in the commencement date of the proposed changes, which was to ensure that the amendments retrospectively commence from 1 April 1993.
