However, in weighing up the totality of the bill, I feel that there would be a greater injustice in not passing the bill at all, particularly to the 10,000 veterans and their dependants who would not be able to get the Commonwealth seniors health card from the Department of Veterans' Affairs from 1 July 1994.

I will now turn to the measures in this bill. In Building on strength, the government announced as part of its advancement towards a fairer Australia that it would improve the position of low income retirees by easing the pensions assets test and by introducing a Commonwealth seniors health card. The government fulfilled the first part of this commitment by introducing legislation to ease the pensions assets test from 20 September 1993. This bill meets the second part of that commitment by introducing a Commonwealth seniors health card from 1 July 1994. This card will give certain low income non-service pensioners access to concessional pharmaceutical benefits, hearing aid concessions and optometry services. It is estimated that this proposal will assist a total of 10,000 veterans and dependants.

It is also befitting in the Year of the Family that the government proposes a bill containing amendments to the child related payments legislation. These amendments introduce greater flexibility in the delivery of child related payments, recognising the important role of primary care givers and the financial burden placed on them. This initiative is part of the government's ongoing commitment to families. The main features of this initiative are:

SPEECH.PARA: the ability to redirect child related payments to the partner;
adjusting the pension payment in shared care cases so that the child related payments are also shared;
backdating child related payments to the first payday after the date of birth in those cases where notification is received within 13 weeks of the birth; and
ensuring, where pensioners have children and are receiving maintenance income, the maintenance income only affects the child related payments.
These changes result in a more equitable method for assessing child related payments and flow from the family payments structure under the Social Security Act 1991.

PARA.TAB: This bill provides consistency in the arrangements for offsetting compensation payments against disability pension for the same incapacity or death for which compensation is paid. At present, this provision applies only to disability pensions paid under part IV of the Veterans' Entitlements Act in respect of defence or certain peacekeeping service. The amendment ensures that the offsetting arrangements will also apply to disability pension paid under part II in respect of war or operational service. This provision will apply only to payments of compensation made after the date of royal assent.

The bill also clarifies the operation of the tax file number provisions where a person fails to comply with a request for a tax file number. In such instances, the Veterans' Entitlements Act currently directs that the person's pension or allowance is not to be paid.

The amendments set out the effect of failing to comply with a request for a tax file number and introduce a generous reconsideration period. It is proposed to give the person three months from the date the pension was last paid to comply with the request for a tax file number and still receive full restitution of the cancelled payment. This would allow the person time to consider the consequences of failing to provide the tax file number. If, however, a person complies with the request after the expiration of the three-month period, the pension or allowance will then be restored from the payday after compliance.

This three-month period is in addition to the 28 days that the Secretary to the Department of Veterans' Affairs already allows the person to comply with the request before action is taken to stop the pension payment. This amendment puts beyond doubt the intention of the legislation.

Of course, this initiative will apply only to pensioners required by the Secretary to provide a tax file number. If the individual or a pensioner category has been exempted from providing a tax file number, these amendments will not apply. Another initiative simplifies the current arrangements for withdrawing an application to determine qualifying service or a claim for service pension. It allows for a person to orally withdraw an application or a claim and to reactivate that application or claim, within 28 days of its withdrawal, without penalty to the original one. This initiative is consistent with the aim of assisting pensioners in their dealings with the department by encouraging oral communications.

A further amendment will be made to the definition of `income' to exempt from that definition payments received from the New South Wales Medically-Acquired HIV Trust. This follows a similar amendment to the Veterans' Entitlements Act in 1992 which exempted payments received from the Mark Fitzpatrick Trust.
Finally, this bill will make a number of minor changes in the area of service pension assessment including a series of technical and consequential amendments. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation, the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill, brought back to the House represents a victory for the coalition in its changes deleting the original part 7 with regard to managed investments. As such, the only double dissolution trigger effectively before the parliament evaporates from this day as things now stand. The Liberal and National parties will support this adjusted, amended new legislation from the new Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca), which takes account of the actions of the Senate in rejecting the old part 7 last time around when this legislation was considered. So the double dissolution circumstance and opportunity have now been removed from the political agenda for the time being, depending on what flows from the budget legislation and other legislation to come before us in what is going to be a very busy session of the federal parliament between now and 30 June.

PARA.TAB: The budget for veterans is a most interesting element of the budget. There are some welcome payments—$20 million in additional funding for young veterans over the next four years to be offset, however, by some changes in the small print which I highlight to the RSL and to veterans around Australia. Firstly, the intermediate rate and TPI pension will no longer be granted to veterans over the age of 65 years. Let me hasten to add that all existing TPI pensioners will continue to receive their payments. I do not want to run up an argument on any inaccurate dimension, and I have discussed this with the minister. Once the relevant legislation passes through as a consequence of the budget, new grants of TPIs will not be made to those over the age of 65, with that additional qualification.

This is directed at a perceived anomaly, where public servants around some of our capital cities and others who might have had wartime service suddenly choose to take a retirement package. Many of them make a learned decision to become farmers on small farms around capital cities and then utilise their new career of farming as being one relevant to the consideration of their eligibility for a TPI. It is alleged that they then go in with a raft of applications for intermediate rate or full rate TPI pension in circumstances where that was not the original intention associated with a totally and permanently incapacitated pension.

I highlight, in conjunction with my colleague Senator David MacGibbon, the shadow minister for veterans' affairs, that quite apart from the rights and the wrongs of that, there are others who are permanently working in their particular industry—quite often it is the farming industry—well beyond the age of 65 who may well seek, quite properly and legitimately, an eligibility for and the granting of an intermediate rate or full TPI pension.

There is a second element just in passing in the small print which I think is probably of more critical concern, and that is that disabilities will be measured against a norm for given age. A medical tribunal will make decisions in relation to the degree of disability. The government proposes to set up the Repatriation Medical Authority comprising medical specialists. The authority will formulate statements of principle that exclusively state what elements of medical scientific evidence will be necessary to establish a causal association between a veterans disease and injuries in war service.

They might like to start by looking at the air conditioning system of this parliament, because there is one humdinger of a virus going around this place in this particular budget sitting week. I often think the air conditioning in this parliament is designed to make sure that a cross-section of every virus, cold and flu from 148 electorates is assembled and intermixed at 2 o'clock on Tuesday. All of us, including the hardworking staff, are guaranteed to be exposed to these viruses and rather debilitating conditions which have imposed themselves upon me in the last 36 hours. But I will battle on.

More seriously—serious as the health and workplace environment of people who work here is—on the question of this tightening up of disability pension eligibility, the coalition has legitimate concerns that in the small print of the budget, assessment will be made much tougher for older veterans who have served this country in time of war. We have concerns which will be addressed in more detail in the legislation which is to come at a later stage, or in the tabling of instruments, which will be disallowable instruments, and we will study them at that time. But we do so against a judgment that upon this parliament rests a responsibility to see that the right things shall be done for those who have served their country in time of war. There should be no short-changing in that regard. That brings me back to the legislation before the House.

The other elements of the legislation before the House have been detailed in the minister's speech. Therefore, I will not delay the House, other than to say that we have consistently indicated our support for all but the managed investment components of the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1994. The minister has now taken account of this, and I acknowledge that. Therefore, the Liberal and National parties will not oppose this new legislation in its new form. Nevertheless, we have a particular query. I refer the minister to his media release dated—curiously enough—1 April 1994, April Fools' Day. The minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: The previous Minister asked the Secretary of my Department to reconsider sympathetically the exemption guidelines for the provision of tax file numbers following representations from a small number of clients.

The Secretary has now determined that those pensioners, who receive ONLY a disability pension and can provide proof that their income and assets preclude them from receiving an income support pension or benefit from my Department, may be exempted from providing their tax file numbers.

My Department will be writing to those pensioners whose pension has been suspended or cancelled under the former guidelines advising them of a new exemption provision. They can then reapply to have their disability pension reinstated if they meet the new criteria.

I have two questions for the minister on the specifics of this legislation. My first question has several parts to it. How does the new part 7 of the new bill—a completely new part 7, because the old part 7 was taken out—which relates entirely to the provision of tax file numbers, square up with the minister's 1 April statement? In the detail of it, does it in fact obliquely bypass the thrust of the minister's assurance by a sin of omission? Where in the new part 7 does it specifically relate to and guarantee the utterances of the minister with regard to the provision of tax file numbers? I have a second and related question. If at the end of the day people are in one of these other categories and fail to provide their tax file number, presumably even under the new part 7 they will still lose their pension payment at that time. I seek clarification of that. I will listen with interest to the minister's response.

PARA.TAB: This tax file number situation is a very important threshold principle. Senator MacGibbon has raised it. Leonard Teale is one particular veteran who took an in-principle stand which led to an alteration of the situation as announced by the minister in his statement of 1 April. Before the House we now see legislation detailing part 7 of the bill in a curiously worded way which at the end of the day still leaves in place the suspension if people do not comply with the issue of the TFN. So there are two related issues to the new part 7. Firstly, does the minister's statement of 1 April in exactitude not conflict with—and in fact has it been taken up in—the provisions of part 7 of the bill? Secondly, at the end of the day, if those in other categories of veterans pensions still do not provide the TFN, presumably the pension remains suspended. I want clarification of those issues.

The complexity of repatriation and veterans affairs arrangements over the years has been well recognised. For two years this parliament debated the first veterans entitlements bill to try to streamline repatriation legislation. Even so, it seems that we have to layer on additional legislation, often reflecting beneficial decisions for veterans. Some of it is so complex—and I will not bother to delay the House by reading extracts from this bill—that it is a necessity, even in the plain English legislative drafting that we now have before the House, that we now have 69 additional pages of complexity attached to the Veterans' Entitlements Act.

The responsibility of the government, the minister and the parliament is to see that there is no excessive addition to the burden of bureaucracy and complexity associated with the administration of veterans affairs so that at the end of the day the services and the outcomes are delivered in as simple a form as possible so far as the legislative base of repatriation in this country is concerned. As the minister will no doubt come back to the parliament yet again with a further round of legislation and/or tabled instruments arising from the budget, I appeal to the minister to be ever mindful that if it can be done in 11 pages instead of 69 pages then of course it should be done in 11 pages—if that can be the case, given the complexity associated with repatriation.

The coalition is not opposed to this legislation. I have lodged my queries with regard to the new part 7. It is a victory that the government has changed its mind, changed its course, and dropped the old part 7. By that action and by our attitude on the floor of the House this day, responsible as it is, the only double dissolution trigger before the parliament has now evaporated.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill has been debated for some time. I am pleased to note that the government has finally capitulated to the wisdom of the coalition and omitted the clause relating to managed investments. The coalition did not agree that changes to managed investments should be introduced in this bill before the committee inquiring into pensions and managed investments had reported. We would not be party to changes to the assessment of managed investments and other retirement income while at the same time the government was examining the entire system.

PARA.TAB: It is simply not fair to chop and change managed investments legislation, particularly when dealing with an aged veteran and pensioner community. How are people supposed to prepare for their retirement when the rules keep changing? The Australian Democrats supported us in this move; however, it has taken some months of persuading for the government to see the light. The government had been claiming it could not wait for the committee's report on managed investments. As my colleague Senator MacGibbon stated in the upper house, the answer to this is that the government must put more resources into the committee to assist it to report as early as possible. Therefore, I welcome the government's capitulation and look forward to its giving way on further legislation in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't hold your breath. This is because we are being good to the diggers.

—Thank you. The Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill includes the introduction of issues that the minister has spoken of, that is, the seniors health card, child-related payments, disability pensions payable and lump sum compensation, and it changes the definition of retirement villages.

PARA.TAB: There is a strong veteran community in my electorate of Grey, with just over 1,500 veterans receiving benefits. I recently had the privilege of attending Anzac Day celebrations in Port Augusta, Port Pirie and Whyalla, which is always a very moving experience. I think it reminds all of us in a very timely way of the contribution that has been made over the generations. I think one most encouraging point that my colleagues have brought home to me in recent days has been young people's interest in and respect for Anzac Day, and this is perhaps no better illustrated than by the attendance at the Gallipoli Peninsula on 25 April over the last few years.

Many veterans have approached me with concerns about the government's treatment of their income and assets. I am disappointed that last night's budget offered them so little. The budget did declare an extra $20 million for the welfare of younger veterans, however, this increased funding is merely a diversion to hide the real decreases in veterans' benefits. Many veterans will no longer be compensated for physical disabilities as a consequence of their service experience, which often become apparent in advancing years. As a result, the government will save $18 million over four years.

The government will also set up a medical tribunal to determine claims, whose decisions will not be challengeable. There is no doubt that the government has set up this tribunal to save dollars. Those dollars will come from veterans. The aim of the tribunal is to reduce the number of veterans who will be granted compensation in the future. I do welcome the long overdue announcement of the $20.6 million rehabilitation program for war veterans, also welcomed by the Vietnam Veterans Association. Vietnam veterans have been rightly angered for many years at the government's non-acceptance of their need for help. This money comes after the recent failure of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to acknowledge our veterans when he was in Vietnam.

In other budget moves, it is pleasing to note that, after many years of lobbying by our merchant mariners who served in World War II, they will now receive the veterans pension for the first time. Even the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca), acknowledged that this recognition of the mariners was long overdue. The Kokoda memorial is also to get $900,000 in 1994-95 and a further $700,000 in the subsequent year, and this is to be welcomed.

I return to the subject of the government's assessment of pensioners' and veterans' managed investments which, as I mentioned earlier, was the subject of contention in earlier debates on this bill. An inquiry into this was clearly urgently needed. The unfairness and anomalies under the present test are estimated to have affected 200,000 people who hold managed investments. In September last year, 55,670 pensioners had their pensions decreased because of a reassessment by the Department of Social Security. This saved just over $1 million for the government. If the government continues to penalise pensioners and veterans for saving and investing for retirement, many will simply dispose of their productive assets to maximise their pension entitlement. The government does not seem to be able to come to terms with that fact.

It is important to remember that pensioners' and veterans' unrealised gains on shares are just paper gains. They do not provide cash, they do not provide food. As least as much as any other group in our society, our veterans and pensioners require security for the future. They need to be able to plan their retirement, particularly with a government which is so strict on pensioners' and veterans' own individual plans and savings. In conclusion, with this bill the coalition has ensured that the government is kept in check and some stability is given to veterans' incomes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca), on his appointment. I imagine it is a tough job. I wish him well and I hope that he will act consistently—I am sure that he will attempt to act consistently—in the interests of veterans. In some respects, I hope that he will do a better job for veterans than he did for social security beneficiaries when, as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security, he led the debate for the government on the pensioner shares fiasco where, right to the last minute, to his credit, I suppose—and the veterans might see the irony—he actually fought a last-ditch battle until that finally went down the gurgler to a large extent. So I wish the minister good luck in this particular area.

PARA.TAB: As the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) has already pointed out, this bill is a major victory for both the opposition and the veterans community. It reintroduces the amendments which were proposed in the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3), with the exception of part 7. It was part 7 of the bill which was so strongly objected to by the opposition and, eventually, the government could not get part 7 of its original bill through the Senate.

To its credit, the Senate is responsible for the government now being forced to back down and exclude the provisions of part 7 of the original legislation which dealt with an area not too far removed from the one I mentioned earlier when we talked about the unrealised capital gains on pensioner share portfolios. That similar and somewhat related area is that of the treatment of managed investments, which the government was also attempting to foist on both social security beneficiaries and Veterans' Affairs pensioners.

So we are delighted that the bill has now been brought back in this form and, as the Leader of the National Party said on behalf of the opposition, we support broadly the provisions of this particular bill because they are generally advantageous to veterans, and there will always be support on this side of the House for legislation that supports veterans. I am very proud to be a member of a Liberal-National Party coalition which has over the years consistently and comprehensively demonstrated its support for veterans and their families. I am very proud of that fact. When the government brings in legislation which enhances the position of veterans, it can always be assured of our support.

Unfortunately, it was up to some of its old tricks with the original legislation that it introduced, the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3), because there it attempted to lump in a number of things that were beneficial to veterans with something that was clearly not beneficial—a trick it has tried a number of times before. It is a fairly crass political tactic to ensnare the opposition in a difficult position as to whether it supports or opposes.

In some cases it has been a very successful political tactic, because it has put us somewhere between a rock and a hard place: if we vote against a bill where there are some advantageous provisions, we are likely to be interpreted as being unsupportive; in the other case, if we support the bill as a whole, we are caught on the other side of the fence. In this particular instance, though, the tactic has failed badly and the government is left—and I would like to hear the minister admit it—with considerable egg on its face because it has been forced to bring back this legislation—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is looking after 10,000 diggers, mate; that is all.

—Let us not be difficult about this. The facts are that the government has been forced to bring back this legislation in a new form without that part 7 which was objected to by us. That is a victory for the opposition but, more importantly, it is a victory for the veterans community, and that is what I am more pleased about.

PARA.TAB: The politics of it in the end do not matter a great deal; the important thing is that we can stand here today on this side of the House at least and say that this was a victory for the veterans community. I am very pleased that that is the case. The minister might want to try to argue his way out of that but I do not think he will be able to.

The minister maintains that this bill reflects the government's continuing concern for the welfare of veterans and their dependants. As I have already pointed out, this was certainly not the case with the original bill. In fact, there are substantial residual doubts within the veterans community about the government's bona fides in respect of its treatment of veterans. In a sense, the new minister finds himself in a very hot seat indeed.

The insensitivity and thoughtlessness which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) displayed towards veterans during his recent trip to Vietnam has galvanised not only the veterans community but the general public as well. There was—quite understandably and correctly—a ground swell of opinion against the Prime Minister's behaviour and attitude in Vietnam on that recent trip. The increased numbers of people who turned out at the Anzac Day marches and observances around the country this year reflect the widespread support in the community for the ideals for which veterans fought and died.

The Prime Minister demonstrated—for all veterans, not only Vietnam veterans—that he fails to understand that particular fact. To some extent, the minister now finds himself in the position of having to take on a task that in many respects might be seen as a lost cause, and that is to convince the veterans community that the government really genuinely cares about them. If it is not a lost cause, then it certainly is a very difficult one.

As has already been said, there is nothing in this bill that we find objectionable. I might take the opportunity of asking the minister something while he is here. I do not want to get diverted too much onto the budget, but the debate on veterans affairs generally today is timely. There are a number of issues which have been raised in the last 24 hours and, indeed, in the last couple of days, because there have been a number of very significant events which affect veterans. The first event was the release of A fair go, the so-called Baume report on compensation for veterans and war widows. This report, by and large, is very comprehensive and extremely helpful in clarifying a number of issues and setting the ground for debate on a number of issues in the area of veterans affairs.

I want to point out another sorry event in the history of this government's treatment of veterans, and that was its reaction to the Bushell decision. I want the minister to make it very clear that that is now, as far as the government is concerned, a dead issue. Of course it is referred to in some detail in A fair go, and I am very pleased that the Baume committee actually makes this statement:

SPEECH.PARA: We do not accept DVA's first stance of the flood gates opening with the advent of the Bushell case. We do accept that the endorsement of the interpretation by the High Court will lead to an increase in claims and success rates, and in the potential for exploitation.

That fact is reflected in the committee's recommendations. I want to make sure that the government absolutely accepts that that is now the position and that there will not be any further attempt to rush in, as indeed it did. It could hardly contain itself after the Bushell decision in the High Court. It rushed in here with legislation aimed at overcoming a court decision which was clearly beneficial to veterans.

PARA.TAB: The government lost a great deal of credibility through that reaction. If it had only reacted to the Bushell case to adjust, in a sense, the decision that was made by the court, perhaps that might have been excusable or understandable. In fact, there was an attempt within that context to go way beyond the Bushell case: an attempt by the government not only to address the effect of the Bushell case directly but, in the view of the veterans community—and obviously that view prevailed, as it turned out—to effectively overturn the Bushell decision. I want the veterans community to be absolutely sure that the government now accepts the decision.

I am not certain of that, as a result of having looked closely at the budget. The Baume committee recommended only one change, and that was that the standard of proof for operational service was to be reasonable satisfaction. That was to replace the test that existed, which was the reasonable hypothesis test. There is no mention yet about the government's reaction to that recommendation, although I take it that—

TALK.START.PARA: —We have rejected it.
—I am asking you to confirm that you have rejected that.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—The honourable member for McPherson will address his remarks to the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, Mr Deputy Speaker. The minister was helping me a little. I want him to make that absolutely sure. I take it then that the government's acceptance of the Baume committee's recommendation that an expert medical committee be established to resolve general medical issues and to formulate statements of principle for application or decision making has been accepted. It is not called that, as I see from the budget papers; it has been called a medical tribunal, and I think the minister has since given it some other name. I take it that that is the response to the Bushell case and that that is the end; that there will be no further attempt by the government to change the advantageous decision of the Bushell case. Hansard will not show that the minister is nodding his head in agreement, but when he replies he can put that on the record so we can all be quite sure.

PARA.TAB: I will not delay the debate much longer but I want to make the minister aware, if he is not already aware, of some residual concerns in the veterans community. There is still, with some justification, considerable suspicion or doubt about the government's long-term intentions in relation to the treatment of TPIs. The budget makes provision for the fact that the intermediate rate and the TPI rate will no longer be granted to veterans over 65 years of age, et cetera. But there is still concern in the veterans community that somehow the government's longer term intention is actually to take that disability pension from pensioners who already have it, those who have already turned 65.

I would like the minister to make it absolutely clear to the veterans community that that is not the government's intention—not now, not tomorrow and not while he remains the minister or however far he can go towards giving a clear and unequivocal commitment on that particular point. That remains a concern.

The important point that needs to be made in relation to disability pensions generally is that they are not welfare. There is some feeling generally that somehow they are welfare. They are not welfare; these pensions are the earned entitlements of veterans. They are compensation for illness, disability and other contributing factors. The point needs to be made that we are not talking about welfare; that we are talking about something veterans have earned. That is why some suggestion in the foreshadowing of the Baume report suggesting that veterans' benefits were somehow overgenerous, to use the word that came out at the time, indicated a misunderstanding or a misconstruction of what veterans entitlements are all about.

I add to the remarks already made about Australian mariners. I congratulate the government on finally coming to that particular decision. We also welcome the proposals in respect of younger veterans and Vietnam veterans. The minister has made a number of announcements about the $20.6 million assistance package for younger veterans. A fair go goes into considerable detail about health options for younger veterans. I am pleased that the government has noted most of that and particularly the comments about improvements to the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service.

I say again there is considerable suspicion within the Vietnam veterans community about the long-term intentions of the government in respect of the VVCS. I would like the minister to make absolutely clear now, today, without equivocation, that the government will continue to maintain the VVCS as a separate and independent entity and that in fact the VVCS is not under threat.

I say that because, as far as the Vietnam veterans community is concerned, there have been signs and signals that the government's intentions in this respect are otherwise. The Vietnam veterans welcome the fact that within the budget there will be increases in resources to enable expansion of the role of the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service. On the face of it that would seem to indicate quite clearly the government's long-term intentions. But things can change quickly.

The Vietnam veterans also welcome the reference in the budget to a mortality study of Vietnam veterans which will be conducted to ascertain the rate of death from all causes, particularly suicide and cancer. I asked the previous minister, the honourable member for Batman (Mr Howe), a question on notice on 15 December 1993, only a few months back, about the death of a particular Vietnam veteran in Queensland. I went on to ask the Minister about the rate of deaths of Vietnam veterans. I asked him:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . how many of the deaths have been attributed to (a) suicide or (b) suspected suicide?
The minister replied:

(4) The Department of Defence has advised that about 53,000 personnel either served, or were deemed allotted for service in Vietnam. My Department has estimated there to be about 49,600 surviving Vietnam veterans. This estimate is based on 501 deaths in action and about 2,900 deaths since 1973.
(5) Of the total number of deaths reported to the Department, 176 have been classified as deaths from suicide or self-inflicted injury. Five deaths have been classified as `undetermined . . . `

The Vietnam veterans with whom I have discussed this hotly dispute those figures. In fact, they asked the government—and the minister might take this on notice for a future time—how it arrived at those figures. There is a suspicion—and I implied it in my question—that, in fact, there are many more than 2,900 Vietnam veterans that have died since 1973. There is a very strong suspicion—but only on an anecdotal basis—that the number of suicides is very much in excess of 176.

PARA.TAB: I give the government some credit for setting up the mortality study of the Vietnam veterans, and I take it that that study results from questions such as mine. It will have a close look not only at the suicide rate—in my electorate there have been some Vietnam veteran suicides—but also at the question of deaths from cancer and other related illnesses.

I appreciate the opportunity to make a few broader comments on veterans affairs in the context of this bill. I wish the minister the very best of luck. He knows of my personal interest in veterans matters, and I can assure him of my ongoing oversight of his work in his portfolio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca The Hon C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—First of all, let me acknowledge that I am well aware of the personal interest in matters relating to our community of veterans, as espoused certainly by the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) and indeed the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer). I have taken on board the comments that have been made, particularly with respect to the question of the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service. The Leader of the National Party may remember that I was a member of the House of Representatives committee chaired by my good friend and colleague the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) back in 1988 or thereabouts. The Minister for Consumer Affairs (Ms McHugh) was also on the committee. We looked at the adequacy or otherwise of the services of the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service.

PARA.TAB: I want to assure the honourable member for McPherson that, rather than wanting to wind down the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service, we are going to beef it up. In fact, if he reads the budget documents carefully, he will see that. I accept the fact that there has not been much time to read them. Vietnam veterans can rest assured that there are certainly no thoughts in my mind or in the mind of the government to get rid of the counselling service.

I did not want to say too much on this bill, and I particularly do not want to say too much with respect to the budget announcements of last night. As was correctly stated by the Leader of the National Party, we will be able to discuss and debate those issues at a later time when that legislation comes in.

I want to make a number of points on this bill. It is true that this bill could have been used as a double dissolution trigger. I feel somewhat surprised in many respects that the opposition would claim this as a victory. Let me tell the House exactly what the position is with this bill. The fact is that this bill was passed by this House but rejected by the Senate on the basis that there was a section of it, part 7 of the old bill, which related to managed investments. The opposition has this rule which, in a stubborn sort of a way, it will not change. If there are any bills that come before the Senate which relate to or have anything in them to do with managed investments or shares, it refuses to let them go through. So it did the same thing with this bill, notwithstanding that the changes in part 7 of the old bill in so far as it related to managed investments were beneficial changes. That was the funny thing: they were beneficial changes. Nevertheless, at the end of the day, the reality remained that the bill did not go through.

The government could quite easily have been cynical about this. But when I took over the veterans affairs ministry one of the first matters that came to my attention was the fact that on 1 July 1994 some 200,000 social security pensioners would end up with a Commonwealth seniors health card as a result of legislation which I introduced some time ago in another capacity. But, because this bill had not gone through, some 10,000 veterans and their dependants would miss out on this Commonwealth seniors health card. It was therefore then my decision, as the new minister, on what I wanted to do with this. As I said, we could have quite easily been cynical about it. We could have quite easily used the opportunity, if that was what was in our minds, to do exactly that and use this as a double dissolution trigger.

I have reintroduced this bill not because it is a victory that can be claimed by the coalition, or a victory that I claim either, but because it is a victory for those 10,000 veterans and their dependants who, come 1 July 1994, will receive their Commonwealth seniors health card from the Department of Veterans' Affairs. They are the winners out of all of this. I am surprised that the coalition would want to be crass enough to claim some sort of victory. The end result is this: as the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, I refuse to allow these 10,000 veterans and their dependants to be used as pawns in a political game played by the opposition. It is for that reason, and that reason alone, that I have introduced this bill, minus part 7, the way it was before.

I can look the honourable member for McPherson and the Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Farrer, in the eye and say to them that this was a decision which I took, and I can assure them that no-one tried to talk me out of it. So it can be seen that the intentions of the government on this were very pure. I will not claim credit for it; the government will not claim credit for it; but opposition members should not claim credit for it either. It is very crass of them to do so.

The Leader of the National Party and the member for McPherson raised the question of the initiatives that were in the budget last night. I will not go into them in any detail, but the Leader of the National Party did say, I think, that he intends to let the ex-service community know of the small print in the budget. By all means let him do that, because I have let them know—Senator Faulkner, my predecessor in this job, has been talking with them for months and months—what our intentions are. Rather than telling honourable members on the other side of the House myself and getting the reaction that that is just the government talking, let me read from a press release that was put out last night by the very well respected president of the Returned Services League, Major General Digger James. I do not think that anyone can possibly say that Major General Digger James is a pawn of any government. The press release headed, `1994 budget good deal for vets' said:

SPEECH.PARA: The 1994 Budget has good news for veterans, in particular the rejection of central planks in the recent Baume report, RSL National President Major General Digger James said tonight.

"In particular we are pleased the Government has rejected Professor Baume's recommendation that the standard of proof now applied to assessing compensation claims be diluted to the civil standard", Major General James said.
"This would have been contrary to the whole ethos of our system and we congratulate the government for standing firm against it.

"Equally, we are pleased at the rejection of any suggestion that veterans are no more than just another group of welfare recipients. To this end we congratulate the Government for transferring war widows and widowers support pensions from social security to the DVA."

Major General James said the new Repatriation Medical Authority which was being set up to streamline the vexed question of the causal relationship between veterans' diseases and injuries and war service was also welcome.
"This initiative has resulted from extensive consultation between the former Minister Senator Faulkner and the present Minister Mr Sciacca and veterans", Major General James said.

"If it is successful—and we believe it will be—it will help solve a problem which has plagued Repatriation since its inception and, since the opening of the system to the courts in the late 1970s, resulted in hugely expensive legal cases." He said he was pleased, too, that the Government had rejected Baume's quite unnecessary recommendations for restructuring TPI and War Widows' pensions.
The final paragraph says:

"Overall, this is a very reasonable Budget indeed as far as we are concerned. The pre-Budget consultative processes with both ministers were exemplary and we look forward to continuing monitoring processes to ensure the intent of the new measures is fulfilled".

I read that because really this is a bipartisan situation—I am sure it can be. I am sure that we will end up getting the approval of the opposition for the full measure because this is a package deal. Almost if not all of what we might save as a result of any perceived tightening up of conditions will be put back into the veterans community by virtue of the more than $20 million package for the Vietnam veterans and others.

PARA.TAB: We can talk about it at a later stage, but I can assure the Leader of the National Party of Australia that just about everything that is in this budget has been passed by the veterans community. Indeed, when we arrange to appoint the medical tribunal, even the names of the people that I would consider appointing will be passed by the Vietnam Veterans Association, the RSL, et cetera.

I look forward to a bipartisan approach from the Leader of the National Party of Australia because I know that he will look at it. At the end of the day this is one of those situations where we say to the opposition, `You can't have the goodies with this without the baddies, because I can't pay for the goodies without the things which you would consider as the baddies but which the RSL certainly does not consider as being bad.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Tax file number.

—I will just answer the query of the Leader of the National Party on the tax file number. He was concerned about the new part 7 under this bill in so far as it related to tax file number exemptions. The new part 7 does not affect my previous statement made on 1 April 1994 as read out by the Leader of the National Party:

SPEECH.PARA: Part 7 applies only to pensioners who are required to provide a tax file number. If the individual pensioner category has been exempted from providing a tax file number, part 7 does not apply.

However, if the secretary does require a person to provide a tax file number, part 7 does apply. The person will have at least 28 days to comply with the request and then the provisions of part 7 will apply.

There is an implied power within the power to require a person to provide a tax file number to withdraw that requirement. Thus the secretary can exempt a person by withdrawing the request for a tax file number. Subsection 128A(2) of the Veterans Entitlements Act refers. . .

In other words, as in the Leonard Teale case, which was brought up by the Leader of the National Party of Australia, the position is that the secretary may decide that, if a person is in receipt of no other income or benefit from social security, receives only a disability pension of some sort and does not come near the government for anything else, he or she is exempt from the requirement, and this bill does not change that position.

PARA.TAB: I thank the opposition for its cooperation on this matter. I am sorry that we had to go to this extent because of its stubbornness in the Senate. At the end of the day, I suppose, all's well that ends well. I commend the bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
