Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Sciacca) read a third time.
Consideration resumed from 23 March.
Motion (by Ms McHugh) proposed:

That the Trade Practices Amendment (Origin Labelling) Bill be referred to the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology for consideration and an advisory report to the House by 6 June 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Trade Practices Amendment (Origin Labelling) Bill 1994, the subject of this motion is to introduce a scheme whereby consumers would be better able to distinguish the Australianness of consumer goods. Extensive consultations have taken place to try to develop a scheme which would assist consumers and which industry would find easy to use. The Minister for Consumer Affairs (Ms McHugh) has appropriately moved that this bill should go to the House Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. That committee currently has a reference entitled `Government purchasing policies and promotion of Australian made goods and services'. The subject matter of that general reference readily relates to, and overlaps with, the subject matter of this bill.

PARA.TAB: The coalition supports strongly the proposal to have a labelling scheme which, while not being overly burdensome to industry, makes it easier for consumers who want very much to support Australian industry to be able to ascertain the sources of products. The scheme proposed under the bill provides for labels on products making a claim about their Australianness. The first type of label would read `Produce of Australia' or `Product of Australia'. This would apply where Australia was the place of origin of each major ingredient or component of the goods and all operations involved in the manufacture or production of the goods happened in Australia.

The second type of label would read `Made in Australia'. This would apply to goods which acquired their essential character or qualities in Australia. The third type of label would read `Assembled'—or `packed' or `sewn', or some similar verb—`in Australia from imported components'. That is self-explanatory. In addition, the bill contemplates that goods that carry a representation likely to be regarded as an Australian origin representation—for example, a kangaroo or a koala, the Australian flag or a map of Australia—must also carry information about the actual origin of the goods.

A number of concerns need to be addressed, and they make a committee inquiry entirely appropriate. The description `Made in Australia'—meaning that the goods acquired their essential character in Australia—is not specific and could in fact apply to goods all of whose ingredients came from overseas. This description also raises questions as to the relationship of the first two categories, that is the distinction between `produced' and `made' in Australia. There is a potential problem of mislabelling occurring due to seasonal supply problems, such as a major ingredient going out of supply.

The definition of a major ingredient or component, in the `Produce/product of Australia' descriptor, is not specified. The government has said that guidelines will be developed but, plainly, they have not yet been prepared or tabled. The proposed section 65VJ and section 65VK cover the use of the Australian origin representations—the kangaroos, flags and maps, et cetera—and require that the foreign origin representation be as prominent as the Australian connection representation, and that the representations be as close to each other as possible. Debate could obviously ensue as to what is `prominent' and what is `close'.

The coalition thanks the minister for agreeing to refer the bill to the committee. The House is to be commended for its third decision to refer a bill to a standing committee. It is the first reference of a bill to the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, the two previous references being to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. The coalition members of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology have advised me that they are keen to ensure that the committee's report is tabled with expedition, and the coalition looks forward to the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I might just add that I too see the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology as a most appropriate committee to have a further look at the proposed legislation, particularly because of the work it has been doing on Australian government purchasing. I will take one minute only, not to debate the bill, but to take up the points that were made by the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams).

PARA.TAB: We are indeed happy to try to address any of these concerns, just as we have been happy to address every concern that has been raised during the 18-month discussion of this bill that we have had with the community and with industry. It is in that very same spirit of cooperation that has been the hallmark of the bill so far that I am happy to refer it to that committee even though, unfortunately, it was only at noon yesterday that we discovered that the opposition still had some concerns.

I want people to understand that the intentions of the bill are only to end the confusion, which will in itself be a great benefit to industry and consumers. The bill will support industry and therefore jobs. It will also give industry 12 months to cooperatively develop the guidelines for the scheme to which the honourable member referred and to change existing labels. The guidelines cannot be prepared until the legislation is through. The guidelines are to be developed with industry, at industry's request, for its assistance. One of the responsibilities of my bureau is to assist industry to comply with the law, and the means of doing this is to develop guidelines that help suppliers to be fully aware of their obligations and responsibilities under the law.

As for matters like seasonal variations that the honourable member referred to, it is important that the legislation set rules that are as definite as possible and that will not mislead consumers. For instance, `Product of Australia' means virtually `all Australian'. If the legislation did deal with all the possible permutations that might arise in practice, it would have to set different percentage levels of Australian content.

We looked into the possibility of doing all that sort of thing, but then suppliers would still move between levels and have to relabel as the source of the ingredients changed. Such legislation would be very complex and certainly harder to enforce than the type of legislation I am proposing. All the matters that are being raised anywhere at all by industry, by consumer groups, by anyone in the community, are being addressed and have been addressed. The consultation has been extraordinary so far, with over 5,000 pieces of correspondence.

Just let me end by saying that the industry associations we have discussed this with include the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Council; the Plastics Industry Association; the New South Wales Chamber of Commerce; the Carpet Institute of Australia; Myer; Grace Brothers; the Buy Tasmania Association; and the Tasmanian Food and Beverage Association, to name just a few. Anyone who has come with a concern has had that concern—for the most part, I believe—dealt with.

The groups are satisfied to the extent that many industries are already switching over to the terms that we propose. For that reason we are getting a lot of messages from industry saying, `Please do not delay the bill any longer.' So we are acceding to the opposition's request in this matter and hope that very soon we will be back with the bill.
Question resolved in the affirmation.

DEBATE.TITLE: PETROLEUM (SUBMERGED LANDS) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1994Cognate bills:PETROLEUM (SUBMERGED LANDS) (USER CHARGE) BILL 1994PETROLEUM (SUBMERGED LANDS) FEES BILL 1994OFFSHORE MINERALS (EXPLORATION LICENCE USER CHARGE) BILL 1993OFFSHORE MINERALS (RETENTION LICENCE USER CHARGE) BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 4 May.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill is part of the package of legislation to implement the 1993-94 budget decision to impose a charge on industry to support the continental margins program conducted by the Australian Geological Survey Organisation, AGSO. The charge, which will be imposed on petroleum and minerals exploration permits and retention leases offshore under Commonwealth jurisdiction, will recover approximately one half of the cost of the program.

PARA.TAB: This bill will enable charges to be appropriated from the consolidated revenue fund to support the program. Consistent with the existing provision allowing cancellation of titles if titleholders do not pay outstanding fees within three months of their due date, the bill will allow cancellation for non-payment of the charge.

The government commissioned an independent review of AGSO in 1992 led by Dr Max Richards, known as the Richards review, to enhance Australia's geoscience effort. The review panel, which included senior members of the petroleum and minerals industries, carefully examined AGSO's operations. The review's report contained a wide range of recommendations, which have been carefully considered by the government. The continental margins program was identified by the review as essential.

The objectives of the continental margins program are to provide geoscientific information and advice in order to improve offshore petroleum and mineral exploration efficiency and effectiveness. The program also supports government decision making on offshore petroleum and mineral exploration and development. Other objectives of the program are to sustain Australia's legal continental shelf claim and to support intergovernmental negotiations on the delineation of seabed boundaries.

The Richards review argued that geoscientific work undertaken by AGSO through the continental margins program should by fully funded by government. The government's view is that, where there are community benefits, the community should pay. Where the industry benefits, the industry should pay. Where benefits are shared, costs should be shared.

The government's decision to raise approximately $10 million from the offshore exploration industry to fund about half the cost of the continental margins program, commencing in 1994-95, is based on the principle that the program benefits both the industry and the community. Therefore, both should contribute to its funding. The data and ideas flowing from the program have been of benefit to companies in their exploration programs. The charge will be applied to exploration permits and retention leases.

To date the continental margins program has focused on activities related to petroleum. Hence the charge will initially be levied only on the petroleum industry. Based on the current number of permits and leases, a charge of around $100,000 per title will be applied. Should the program, in consultation with industry, be extended to research of interest to the minerals industry, a charge will be applied to minerals exploration and retention licences.

The government is committed to ensuring that the work of AGSO, including this program, remains relevant to both industry and community needs. AGSO has thus been directed to consult fully with the industry in the development of, and reporting on, its programs. This will enable industry priorities to be taken into account. The program will be subject to evaluation in 1996-97.

This bill will also make a number of miscellaneous amendments to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 to improve efficiency in administration. The bill will also repeal four acts which provide for the charging of fees to cover costs of administering offshore petroleum titles. A separate bill will create a consolidated fees act to replace these four acts. I will now briefly refer to these miscellaneous amendments.

The bill will ensure that the outer territorial sea boundary adjacent to Western Australia and the Northern Territory will remain at three nautical miles for the purposes of this act. This amendment rectifies an inconsistency created when the Australia-Indonesia zone of cooperation in the Timor Gap was excised from the act in 1990.

An amendment is being made to ensure that joint delegations of routine joint authority powers to officials can be made to nominated positions rather than named persons. This amendment will avoid the need to issue a revised delegation instrument each time a different person holds a nominated position.

The bill will remove the need for the designated authority to consult titleholders affected by an access authority application where the applicant has obtained prior written agreement from relevant titleholders to the access authority. This amendment will streamline procedures for access authorities without affecting the rights of other parties.

The bill also clarifies that the companies rather than the regulatory authorities should accept ultimate liability for their operations. This decision will encourage companies to use their management skills to ensure that safety and environmental objectives are effectively met.

The bill will repeal the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Exploration Permit Fees) Act 1967, the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Production Licence Fees) Act 1967, the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Pipeline Licence Fees) Act 1967 and the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Retention Lease Fees) Act 1985. This will allow the consolidation of these acts into a single fees act. This proposed act forms the basis of a separate bill.

The amendments allowing the appropriation of user charges to partly fund the continental margins program have a financial impact. They will allow the $10 million expected to be raised each financial year, commencing in 1994-95, to be allocated to this program. None of the other amendments have any significant financial impact.

SPEECH.PARA: PETROLEUM (SUBMERGED LANDS) (USER CHARGE) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: This bill is part of the package of offshore petroleum and minerals bills. The government announced in the budget that a charge will be imposed on Commonwealth offshore petroleum exploration permits and retention leases. The purpose of the charge is to raise from the industry approximately half of the cost of the geophysical work undertaken by the Australian Geological Survey Organisation in its continental margins program. The bill imposes an annual charge on holders of offshore petroleum exploration permits and retention leases. The level of the charge will be set by regulation. The charge will be payable to the Commonwealth.

The bill will have a significant financial impact. Ten million dollars is expected to be raised each financial year, commencing in 1994-95. No user charges will be collected this year. The arrangements will be reconsidered at the time of the major review of the continental margins program in 1996-97.

SPEECH.PARA: PETROLEUM (SUBMERGED LANDS) FEES BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: This bill is also part of the package of offshore petroleum and minerals bills. The bill will establish the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Fees Act 1994—the fees act. This act will replace and consolidate the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Exploration Permit Fees) Act 1967, the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Production Licence Fees) Act 1967, the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Pipeline Licence Fees) Act 1967 and the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Retention Lease Fees) Act 1985. The consolidation of these four acts into a single fees act will reduce the quantity of legislation administering the offshore petroleum industry. The provisions of the fees act are equivalent to those of the four acts it replaces.
The move to a single fees act will not have any significant financial impact.I commend the bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of mineral and petroleum bills before the House will impose a new tax on the petroleum and minerals industries operating in the offshore zone. The offshore area includes the continental shelf and territorial sea. The government's intention is that $10 million per annum be raised by this new taxation measure. This revenue will constitute about half the cost of the continental margins program as conducted by the Australian Geological Survey Organisation, AGSO, formerly known as the Bureau of Mineral Resources. The continental margins program began in 1983. It was designed to research the structure and the evolution of Australia's continental plateaus and adjacent ocean basins, as well as the exclusive economic zone. The program provides a geological framework for hydrocarbon and mineral resource exploration and development.

PARA.TAB: The legislation now under consideration will require companies holding exploration or retention permits for the offshore area to pay an annual fee. It is worth noting that an exploration permit allows the holder to explore for petroleum in a specific area of offshore Australia, while a retention lease allows for further investigation of a discovery to occur and plans for production to be developed.

Initially, the tax will be zero for the minerals industry as the continental margins program does not yet address the shallow water geophysical work required by the offshore minerals industry for exploration. The petroleum industry will initially, therefore, provide the full $10 million through a charge on each offshore exploration or retention permit of around $100,000.

However, as the program focuses further on this work in the future, the government will increase the tax and include the offshore minerals industry. The intention is that the tax on the petroleum industry will decrease over time as the offshore minerals industry makes more use of the continental margins program and the charge for offshore minerals permits is correspondingly increased. In this way, the taxation measure will continue to be $10 million a year.

Although the government attempts to dress up this new tax as a user charge nothing could be further from the truth. It is a new taxation measure and bears no similarity to the concept of user charge. How can it, when the government sets the charge at $10 million per annum, and it does not matter whether there are 100 licence holders or retention permit holders or 1,000? That $10 million is still the set fee. It is an insult to the intelligence of the honourable members of this parliament, let alone the participants in the industry, to try to pretend this is a user charge. If there is a variable number of payers of the set amount, that means that the payer is not paying according to usage. There will be a set $10 million and each year there will be a different number of people contributing to that $10 million.

The $10 million does not come down to $5 million one year and then up to $15 million according to the amount of information provided under the continental margins program. It is utterly dishonest on any assessment of user charge to claim that the $10 million is anything other than a tax. User charging requires that the user of a service be charged for the provision of that service and for no other service.

Under this legislation, the seismic data provided to companies gaining exploration permits will not reflect the cost of provision of that data. The fact that they are holders of exploration permits immediately means that they have to pay $100,000 a year not $50,000 because they use less than another company which should be charged $200,000. There is no nexus between usage of the information provided and the charge applied to the company. Instead, under the legislation, the cost will be based on the number of years the permit is held with a rate of $100,000 per year.

Companies gaining an exploration permit will already have gained any possible benefit from the continental margins program data. On gaining the permit they will start paying $100,000 per year for seismic work that does not apply to their exploration permit. It is crystal clear: you pay $100,000, supposedly for data provided under the program, and then you pay $100,000 the next year and $100,000 the year after and the year after, and so on. Talk about double dipping! This is triple dipping and more.

If the information provided is related to the $100,000, then why do applicants not pay it when they gain the exploration permit? Why is it a renewable charge year in, year out? Why are they paying twice or four or five times for the same amount of data that was provided in the first year? The simple answer is that it is a tax. It is not a user charge. Realistically, user charging requires that if services cease to be provided then the charges should cease. If companies have paid for the information once, they should not have to pay for it several times over. That is not a user charge. It would be a user charge if the information provided was purchased once only. This legislation is going to require companies to continue paying $100,000 per year for so long as they hold the permit. As permits can be renewed indefinitely for five-year periods, the payments will extend far beyond any reasonable concept of user charging.

Again, allow me to stress that user charging requires that the charge rate should reflect the cost of providing the service received by the customer. None of the commonsense definitions of user charging apply to the proposal put forward by the government for the offshore petroleum and mineral industries. This is a smokescreen for a straight tax grab which has left the industry embittered. The primary objective of the continental margins program should be to increase the amount of petroleum and mineral exploration on Australia's continental shelf by providing pre-competitive seismic information to potential explorers.

In this instance, `pre-competitive' means that the seismic data generated does not indicate suitable sites for offshore oil wells but rather indicates geological structures which may include suitable drilling sites once further and more detailed seismic investigation is undertaken by the companies holding the exploration permits.

The government uses the seismic information obtained under the continental margins program to determine appropriate permit areas to release for exploration. Thus, the program is an important element in attracting minerals and petroleum investment to Australia's offshore areas. This is clearly a government responsibility. If the Australian government does not undertake the pre-competitive work—the base line research necessary to attract significant investment in petroleum and minerals exploration in Australia—then it is Australia which suffers. The petroleum and minerals industries will not suffer, as they will simply move to countries that view petroleum and minerals exploration more favourably.

In my discussions with the industry it has been made abundantly clear that the industry would prefer not having the continental margins program to paying for it in the way proposed by the legislation. Does the minister understand that? The industry does not make commercial use of the continental margins program. Let us have transparent and unambiguous user charges in regard to the continental margins program. Try selling data to the industry. It does not want it. It will do its own seismic data collection rather than pay for information which is not of crucial use to it.

The government has to answer this very simple point: if the program is of commercial benefit, as the minister in his second reading speech would have us believe, then why is the industry vowing to abandon the continental margins program rather than pay for it? The Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall) said in his second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the program benefits both the industry and the community. Therefore, both should contribute to its funding.

Let us test it. If the minister thinks the program is of benefit to industry, then charge industry for it, voluntarily, and see if industry takes it up. It will not. The minister goes on to say in his second reading speech:
The data and ideas flowing from the program have been of benefit to companies in their exploration programs.

Again, test it; test it. Make it a voluntary user charge and the industry will call your bluff. This is a compulsory contribution to the work of AGSO supposedly in the form of user charge but what in reality is a new tax. I think it is going to have very serious consequences for the relationship in the future between AGSO and the industry. I must say that I too am developing something of a jaundiced view of AGSO over this particular issue and over another which I will refer to shortly.

PARA.TAB: The minister said in his second reading speech that the community benefits from the continental margins program. Unquestionably. There is no doubt about that. As far as it is a public good program, the government should fully fund it.

We are going to hold the government to its claim that the program benefits industry. It is drawing a very long bow to claim that industry benefits from the program when the industry has said it does not want the program. Could anything be more clear? It is so obvious that this government is misleading the parliament in claiming that this is a user charge. The consequences are very serious for the investment climate as well as for the industry's relationship with AGSO.

The community clearly benefits from the continental margins program because Australia is a more attractive place to invest in as a result—and hence more jobs and more export income are created. The industry benefits from the program in that baseline exploratory work only has been done. It is totally misleading for the minister to claim that the industry benefits to the tune of $10 million from the continental margins program.

The program indicates to the government which permit areas can be released for exploration. Let us also make very clear that the government benefits directly from the program because it raises revenue from knowing which areas in offshore Australia to release for exploration and development. So the government is going to have to do the continental margins program, perhaps not in its totality as at present, and perhaps the government has to tailor the continental margins program to be truly commercial for its own purposes, but do not pretend that it is the industry which needs the continental margins program.

The government's interest is financial because it needs the program to give it that baseline information about hydrocarbon deposits and geological structures and the like so as to release areas for exploration. But there is also the larger national interest issue of developing Australia's resources. A failure by the government to fund the continental margins program in some form and the consequent failure to attract investment may well result in the dwindling of jobs and export income that these industries provide.

Mining and petroleum industry leaders have made it perfectly clear recently that they are lifting their sights to overseas prospects as the difficulties of conducting business in the resources sector in Australia increase. At present Australia enjoys over 80 per cent self-sufficiency in oil production. However, that degree of security will change disastrously without sufficient incentives to engage in the high-risk business of discovering fresh reserves. The government has a duty to the community to make Australia an attractive place for resources investment.
The minister makes the following claim in his second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: The government commissioned an independent review of AGSO in 1992 led by Dr Max Richards . . . The review's report contained a wide range of recommendations which have been carefully considered by the government. The continental margins program was identified by the review as essential.
At first glance, that would seem to indicate the support for the government's legislation by Dr Max Richards and the other members of that inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read on.

—It is cleverly worded to imply that the Richards review supports the introduction of these user charges. The Minister for Resources, who is at the table, invites me to read on from his second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: The Richards review argued that geoscientific work undertaken by AGSO through the continental margins program should be fully funded by government. The government's view is that, where there are community benefits, the community should pay. Where the industry benefits, the industry should pay. Where benefits are shared, costs should be shared.

I can see the minister's point: it does not lock the Richards review into outright support of the user charges proposed by the legislation but it certainly does not express the published view of Dr Max Richards that these user charges are outrageous and detrimental to the interests of one industry. The minister should be honest and unambiguously state the view of the Richards review, which is that the government should fund the continental margins program in so far as the government believes it conducts a public good.

PARA.TAB: Dr Richards is not endorsing this legislation and what he actually said about the continental margins program is very different to what the government has said. He actually recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: The public good nature of AGSO's programs and outputs be recognised, ie pre-competitive, of wide benefit and long term in nature.

This statement paints a very different picture from the government's rhetoric. From Dr Richard's viewpoint, the continental margins program is a public good. It is pre-competitive, of wide benefit and long term in nature.

PARA.TAB: Before now, the federal government has recognised the principle that research of genuine community benefit should be properly funded by government; basic research, fundamental research is the responsibility of government. Indeed, the federal government has repeatedly renewed its commitments in this regard since the 1989 science and technology statement. More recently, the government supported this principle in the response to the report of the Public Accounts Committee on public sector research.
In this regard, bodies such as the CSIRO will find it very difficult to make the crucial policy shift to 50 per cent industry funding for fundamental research programs. Let me

SPEECH.PARA: restate that. The continental margins program undertakes fundamental, pre-competitive research. It is therefore the responsibility of government. Suddenly the government needs funding, so it plucks a figure of external earnings of 50 per cent out of the air and applies it to industry. How does that make CSIRO and other publicly funded institutions feel? Well, I can tell honourable members that I have spoken to them and they are pretty scared. This is an extremely dangerous precedent because, if the government can apply a 50 per cent industry funding requirement on the fundamental work of the continental margins program, it can do it to any other publicly funded research institution. It flies in the face of the government's own support for appropriations to public good research. CSIRO, ANSTO, AIMS and other publicly funded research institutions are particularly concerned about environmental and natural resource related programs which find it very difficult and, in some cases, impossible to attract industry funding.

PARA.TAB: At this point, I want to comment on the matter of AGSO's external funding requirements as it relates to the detail of government plans for the continental margins program. Unfortunately, I must remind the House that I have got numerous questions on notice lying unanswered for seven months or more. The question I filed on 16 December had 32 parts to it and much of it related to the government's attitude to the continental margins program and the role of AGSO, so I can understand that the government would neatly and conveniently avoid answering that question on 16 December and wait for the legislation.

However, there is no excuse whatsoever for the government not answering my question filed on 21 October 1993, which had 24 parts to it. In it I tried to find out how AGSO is going to meet the 30 per cent external funding requirement imposed on it by government. What is its business plan? How is it going to structure its operations to be commercially attractive so as to convince industry, which takes a very hard-nosed view on these matters, to contribute 30 per cent to its funding? I must warn the minister that, if he wants the support of the opposition for organisations such as AGSO, he needs to take us somewhat more seriously. I have grave doubts that AGSO is in any position to restructure itself and to prepare itself to be industry relevant so as to attract 30 per cent of its funding. And to a large extent it has got my sympathy; it is no easy matter. As shadow minister for science and technology for four years, I saw a whole range of other research institutions grapple with this enormous problem of meeting the very high external funding requirement expected of them. But you must involve the opposition, Minister, so that we are confident that AGSO is making the attempt. I have seen examples over the 1980s where institutions dragged their heels in meeting these external funding targets.

There must be some degree of confusion within the government or within AGSO if it cannot answer for several months those questions relating to its external earnings program. I think this ill-conceived legislation is a direct result of that confusion. But it must not be allowed to set a precedent for future opportunist measures by this government. The petroleum and offshore minerals industry's needs from the government are quite simple. As resources projects take many years to mature, with most of the expense outlaid before income is received, governments should not change the rules at any point through a project for some short-term financial or political gain. Industry investors must have the confidence that the many years of initial expense will be paid for when the product produces income. The past actions of governments have an important effect on the perceptions of the industry and investors. The Labor Party might consider that the big resource controversies of past years like Coronation Hill are gone, but they are not forgotten. The three mines uranium policy will never be forgotten while it arbitrarily restricts jobs and export income.

In that vein, the legislation before the House will extract an extra $100,000 per year for the privilege of holding a retention licence and will make an investment in offshore petroleum or minerals less attractive. The government should not introduce an additional charge after the decision to invest in development and production has been made. Those oil investors who have waited through the long years and high risks of exploration and were rewarded with a successful strike are now enduring the development phase before production occurs, and they now find that, without warning, this new tax will absorb a further proportion of the long-awaited profit.

The imposition of this tax on top of existing charges leads inescapably to the conclusion that the government is determined to meet its budgetary requirements with an extra $10 million from the resources sector and it does not really care how this affects the petroleum industry. It is not as if the petroleum industry does not already pay its fair share of taxes. In addition to the usual company tax, fringe benefits tax and sales tax, the resources rent tax will cost the industry $1.3 billion this financial year. Additionally, petroleum products excise will produce a massive $9.7 billion for the government this financial year. The petroleum industry underpins our way of life in many diverse ways and provides an enormous contribution to government revenue. The government should be encouraging the industry, not imposing new taxes.

The effect of this legislation on the holders of retention leases is minor compared to the effect on petroleum exploration. This legislation will discourage exploration. The minister has personally assured me by way of a written explanation of the legislation in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The government does not believe this charge will constitute a significant impediment to offshore exploration.

Despite this the charges per permit for the petroleum industry will decrease as the charges on the minerals industry increase, as it begins to use the continental margins program data. So when the embryonic offshore minerals industry begins to utilise the continental margins program—not that it will choose to but it has no choice—and starts paying for exploration permits and licences and the like, so the petroleum industry's costs per permit and licence will come down.

PARA.TAB: What a great user charge that is. We have covered the user charge argument, but that is just another argument against how this cannot possibly be called a user charge. Moreover, this decrease in the petroleum industry's cost in the years to come as the offshore minerals industry takes off is proof that the government knows it is a disincentive. If it were not a disincentive to exploration and development, the government would keep the charge on. The government is in a hurry—it is very eager—to lessen the impact on the petroleum industry as the years go on by including the minerals industry as a contributor to the payment towards a continental margins program.

So the minister cannot claim, as he tries to, that the costs associated with the permits and licences are not a disincentive to exploration and development. A properly structured tax with a justifiable basis would not need to be phased out in a furtive manner. Of course, this raises the likelihood that the government will break its promise to reduce the tax for the petroleum industry and continue to unfairly tax an already burdened industry.

But we must take the minister and the government at its word. The government has said the petroleum industry will be paying less in the future, depending on to what extent the offshore minerals industry takes off, but it does worry people that it may not hold to that. Again, the minister has said that the more licences or the more permits, the less the amount that attaches to each of them. Wow! And that is a user charge? I do not think so.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the unit cost as well.

—I do not think that is a user charge at all. Given that an offshore exploration well costs up to $10 million, the cost of retaining the associated exploration permit will now be at least one per cent per year of the well cost. I genuinely am convinced that that will eat away at the opportunities for companies to drill further wells. It is a significant impost, particularly when only one in 12 wells drilled is successful. So this new tax will discourage the small companies which often prove up an area for later investment by the big players.

PARA.TAB: Australia must not become complacent about the self-sufficiency in oil we have enjoyed in the past. You cannot keep imposing costs and charges and taxation burdens on the petroleum and minerals industries without them making a commercial decision to reduce exploration investment or to go to another country which provides a more favourable incentives scheme.

Let no member of the House be under any illusion. This is a revenue grab; it is not a user charge. I believe that the minister must act very quickly to restore the worsening relations between the industry and AGSO. The minister can do that only by withdrawing this legislation and by acknowledging that it is detrimental to the national interest. The opposition strongly opposes the legislation and will continue to do so in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The old grab bag is out and all the cliches and all the non-information are starting to flow. The honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), apart from claiming that the charge on industry to support the continental margins program is a disincentive, during his speech made reference to the fact that Australia is one of the more attractive places to invest. There is no doubt that the 10 years of our government have helped Australia to become one of the more attractive places to invest.

PARA.TAB: This legislation is proposing a fee for a service. We are not saying that the information is not available. The seismic information is available to companies that might wish to explore off our shelf.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't want it.

—They might not want it but over recent years they have paid for it in increasing amounts, as I will explain later. They are prepared to pay for it because it provides a service that allows them to identify those areas most likely to yield a satisfactory result. I know what I am talking about because I worked as an exploration geologist for a mining company. When I was given a job to explore an area, I would visit the geological survey service and look at aerial photographs and geological maps so as to get a feel for the geological structure of the area and some idea of how I was going to tackle the exploration. It was an invaluable service.

PARA.TAB: We are saying to explorers, `Once you have had a look at the seismic information being provided by a government service, we want you to pay. We want you to contribute half the total cost of providing that service to the Australian community and to the Australian mining industry.' We are asking that $10 million a year be recovered.

TALK.START.PARA: —What if they don't want to look?

—I am quite happy to have a private conversation with the honourable member for Gippsland at any time. It is with pleasure that I support this legislation. It is a package which will enable the 1993-94 budget provisions to be implemented concerning the continental margins program conducted by the Australian Geological Survey Organisation. The continental margins program is an extremely important one, as the honourable member agrees. It is a very important element in Australia's strategy to encourage exploration for, and the development of, Australia's offshore petroleum and gas resources. Its primary objective is to increase the amount of exploration on Australia's continental shelf by providing pre-competitive geoseismic information and advice. The information it provides is aimed at improving perceptions of prospectivity and, ultimately, attracting exploration activity to Australian waters.

PARA.TAB: The program also will support government decision making on offshore petroleum and mineral exploration. It will sustain Australia's legal continental shelf claim and provide support for intergovernmental negotiations on the delineation of seabed boundaries. It provides an invaluable source of baseline data which can be used—and, indeed, is currently used—to assess environmental impacts and sensitivities in Australian marine environments.

Such an important program requires adequate funding, and that is what this legislation is all about. A necessary administrative adjunct to the legislation is to allow cancellation of titles for non-payment of user charges. In other words, if someone decides to take out a licence over an area and then proceeds not to pay the contribution the rights to it are forfeited—and so they should be.

The user charges announced in the 1993-94 budget followed the government decision that approximately half the cost—about $10 million—of the continental margins program should be funded by the offshore petroleum and minerals industries. Funds from these industries will be raised through an annual charge placed on the holders of Commonwealth offshore petroleum and mineral exploration permits and licences and retention leases or licences. That is the proper way it should go: revenue raised should go back into research. I am not suggesting that this is the only level of research that will be carried out in future. Surely it is in the interests of exploration that the government be allowed to upgrade the services that it provides. One of the differences between the present government and previous governments of Australia is that we are looking to the future. At this stage, the activities of the continental margins programs are concerned with petroleum rather than minerals and therefore the user charge on minerals exploration and retention licences will be set at zero.

This legislation has come about because the government wanted to respond to the 1993 Richards review of the Australian Geological Survey Organisation. The Richards review was very thorough. It was an independent report on the operations of the Australian Geological Survey Organisation. Its recommendations have been very carefully considered by the government, and special consideration was given to the recommendation that the geoscientific work undertaken by AGSO should be funded by government and that funding in 1996-97 should be increased. In this way the continental margins program can continue to improve the organisation's responsiveness and accountability in serving both national and industry needs. An additional 30 per cent external funding target, exclusive of the user charge, was set for AGSO's geoscientific services to ensure that these are provided. There is also a need for an extra $1.5 million per annum for the national mapping accord to enhance the pace of its implementation so that there can be an added incentive to encourage greater state participation.

Let us go to one of the points that the opposition continues to make: industry does not want to purchase this information. Why would industry want to purchase the information if it is being given free? I would like honourable members opposite to identify a single user-pays charge—or tax, as they insist on calling this charge—that is friendly. I would like them to identify one single tax that they pay willingly. They know they cannot. There is no such thing; it has never been devised.

Although the amounts paid by petroleum explorers and producers in Australia to the Australian government are large, I do not notice any of those companies wishing to reduce their charges. I wonder whether the next speaker is going to identify how much BHP paid to go to South Vietnam for a right to explore in the ocean there and what was the deal done with the Vietnamese government if BHP is successful in discovering petroleum there. I wonder how it compares with the user-pays charges that this legislation is introducing.

In the order of $2.5 million was paid for AGSO's services in 1992-93 and $2 million so far in the first half of 1993-94. From 1987 to the end of 1993, sales have totalled $5.8 million. That is as exploration is increasing.

I have great pleasure in supporting this legislation. It is a worthwhile program and a commonsense program. Obviously, the more information we have, the better equipped we are to care for the environment, and the information we can offer explorers is more worthwhile and valuable. I would like to point out that the amendment that allows the cancellation of titles if companies do not pay the charges within three months is consistent with existing provisions allowing cancellation for non-payment of other fees.
I commend this bill to honourable members. It is sensible. It puts in place the means by which the excellent functions of AGSO can be continued and, indeed, expanded.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Paterson (Mr Horne) has made enough remarks to guarantee my spending 20 minutes discussing just them. I will start with some of his opening remarks. He referred to a group of cliches and grab bags. I wish the honourable member were entitled to a supplementary response. If he were, he might tell us what relevance they have to an argument about how the government should levy a tax or charge against the oil industry for providing a service.

PARA.TAB: There is no conflict on the issue of user pays. The honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), the shadow spokesman, did not put up an argument that the oil industry should necessarily pay nothing. It is a pity that the honourable member for Paterson has to leave, because I will make some other remarks about the things he had to say. I have certainly warned him of that.

The opposition and industry are saying in the first instance that if there is to be a charge, let it be, firstly, for a worthwhile service, secondly, for that component of the service for which the purchaser sees value and, thirdly, one which the purchaser can afford. This is our great problem with this government's move to the implementation of the user pays principle. Had the honourable member for Paterson stayed, I am sure he would be reminded of our participation in the subject of the quarantine services. For years, industry got a service for nothing and did not give a damn about its efficiency or any aspect of it until the government commenced collecting 100 per cent or thereabouts of its cost. Suddenly, industry became very interested.

I remind the House that when it was still arguing about the effectiveness of industry in the meat substitution royal commission I gave evidence pointing out then and there that it was the responsibility of government not to provide the service with whatever inefficiencies that government usually manages to create but to supervise the service in this instance and let the charge be directly applicable to the consumer; in this case, it was the meatworks. I do not want to spend too long on what might seem an irrelevant aspect of this debate.

In this other debate, the honourable member for Paterson was representing himself as a cattle breeder; he probably is. Today he is representing himself as a one-time geologist; he probably was. When he is defeated at the next election, I do not know which job he will go back to, but in each case he has a problem, because people want to charge him more than they used to for services that his industry gained some benefit from.

The honourable member for Gippsland was not saying that there is not necessarily an available benefit in these services. We are saying that the means by which the government has chosen to apply the charge is, to put it in the simplest terms, silly and not very smart.

Another area where I find myself having an interest—I have had to write on this very matter—is the International Wool Secretariat. Quite properly, having created a huge asset in the woolmark, it has said to those who get value from putting it on their clothing—it is on my suit—that they should pay something for it. That is a good idea. But just as this legislation provides, it has proposed a flat fee of $7,000.

In other words, some poor little backyard operator trying to produce a product and promote this expansion that the government is so desperate for the business sector to provide in order to save it has to come up with a fee of $7,000 in the case of the woolmark. That is a huge sum of money for some very small operator to get the right to put the woolmark on a product. Because of the efforts of the IWS, people in many foreign countries just will not buy woollen products without it. When those opposite re-enter the debate, that point will prove pretty handy for me. I reckon that I am doing pretty well here on my own.

The reality is that, with the licensing system in the wool industry, the same thing has been done here—a flat fee has been applied. The biggest Italian suit maker in the world will pay $7,000, the smallest—and, of course, this is probably a fair comparison—Australian company trying to develop a niche market in wool will also pay $7,000. I have written to the IWS and said that the idea sounds silly, and I hope that it is changed. The charge should somehow reflect the size of the operation and presumably the magnitude of the service.

Firstly, to say that the amount in this instance will be $10 million and will be divided by the number of tenement holders at this point in time is silly. It should not be done that way. Secondly, government today recognises its role. It decided, because of an accident of history—originally government saw its role quite differently—that if we ever wanted one oil well in Australia it would go out and survey land from time to time with whatever technology was available and provide the sorts of survey maps that the honourable member for Paterson referred to. I well remember when we had no wells and I well remember when we had the first one that looked like being something at Rough Range near Carnarvon, where I live, and the great excitement associated with it. The government thought that, having done so, maybe someone would come along with the then tens or hundreds of millions of dollars needed and be encouraged to look a bit further. That was what the government set out to do.

Things have changed over time for many reasons. We are now recognised as a highly prospective area of the world in terms of any form of minerals. So prospecting companies come knocking at our door. Government has hung in there basically now as a business. It has a status in business that I would dearly love to have. It can stand in this place and tell people how much it will pay. It tells them that they will have to pay whether they want the service or not. That is the fundamental objection of the opposition.

The government can hang out its shingle as a supplier of survey maps if industry comes to its door. It was interesting because the honourable member for Paterson said, `It's a great help to me. I'm a geologist. I can go in and see all this for nothing.' But under this proposal he is still going to see it for nothing. If he is as lucky as the American geologist that discovered oil in Bass Strait and got a massive royalty payment out of it, he would still be out of it. He had a company which Holmes a Court ended up with and an income stream paid for by the Western Australian taxpayers. But let us put that aside.

TALK.START.PARA: —Weeks?

—Yes, Weeks's petroleum. That to me is silly too. According to honourable member for Paterson, the clear beneficiary of the service is in fact the geologist. He is able to go in there and get all this for nothing and will still be able to get it for nothing, while somebody else out there, such as a tenement holder, who is in a different situation, has to pay the bill at a flat rate. When the honourable member for Paterson leaves this place and goes back into geology, why should he not have to pay?

PARA.TAB: The first test is then the value of the government service. We will see how many people come and knock at the door. There is nothing wrong with that. If the government were to tear this bill up and come back into the House and say, `From here on we will charge,' I imagine the fee the honourable member for Paterson mentioned might be $10,000. Why not? He will make up his mind whether he needs it or not. Of course that is fair and reasonable.

More importantly, we have to spread this fee so that it is in some way applicable to the value of the tenement. I have mentioned Bass Strait. I do not think anybody was too keen on having some tenements in Bass Strait until Mr Weeks, an American geologist, came along and said to Esso and BHP, `If I were you I would go down there and look.' A lot of these tenements are pretty risky. People sit on them, and they just might become the greatest source of product of all. But we are now going to impose another charge which is not relevant to the prospectivity of the area; it will drive people off these tenements. The suggestion is that there is a massive queue waiting behind them to take their place. Well, at an extra hundred grand a year, I am not sure there is. Those tenements might be abandoned and become a desert of productivity—not very smart.

The honourable member for Paterson suddenly threw in the fact that there is another role—protection of the environment. That is a highly beneficial role, but it is not the role of the tenement holder. That is the role of government in the public interest, so let the public pay. If we are talking about protection of the environment and all the other peripheral issues, let the government pay; let the people pay. That is a proper and important role. But we are not talking about doing that; we are talking about dividing into $10 million a certain number of tenements and making them all pay the same. That is silly.

I do not think the Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall) should try to find some rhetoric to refute such a logical argument. He should say, `Fellas, you're right. Thanks for the advice. We'll go and have a look at it again.' A piece of legislation can be brought back into this place which is user pays and which reflects the prospectivity or the productivity of the tenement and which, better still, reflects the value of the product, the service provided and the charges that will be levied. I think that is simple. I had a bit of a grin when the member for Paterson said, `They mightn't want it' and then paused before he said, `but they are going to get it.' That was a bit of humour. It is a pity he is not here. He is a nice guy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is he?

—He is, outside of his opinions and his understanding, but that is a bit of a problem on the other side of the House. We do not believe that the proposal is appropriate or sensible. Then the honourable member for Paterson—I have not been able to move further than the previous speaker yet—challenged us to tell him what BHP might have paid to Vietnam for the opportunity to go up there. He did not remind us that that is where BHP is going—Vietnam and China. Of course it would have paid to go there. The simple fact is that it also pays for the privilege of mining oil or other minerals in Australia. It pays royalties. It pays permit fee licences. Sometimes these permits are tendered for. I assume that includes some payment for the privilege. That is set in many ways. The simple fact is that it was totally illogical to compare this proposal with what BHP does in deals in other parts of the world.

PARA.TAB: Simply put, there are a number of charges. The honourable member for Gippsland identified the $1.3 billion appearing in yesterday's budget by way of the resource rent tax. There are numerous taxes. We are talking today about charging for a particular service—an exploration service. We are not saying the government need not provide it; we are not saying the government need not charge for it. We are saying that the methods it has identified are not appropriate in each case.

I think it is very important that we look at the public interest in this case—and certainly the future of this government considering the `gamble' of yesterday's budget. Every major daily this morning has in its headlines in relation to the budget the word `gamble'. We thought the previous Prime Minister was the gambler—Victab and all those sorts of things—but here we are now with a government labelled as a punter; a punter on the future of our kids. If I were of the government and read those words `gamble, gamble, gamble', I would be hugely embarrassed.

If the public interest is supposed to be a serious matter and if resource, investment, development and expansion are the nub of yesterday's budget, why would we be doing anything that might chase some of that investment away? Everywhere we turn and everywhere we look, having pleaded for it, we find ourselves imposing extra financial hurdles on this investment. This legislation is a classic example: it is another charge. It is all right for the minister to quote his statistics and say that the mining industry is here to stay and percentage-wise they are still only going overseas to the same percentage. He, if he has been knocking on doors, knows differently.

The simple fact is that the mining industry is getting very disillusioned about all these things. It is getting disillusioned about a lot of other factors relative to mining in Australia. The uncertainty of Mabo: if we take the black and white issues out of it, there is grave uncertainty and there are grave questions over the federal legislation as to how long it might take to get approvals through. People are saying to us, `We think it's easier to go overseas.' There is good reason, too. Other parts of the world are becoming a lot more attractive—politically, culturally and economically—places we would not dream of going to for fear of being shot up and imprisoned where we were just told, `Don't come, you're free enterprise and we're communist.' All that is changing. Australia has to be aware of that when the government comes in with proposals of this nature that just might be the final political straw that breaks the exploration or investment camel's back. I think that is very important and, again, good reason for the opposition to stand here and oppose this legislation.

Finally, where does it all end up if there is a successful discovery and more oil is produced? Is the explorer going to say, `Well, I'm a genuine, compassionate person, I'm going to charge this much for my product; I'm not going to worry about the fact that the federal government has just loaded 100 grand on me'? Or is the explorer going to pass that 100 grand off? Is it going to go into the cost structure of the entire chain right down to the fuel bowser where, of course, the budget is collecting another $1 billion this year also? Of course it will. That is another reason why the opposition thinks that this proposal should not proceed. It is a cost of that nature. But, if it were just a cost for a service, business would make its own decisions. It would decide on the value of it, and it would choose to use such information that would save it money by doing the same work itself. That is the difference.

I think that primarily covers the issue as the coalition sees it. We do not think the proposal is appropriate in its delivery, but we do not generally oppose the concept of user pays. It is a pity that the government, in so many other areas where it is putting this user-pays component on, does not remain or continue to remain the sole provider of the service. That is the problem. There is no competition in AQIS. Government should right the rules. It should, through AQIS, license providers who could be competitive in the marketplace instead of having one charge of this nature. I completely support the argument put forward by the shadow minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—The shadow minister, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), raised the issue of a couple of questions he had on the Notice Paper prior to my becoming the minister. I will investigate today why they were not answered. I am not aware of them, particularly the one in October.

PARA.TAB: I listened with great interest to the shadow minister. I thought his weakest argument was in relation to the issue of retention leases. As he would be well aware, once you have your exploration lease—once you find something that may not be viable at that time and take out a retention lease because you think that some time down the track that resource you have found will be viable—that precludes anybody else from looking in that particular lease area. The strongest argument for a charge lies in a retention lease.

The other point that the shadow minister made was that the charge was not valid because the more people looking, the cheaper the charge. I would have thought that was exactly the opposite in reality. Have a look at, say, the classic example in a free enterprise society of the model T Ford: the more that were made, the cheaper they got. There is an infrastructure cost of $20 million for a seismic vessel to operate—so the more people that take up leases, the cheaper the charge. I think that is a benefit.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a benefit; it's not a user charge.

—It is a charge. The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) made a point about the wool market, and I totally agree with him on that. I think he made a very sensible analogy, but it is not relevant here because what you are paying for here is not one person getting a lot of leases and paying $100,000, nor is it one person getting one lease and paying $100,000—everybody pays the same fee. I thank the honourable member for Paterson (Mr Horne) for his contribution, and I will add no further to the debate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
