TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being past 3.00 p.m., the proceedings are interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The proceedings may be resumed at a later hour.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. Given that the green paper says on page 52 that we need 4.75 per cent growth in each year between now and the end of the decade to get an unemployment rate of five per cent, and given that your own forecasts for the next several years predict growth of 4.5, 4.25, four and four per cent, does this not say that even by your own optimistic growth forecasts you will go nowhere near creating two million jobs, nowhere near achieving a five per cent unemployment rate, by the end of the decade?

—The objective of a five per cent unemployment rate by the end of the century is certainly a worthy one and one which the government will strive to obtain. As has been made clear already, what exact numbers one needs to get to that level will depend on various factors which are outside the government's control, for instance things like the increase in the participation rate, a factor which is determined by the behaviour of individuals, by their indicating their desire to get into the work force in an increasing way.

PARA.TAB: One of the social revolutions of our time is the increase in the participation rate, particularly by married women. That process can be expected to go on. In addition to that, there can be other inducements for people to move into the work force, particularly if real wages are increasing. So how fast the participation rate will increase is something which we will have to see over time.

One can make assessments about what is a low level and a high level and a reasonable set of assumptions about what that might be. I think we would probably need something in the order of 170,000 jobs a year just to keep unemployment where it is. So that means we have to create considerable amounts of employment each year—over 170,000—to start knocking back unemployment levels. That is a basic fact of economic life which we have to address. In the last 12 months, we were very successful in doing that with 230,000 jobs and, consequently, a reduction in the unemployment rate.

Through the 1980s, we were very successful in increasing employment by over three per cent per annum. In fact, it increased by some 26 per cent in the period from 1983 to 1990 and gave us 1.7 million jobs in that seven-year period. The Leader of the Opposition is saying that that sort of thing cannot be done again. That is just being utterly pessimistic about the future—a sort of no hope proposition. He thinks there is no point in our trying to set an objective of five per cent unemployment, because it is unobtainable. It is obtainable, but obviously it requires a lot of things to go right for us. In particular it means that we have to have a high, sustained economic and employment growth for the rest of the decade, as we had through the 1980s.

Given that our fundamentals are much better now, inflation rates are lower, interest rates are lower, profit share is high, productivity is higher, wages are being set on a productivity determined basis, international competitiveness is much better, all of these factors provide a much sounder basis for growth than we had in the 1980s. So there is no reason to be pessimistic about our prospects for getting that kind of growth again and getting unemployment down to around the five per cent level by the end of the century.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. In light of the intense public interest in the budget forecast of an increase in business investment of 14.5 per cent, can the Treasurer provide the House with information which would assist in understanding the robustness of the forecast? Further, can the minister advise the House of the business community's reaction to the budget and the prospects for investment?

PARA.TAB: Mr Richard Evans interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Cowan was not asked to comment.

—In the wake of the budget forecast, there has been some focus on the 14 1/2 per cent growth in business investment. That compares with an expected one per cent growth in 1993-94. The comparison is leading people to say, `This is a very sharp turnaround and, therefore, a bit unbelievable.' Let me just take the House back through history as to what happened in the 1980s. Over the 1980s, we had business investment at a peak growth rate of 17 per cent in one year. It bottomed at a negative growth rate of almost 13 per cent. So it is obviously a very volatile economic factor.

PARA.TAB: In 1979-80 business investment fell by three per cent. In the next year, it rose by 17 per cent. So we had a dramatic turnaround. In 1982-83 and 1983-84, business investment fell but bounced back by 14.9 per cent in 1984-85. In the last few years, we have seen investment fall by 25 per cent with the onset of the recession in 1991-92. It grew at around one per cent last year, and in the current year—1993-94—a bounce back in the order of 14 per cent would not be out of line with the kind of movement that we have seen in previous economic periods. So this is not something that is out of the blue or unusual or something that has not happened before. It is very much on a par with the kinds of bounce backs that we have seen from business investment after slack periods in our recent economic history.

At the moment, other forecasters are saying that that is a reasonable estimate. BT Australia's forecast for investment growth is 15.6 per cent. The National Australia Bank says 15 per cent and CS First Boston says 14 per cent. So these are private sector forecasters saying that they expect business investment to pick up strongly in the forthcoming year. There are very good reasons for that to happen.

The good reasons are these: we have seen corporate profitability improve quite considerably in recent times. The corporate profit share is now 17.7 per cent of GDP, which is the highest profit share since September 1985. We have low inflation and low inflation expectations, so inflation is likely to remain low. The balance sheet restructuring period for businesses seems to be over. Our competitiveness internationally has increased by 20 per cent over the last two years.

We have growth in domestic demand, with little growth in the capital stock in recent years, which is leading to a rapid return to more normal levels of capital utilisation. Clearly, in the central business district property area, there is an overhang which is rather larger than that for plant and equipment. That will take a bit longer to turn around. In plant and equipment we are seeing capacity utilisation increase very rapidly. We have high business confidence, which is obviously important for investment. The surveys on that show that business confidence now is at its highest level for five years and that in the manufacturing industry it is the highest for 30 years.

Also there are very substantial tax inducements to investment. Some people have been saying that the government should have done more in this budget to give industry an incentive to invest. Look at what has happened in recent times. In the One Nation package there were accelerated depreciation, the development allowance, the 150 per cent write-off for research and development, the general investment allowance and the cut in the corporate tax rate from 39 to 33 per cent.

This is a $3 billion list of incentives to businesses to invest. Clearly there is a very substantial tax incentive to do so, especially given the fact that the investment allowance requires those who would seek to take some benefit from it to have their investment in place by the end of the year 1994-95. In other words, if they want to utilise that extra 10 per cent write-off, they have to get their investments up by the end of 1994-95. That is a powerful inducement to investment in the forthcoming financial year. For all of those reasons, I believe that the 14 1/2 per cent forecast is well based. Clearly, it is an estimate and it is not absolutely written in concrete, but it is a sound estimate, in my view, and one which accords with historical precedents. There are a lot of good, very sound reasons as to why that forecast should come through.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is again directed to the Treasurer. I refer the Treasurer to an assurance that he gave this House on 10 May 1993 that the government did not intend to increase the overall burden of taxation. I also refer the Treasurer to the fact that according to the budget papers tax as a share of GDP has increased from 21.9 in 1993-94 to 22.5 in 1994-95 to 23 per cent in 1995-96. Will the Treasurer confirm that he has broken yet another promise to the Australian people?

—There is no broken promise and there are no tax increases in this budget, much to the chagrin of the opposition, whose whole preparation for this budget was on the basis that it was going to be a tax and spend budget. In fact, last night, following a budget with no tax increases, the shadow treasurer said to the nation that this was a tax and spend budget. What a ludicrous statement—there are no tax increases but this is a tax and spend budget! You just could not change your rhetoric in time to fit in with the budget.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition should know something about the cyclical movement in the taxation share of GDP. He knows—he should know, anyway, unless he has forgotten all his economics—that, as the economic cycle picks up and employment picks up and there is an increase in real incomes, we see tax becoming a slightly higher share of GDP. There is nothing wrong with that. People are not paying higher tax rates. It simply means that with a more buoyant economy we see that there is more tax revenue, particularly through employment. That gives us some pick-up in the tax proportion of GDP.

There is nothing unusual about it; it happens in every economic cycle. It is not surprising that our figures show that. It is a product of the strength of the recovery, not a product of this budget imposing a great burden of taxation on the Australian people. You know that to be a fact. Mr Speaker, it is a nonsense proposition. The fact is that tax, as a proportion of GDP, will remain well below the level of the 1980s and there will be no increase in the overall burden of taxation compared with what it was at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Is the minister aware of criticism that the government's deficit reduction program as outlined in the budget papers does not go far enough and that it is largely achieved through asset sales? How does the government's program compare with those of other countries and to what extent is it actually dependent on the proceeds of asset sales?

—The government has not only confirmed its commitment to the deficit reduction target, it has also exceeded it. The deficit in 1994-95 will be $11.7 billion, or 2.5 per cent of GDP. That is down from $13.6 billion, or 3.2 per cent, last year. It will fall to only 0.9 per cent of GDP in 1996-97, and 0.4 per cent in 1997-98.

PARA.TAB: This has been achieved while accommodating something like $3 billion worth of decreases in business taxes over the last couple of economic statements and a white paper at its maximum point of some $1.9 billion. It gives us, nevertheless, one of the tightest fiscal policies in the OECD. When our deficit will be less than one per cent, the US will be at 2.3; Canada, three; France, 2.5; and the United Kingdom, about two. Australia has one of the lowest ratios of government outlays to GDP in the OECD. Commonwealth outlays in 1994-95 will be reduced from 26.6 per cent of GDP to 26.2 per cent. This compares with 28.8 per cent when we came into office in 1982-83. If we were still spending at the rate of the previous coalition government, outlays would be some 2.6 per cent of GDP higher, or about $12 billion higher this year than they are in fact going to be.

There have been some comments about the use of asset sales to reduce the budget deficit. Government outlays as a proportion of GDP would have been reduced even without the income from asset sales. Overall outlays will fall from 26.6 per cent of GDP in 1993-94 to 24.9 per cent in 1996-97. Excluding asset sales, government outlays would still fall to 25.1 per cent of GDP. The asset sales program commenced in 1987-88 and proceeds have averaged less than one per cent of outlays over that period. In 1997-98, there will be virtually no impact from asset sales. Outlays will still fall further then to only 24.2 per cent of GDP, and the deficit to 0.4 per cent of GDP. If there were no asset sales in that year, outlays would still be at 24.2 per cent of GDP.

So, quite clearly, the deficit reduction target of the government is both on track and not dependent upon asset sales for its success. If we actually took anything from the opposition on this point, we would basically operate on this basis: unless our budget was in balance, we would have no asset sales. That is basically the proposition opposition members put forward: unless our budget was in balance, we would have no asset sales. Their argument is that it is illegitimate in the period in which we are incurring some level of debt to actually count asset sales against it. That is effectively the logic of the proposition the opposition has put forward. If that were the case, there would have been absolutely no asset sales under the previous Liberal government, because it only once managed to get itself into balance.

Of course, the asset sales program is related to a whole series of other policy considerations that have nothing to do with the issue of budget deficit. It has everything to do with increasing the competitiveness and the efficiency of the particular assets concerned, and it has everything to do with exiting the government's standing in the market when there is no need for it to be there any longer because the time of a natural monopoly may have passed or whatever. Asset sales, whilst essential for a variety of policy reasons, are not essential for achieving the government's task of a continual reduction in the size of outlays as a percentage of our gross domestic product.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is again directed to the Treasurer. Given that the company tax rate has been reduced by 15.4 per cent to 33c in the dollar and that the budget papers assume only a 13.25 per cent growth in company income, how does he explain the fact that company tax collection has increased by seven per cent instead of falling?

—My recollection is that a number of factors affect company tax, of which the increase in company profits is one. I cannot exactly recall for the moment what exactly the rest of the factors are, but they are explained in the budget papers. I will get the Leader of the Opposition an answer subsequently.
—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. What is Australia's situation in relation to public debt? How do we compare with other industrial countries?
—What about Asia?
—If you listen, you will get a good answer.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! We would certainly hope that that is the case.
—I am simply expressing confidence in the Treasurer.
—Get to your question.
—Is this position one of the reasons underlying the budget strategy?

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my left! There is an opportunity coming shortly on a matter of public importance in the name of the honourable member for Mayo to debate a number of these issues. I suggest that those who are to participate in it keep their interjections.
—Are we allowed to laugh?
—It depends on what you are laughing at. The Treasurer has the call.

—In answer to the honourable member for Fraser, I can say that Australia's public debt as a proportion of GDP is quite low compared with that of virtually any other industrial country. This is a relevant factor when considering the increase in debt that comes with the deficits that we have had to run in the aftermath of the recession.
—You have got the answer to this question already. It is written down for you.
—The honourable member for Sturt!

—In the period leading up to the recession, we had budget surpluses that turned around with the recession, and properly so. Those deficits protected us from having a severe slump. We went into recession, but not too deeply—nowhere near as deeply as we would have had we not had the deficit increases that we had and the turnaround in the budget balance.

PARA.TAB: That has some impact on public debt. It has been said that that therefore creates a problem for Australia. Certainly it increases the public debt interest, but it is also relevant to get these things in perspective. The fact is that we have a gross debt for 1994 that is, on Treasury estimates, 29 per cent of GDP. That compares to the average for OECD countries of 68 1/2 per cent. So no other country in the OECD list for which figures are available has a lower gross public debt as a proportion of GDP than Australia. That is certainly a highly relevant factor to bear in mind and to get this debt increase in proportion.

We are concerned to see that debt contained as much as possible. The deficit reduction program is about reducing the deficit responsibly. Our deficit reduction program is one which fits well compared with other countries. If we look at the deficit reduction programs of other countries which have announced such a program—that is, the United States, Germany, France, Italy, the United Kingdom and Canada—we will see that our deficit reduction program is certainly a commendable one. From 1993, the United States deficit has been moving from four per cent to 2.3 per cent, which is its target for 1998, so there is not a great deal of reduction there. The others are as follows: Germany, 2.2 per cent to one per cent by 1997; France, 4.7 per cent to 2.5 per cent by 1997; Italy—

TALK.START.PARA: —Wake up Knotty.
—I warn the member for Sturt.

—Italy will move from 9.7 per cent to 5.8 per cent by 1996; the United Kingdom will move down from 7.8 per cent to 1.5 per cent by 1997-98; and Canada will move from 6.4 per cent to three per cent by 1996-97. None of them go below one per cent, which is our target, and certainly the rate of reduction, apart from the United Kingdom, is less than ours.

PARA.TAB: This shows that Australia's deficit reduction program is a rigorous one. This budget produces a more accelerated deficit reduction program. It gets the deficit down to less than one per cent of GDP by 1996-97. In terms of getting our debt down as quickly as we responsibly can, we are doing better than any of these major industrial countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Treasurer. I refer the Treasurer to his claim in the budget speech last night that `we have not increased general taxation'. Can the Treasurer confirm that on 1 August this year the fuel excise on unleaded petrol will increase by 1c a litre and by 2c a litre on leaded petrol? Can the Treasurer confirm that the tax on wine will increase—

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my right!
—You do not like to hear this, do you? You would like to forget about it. You are not going to be allowed to forget about it.
—The honourable member for Mayo will get to his question.

—Can the Treasurer confirm that the tax on wine will increase on 1 July by two per cent? Can the Treasurer confirm also that tobacco excise will increase by five per cent on 1 August and by five per cent again on 1 February next year? Why did the Treasurer last night try to deceive Australians into believing that taxes will not rise this year?

—What I said was that there are no tax increases in this budget, and there are not. That statement is absolutely true. This budget imposes no new tax increases. The only revenue increases relate to the strictly cost recovery areas. The tax measures referred to by the honourable member for Mayo, as everyone in this House knows, were the subject of great discussion last year following last year's budget. They were part of last year's budget, not this year's budget. So the statement in the budget is absolutely correct.
—This question is about a tax reduction. Can the Minister for Transport inform the House of the impact the reduction in oil fuel excise will have on Australian coastal shipping?

—No-one will be happier than the honourable member for Throsby, that great enthusiast for Australian shipping, to know that the reduction in fuel excise announced by my colleague the Treasurer last night will save Australia's coastal shipping fleet $8.5 million per annum. Effective from today, fuel excise has of course been reduced by 2c per litre. The customers of our coastal shipping will receive the benefits of that measure. I draw to the House's attention—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The minister might wait just for a moment. I draw the House's attention to standing order 55. The minister is entitled to be heard in silence.

—Already today we have had the warm congratulations of the Australian Mining Industry Council, which has said that this decision will be of great benefit to coastal shipping as well as to the mineral processing industry. On my way down to question time today I received this laudatory press release from the Australian National Maritime Association, congratulating the government in the clearest of terms.

PARA.TAB: The government has already achieved some far-reaching reforms to the Australian maritime industry. That has been estimated as saving each ship approximately $200,000 per annum. That is in our reform process today. Last night's decision will protect these savings, and it will go a long way to encouraging further reform.

I can also tell the House that the annual $2 million subsidy agreed to by the Prime Minister last year to compensate Tasmanian industry and the passengers on the TT-Line for the increased cost of passenger and freight shipping attributable to last year's increase in excise will remain. In other words, the $2 million subsidy will continue; it will not be affected by this decision. That means that Tasmanian industry, Tasmanian consumers and the tourism industry in Tasmania will benefit a very great deal indeed. In conclusion, I acknowledge the particularly effective representation of my Tasmanian government colleagues who can rightly claim all of the credit for engineering this decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Treasurer. I refer the Treasurer to the Prime Minister's pre-election promise of 4 March 1993 on the 7.30 Report when the Prime Minister said, `We will return to taxpayers the impact of inflation, even low inflation, on the tax system.' I remind the Treasurer that, using the budget papers, it is estimated that there will be between $4 billion and $6 billion in bracket creep grabbed from taxpayers over the next four years. Will the Treasurer now admit that the Prime Minister's promise is dead and buried?

—Certainly taxpayers are currently enjoying tax cuts which have come in sooner than was promised at the last election. So as far as fulfilling promises about income taxes go, since November last year the people of Australia have been enjoying a tax cut which they were originally promised would not come in until July this year. They have certainly got that income tax cut in the bank. The second leg of the tax cuts has been deferred, as was stated last year, until consideration in 1998. As we approach that time, we will decide exactly when they will come in.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the point raised in the question about fiscal drag, we have low inflation; the honourable member for Mayo may not have noticed that. It is not like the period during which the coalition was in office when we had double digit inflation rates. We have an inflation rate of 2 per cent. With low inflation, we do not get much in the way of fiscal drag at all. So I am not sure where the $4 billion to $6 billion figure comes from. There will be some fiscal drag with low inflation, but it will be an awful lot less than that which occurred under the coalition government with its high rates of inflation. When the second leg of the tax cuts is brought in, that will more than fully compensate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, relating to wartime merchant mariners from World War II, is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Does the minister recall the petition I presented to this House on 18 November last year on behalf of 13,500 Australian citizens seeking access for wartime merchant mariners to the same entitlements as veterans of Australia's defence forces? Is he aware that the petitions were supported by members from both sides of this House? In congratulating the government on granting the terms of the petition and recognising the sacrifices made by Australia's wartime merchant mariners, I ask: what information is the minister able to provide to honourable members on the procedures to be followed by mariners in gaining access to these new entitlements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sciacca The Hon C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Shortland for his question. More importantly, on behalf of the thousands of Australian merchant mariners who served during World War II, I thank the honourable member for leading the charge on this issue and hanging on with the tenaciousness of a bulldog. I suppose that has something to do with his Greek heritage. I recall the honourable member presenting petitions to the House last year; I do not know whether there were 13,500 petitions, but there were 13,500 names on them, I am sure. I recall the concluding remarks of the honourable member's speech on that occasion when he said:

ANSWER.PARA: I appeal to the government, the cabinet and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to right this wrong and to bring forward legislation to repeal the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act of 1940 and to give wartime mariners the same entitlements available to former defence personnel under the Veterans' Entitlements Act of 1986.

Today I am pleased to say that the government, the cabinet and the Prime Minister have all listened to the appeal of the honourable member for Shortland and that, from 1 July 1994, the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act and associated statutory regulations will be repealed. Mariners who were eligible under that act will become eligible under the Veterans' Entitlements Act.

PARA.TAB: In the past, I understand that a person virtually had to be on the top of the deck of a ship and be hit by direct enemy action to be able to get anything. This is an initiative which I am sure will please honourable members on both sides of the House. I am sure we all have had a lot of representations.

I am informed that some 54 merchant ships were attacked in Australian waters during World War II, with some 38 of them going to the bottom of the sea. While not serving in uniform, these Australian wartime mariners were alike in other ways to our Defence Force personnel. To use the words of the honourable member for Shortland, they bled the same, they died the same, and they survived the same. Today we are going to treat them the same as all other veterans who fought in the Second World War. I do not know what the honourable member for Bennelong sees as funny about this.

TALK.START.PARA: —We were talking about something entirely different.

—I am sorry, my apology. As from 1 July this year, wartime mariners will be given access to the same benefits under the Veterans' Entitlements Act as are given to those who served in the armed forces. Eligible Australian mariners will now be able to claim for the long-term effects of their service, such as cardiac and respiratory diseases, which had very little chance under the old act of getting up.

PARA.TAB: I urge all honourable members to tell all the Australian wartime mariners who live in their electorates that, while they may have been refused a pension claim in the past, they should now apply again because they are now no longer perhaps precluded as a result of the Veterans' Entitlements Act giving them more chances for eligibility. These people should contact their local DVA office for inquiries and assistance.

In conclusion, thanks to the input of the McGirr inquiry of 1989, recommendations from the Baume committee report released by myself last Monday, the tireless efforts of the honourable member for Shortland and those other honourable members and organisations who rallied around him at the time, equity at last has been achieved on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. I refer to the government's deception of the Australian people concerning the l-a-w law income tax promise by the Prime Minister before the last election. Does the Treasurer really think that anyone still believes that he will deliver on the second round; or will he acknowledge, as Bankers Trust believes and has acknowledged, that `the second tranche will be delivered in the year that England wins back the Ashes'?

—Is that your best effort? I do not know what authority BT has to speak on this issue. It can make forecasts, that is fine; that is something that it can quite legitimately do. It certainly cannot speak for the government as to when tax cuts will be brought in. That is a matter for us to decide, not BT. So I do not see the point of quoting BT on this issue. I have already stated the position in relation to the second leg of the tax cuts. Quite clearly, last year, as part of the deficit reduction program, when the government undertook a number of measures to ensure that we would have a deficit reduction program that got us to around one per cent of GDP by 1996-97, the second leg of the tax cuts were postponed. That is absolute history, and we all recall that that happened. It was said at the time that they would be deferred for consideration not before 1998. That remains the position. As we move closer to that time, we will decide exactly when they come in. But they have been deferred, not abandoned.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Is the minister aware of alternative income proposals for unemployed people to those adopted by the government in last week's white paper? How have the government's income proposals been received by Australia's unemployed? Will the government adopt any of those alternative proposals?

—I thank the honourable member for Chifley for his question. The basic thrust of the government's reform of social security income support payments for the unemployed is to try to achieve a situation where people on unemployment payments, whether they are single, part of a couple, whether or not they have children, invariably benefit by raising their work effort—whether the opportunity is to take up further part-time work or to take up a full-time job.

PARA.TAB: As part of that, the government is bringing in the parenting allowance of up to $133 a week. That allowance will have the effect of overcoming an existing impediment to couples with children taking up work where they are both unemployed and the offer emerges of a low paid full-time job. Under existing arrangements, quite often such a family can actually be worse off as a consequence of one member of the family taking up a low paid full-time job with the other member of the couple staying home to care for the children.

So this is a major reform which overcomes that poverty trap and also makes more real the existence of a choice for low income families as to whether both want to take up full-time work or whether they prefer a situation where one is engaged in full-time parenting.

I talked about these new measures on Monday in answer to a question about this matter. But in response the honourable member for Bennelong that day put out a press release referring to income splitting. I was contrasting the effect of our changes with income splitting. In his press release he said, `The new parenting allowance delivers substantially the same benefit to low income single-income families as would income splitting.' This statement is outrageously untrue.

Let us take a specific example, a single-income family on not much above the lowest full-time award wage, say $300 a week. Under income splitting this family would lose $3.75 a week. That family under our provisions will receive over $84 per week in parenting allowance, which is $57 a week more than the with child dependent spouse rebate; in other words, $60 more than the honourable member for Bennelong would give them.

What we have tried to do with this change to the income support system is eliminate poverty traps and make sure, as I said at the outset, that families in those circumstances—a couple with dependent children, and one of the parents is offered a full-time job prospect—are better off by taking up that work. The parenting allowance is the key instrument by which we achieve that objective. Not only would the coalition not do that if it adopted the honourable member for Bennelong's income splitting proposal; it would actually make that poverty trap worse. Whichever way we look at it, this is an outrageously inequitable proposition. It really exemplifies the lack of concern the opposition has for equity.

There are a number of other propositions rattling around in the opposition in relation to this area. One of them has been put forward by Senator Minchin. He says that we should combine all family payments, all child-care rebates, into one big lump and then divide it up and pay it to all families with children on a per child basis. What would that do to the low income family I talked about which got $300 a week, which had two children under 13 and which was living in private rental accommodation? Under our proposal that family would get $207 per week in family payments, rent assistance and parenting allowance. The Minchin proposal—which the honourable member for Bennelong commented on in a Herald article on 28 March and said was a reasonable option that should be considered—would involve a cut to that family of over $120 a week. Contrary to what the honourable member for Bennelong had to say, there is a vast difference between our proposals and their proposals both in terms of equity and in terms of work force incentives.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Does he concede it is dangerous and risky to ratchet up debt during recovery? Will this mean that the Commonwealth will be even more exposed in the next economic downturn than it was in the last one?

—You cannot walk outside this place, lift a rock and find anything other than a member of the opposition frontbench with a new spending proposal. You cannot do that; be it the member over there who reckons there ought to be $3 billion spent in regional affairs; be it the Deputy Leader of the National Party who comes in with a couple of hundred million; be it the South Australian member who used to be the opposition's industry spokesman, with another one there; be it the Leader of the Opposition with another $800 million to be spent on Aboriginal affairs; or be it any one of the others who are going around the place pretending to be warm and cuddly for the benefit of some constituency that they are advocating.

PARA.TAB: When we walked into this place before question time, there was a division. What was the division about? It was an opportunity that you saw to add about another $10 million to the budget deficit as you voted against a proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order on two counts. Firstly, the minister is not allowed to reflect on votes of the House, least of all on the same day. Secondly, and more importantly, under standing order 145 he is yet to come to the core of the question asked by the honourable member for Higgins and he should be directed to do so.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Will the Attorney-General outline the budget measures within his portfolio which confirm the government's commitment to social justice?

—Obviously, the main thrust of the government's program, both in the white paper and in the budget, related to employment and associated measures. But there were other important initiatives in the social justice field, some of which fall within the area for which the Minister for Justice and I have responsibility.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members will be aware of the government's changes to the family law system in this country which are under way. The major approach will hopefully allow couples to resolve differences they may have outside the formal court system, through the process of mediation. Over the last number of years, the Family Court has trialled successfully mediation programs within the court and throughout community organisations. The budget accepts the success of these initiatives, takes them off a trial basis, funds them on a permanent ongoing basis and allows modest increases for the expansion of the services beyond Melbourne and Sydney and ultimately into Brisbane and other registries. So Australia-wide mediation services will be available through the court. Also, an extra $3.1 million over four years will be allocated to community organisations.

There have been some important reforms in the area of human rights. The most important was the government's response to the Burdekin report on the human rights of Australians with mental illness. Honourable members will be familiar with the large funding commitment in that area. A smaller funding commitment also occurred in the area of disability discrimination. That legislation is new. The complaints are beginning to be processed by the commissioner in that area and there are additional resources to enable that to occur. There has been a modest increase in the provision of legal aid. I would have to say that it is not as much as I am sure the Minister for Justice and I would like, but at least it maintains the government's commitment in this important area.

There have been important reforms to the operation of the Australian Institute of Judicial Administration with respect to the way in which Australian judges operate in this country and the programs which they run. Also, importantly, the government is continuing with its Commonwealth courts building program which has seen new buildings in a number of capital cities over the last 10 years.

The Melbourne court building has also now been given the go-ahead. Planning will start on that in regard to detailed design, with the actual construction in a few years time. This will allow the citizens of Melbourne to have access to a custom designed court building sympathetic to the needs of Australian citizens, the ultimate users, which the justice system operates for. It will also allow the court to operate in appropriate and dignified circumstances. All in all, these are some important reforms in the broader issue of access to justice for Australian citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The impact on Australians of the higher tax burden and broken promises outlined in the budget.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
