TALK.START.PARA: —The budget that was brought down last night by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) is a tax and spend budget. There are no ifs and buts about it: it is a tax and spend budget. This budget tells you one thing about the Labor Party in government: the government is pocketing the benefits of the recovery. Most Australians get nothing except a higher tax bill. They get no tax relief. They pay higher petrol taxes, they face longer hospital queues, they pay higher tobacco taxes; but they get nothing at all out of this budget. Just about every figure in this budget is rubbery, except for the tax increases. They are law, l-a-w, implemented in legislation that was passed at the end of last year.

PARA.TAB: It is also a budget which is absolutely full of forecasts which the Treasurer himself is not happy to stand by. At the Press Club today he was asked a question about his forecast for jobs growth. He was asked whether by the year 2000 unemployment would be reduced to five per cent and two million jobs would be created. This is the boast that ministers and members of the Labor Party are going around making but that the Treasurer, confronted with the press gallery, was not prepared to make. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: So it's difficult to be adamant that one is going to achieve forecasts like five per cent by the year 2000.

In other words, he is not prepared to endorse the forecast that unemployment will fall to five per cent by the year 2000. That figure is just a political mirage designed once more to deceive the Australian electorate.

PARA.TAB: Let us just have a look at the assertion that this budget is a tax and spend budget. That the Labor Party government throws money at any problem in society is well known to all Australians. Nobody would be surprised to hear that the budget is replete with administrative waste and that there is extravagance in terms of the increase in administrative costs of running the program.

The fact is that 1994-95 will be the year of the tax collector and the year when taxes right across the board increase—and increase very substantially. Let us look at some of the taxes that will increase during this coming year. First of all, let us look at the indirect taxes. The Treasurer said in his speech last night, and tried to imply to Australians generally, that there would be no increases in this coming year. I have noticed him and his colleagues trying to pound that message out across the radio and television waves so Australians will believe that this is a sort of no tax budget.

What are Australians going to be hit with during the next financial year? First of all, on 1 August motorists will be hit with a 1c a litre increase in tax on unleaded fuel and a 2c a litre increase in tax on leaded fuel. In total, as a result of the legislation that the Labor Party—with the Democrats and the Greens—passed late last year, this coming financial year the government will get $1.3 billion worth of extra revenue out of Australians just in terms of fuel excise. Let us look at tobacco excise. From 1 August 1994 Australians will be paying five per cent more excise on their tobacco. From 1 February 1995 they will be paying another five per cent excise on their tobacco. On 1 July the sales tax on wine is going up to 24 per cent from 22 per cent. Let us take sales taxes generally. At the end of the financial year, when Australians have finally got through all of the increases in other indirect taxes, on 1 July 1995 they will be hit with another one per cent increase in sales tax on everything from toothpaste to washing powder to household goods and confectionary. So, just on the indirect tax side, using the budget figures written into the budget as part of the budget, during the next financial year the government will hit Australians with additional indirect taxes of between $2 billion and $3 billion. And that is just indirect taxes.

Australians running businesses who are already struggling with the burden of the fringe benefits tax, which is another kind of payroll tax, should sit down and look at these budget papers and at what is said in this budget. According to Labor Party rhetoric, this is supposed to be a budget in which there are no tax increases. Australians running businesses will find that in this budget there will be a 130 per cent increase in the tax takes this man over here gets from the fringe benefits tax. How is that going to encourage businesses to employ and grow and compete when we have the Labor Party, in government, increasing fringe benefits taxes by 130 per cent?

Then the government has this claim that each year for the next four years it is going to collect something like $300 million from so-called compliance by getting the Australian tax office to tighten up its measures. Remember the Australian tax office, which the now Prime Minister (Mr Keating) used to boast had solved all of our tax problems? The Prime Minister went to elections claiming there were no tax rorts left in Australia. Apparently that is not true. Apparently over the next four years there is $1.2 billion that can be taken out of the community as a result of increased compliance.

As somebody said to me the other day, small businesses particularly will find tax collectors pouring through their doors, going through their books, adding to their administrative costs, adding to the time they have to spend in administration, and dotting every i and crossing every t in tax in order for the Labor Party to suck more tax out of the Australian community. Finally, let us look at income tax. The government says that income tax is not going up. Over the next year, income tax receipts will increase by a massive 8.1 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good. More people will be employed.

—The honourable member for Lilley says `good'. That is a very Labor thing to say. That is what the Labor Party would always say: `Good. Let's hit people with more tax. Let's tax them more.' Of course, as I pointed out, this budget does tax them more. Over the next four years the government has between $4 billion and $6 million being sucked out of the Australian community in the form of bracket creep. In question time we pointed out how all that contrasts with the glib promises made by the Prime Minister—and, I am sorry to say, also by a man who people used to think was so honest and reasonable, the Treasurer himself—at the time of the last election and beyond. We will not forget the Prime Minister's interview on the 7.30 Report on 4 March 1992, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we will return to taxpayers the impact of inflation, even low inflation on the tax system.

This was all about tax cuts which were in law—l-a-w, law—but the bulk of those tax cuts, five-eighths of them, were put off until 1998 in the last budget. In this budget, if we look at the forward estimates, they are not even there. They have completely disappeared into thin air.

PARA.TAB: The Treasurer comes to the dispatch box and says, `Maybe these tax cuts will occur some time in the future.' Anything can happen in the future. The earth might collide with the sun one day in the future. As the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) said, England might even beat Australia at the Ashes some time in the future—although I find that very hard to believe. But the fact is that these tax cuts are dead and buried. They have been buried very solidly six feet under—or two metres under—in this year's budget. They are completely gone. I thought it was ironic that on the exact day of the budget a year ago, on 10 May 1993, I asked the now Treasurer whether he could confirm that the government would not increase tax as a proportion of GDP. In his answer, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has made it clear in statements in the past by the Treasurer—
of course, that was Mr Dawkins—
that in relation to taxation it does not intend to increase the overall burden of taxation.

He went on and on in that vein, yet the reality is that the government is proposing very substantial increases in the burden of taxation. In financial year 1993-94, tax will be 21.9 per cent of GDP; next year, 22.5 per cent; the year after, 23 per cent; and the year after that, 23.1 per cent. It does not matter how you try to contort and distort the figures; you were happy to make the promise a year ago, Treasurer—the Prime Minister, of course, will make a promise about anything to get a vote, but you have not had that reputation over the years—that there would not be an increase in the burden of tax. Now you have the gall to stand up and say that an increase in taxation as a proportion of GDP is not apparently an increase in the burden of tax. Of course it is.

PARA.TAB: What is more, this year in real terms tax will increase by 7.4 per cent. That is a bigger increase in one year in the tax burden in this country than has occurred in any of the previous 10 years. So this year's budget is the biggest taxing budget for a decade. The government is trying to get people to believe that there are no tax increases in this budget. I say to Australians that they should read the budget, particularly the chapter on revenue in budget paper No. 1, and they will find page after page of tax increases right throughout it.

The other aspect of the budget which the government is trying to justify is the fact that according to its own figures it will run a deficit of $11.7 billion. That is a massive budget deficit. It is the third biggest budget deficit that we have ever had in the history of the Commonwealth of Australia—at a time when the economy is growing at four per cent and the Treasurer is claiming it is going to grow by 4 1/2 per cent next year.

The simple question is this: what sort of responsible economic manager would pump prime an economy which is already growing at between four and 4 1/2 per cent? But here we have a Labor government pump priming, pump priming, pump priming. Why? Because it is good macro-economic management? No, because it does not have the courage and it does not even have the sense to make sure it gets its own budgetary position under some degree of control. The government did better last time. Coming out of the last recession, at this same point, the budget deficit was, as a proportion of GDP, around a third the size of what it is this time around.

The price the government pays for running these big budget deficits is that, in the end, interest rates will be higher than would have been the case had the government taken a more responsible approach to fiscal policy. When the Treasurer and the Prime Minister have been asked in the last 12 to 18 hours whether they would guarantee there will be no increases in interest rates over the next twelve months, neither of them has given that guarantee. Of course they will not. Because the Treasurer, his department and the Reserve Bank of Australia know that interest rates will increase during the next 12 months, and they will increase quite markedly. The Treasurer does not want to tell Australians that at the moment, just as he does not want to tell Australians that this budget is the biggest taxing budget in a decade. He does not want to tell people that.

As everybody knows, the Treasurer's deficit figures are achieved by using asset sales—$2.4 billion worth of asset sales in this year. The government just squanders the money. It is all gone. It does not invest it in reducing government debt to get a recurrent benefit. It just spends it all in one year. It is like selling the family home, spending all of the money on an overseas trip or whatever it might be and ending up with nothing at the end of the year.

The fact is that, when it comes to Labor budgets, we have heard it all before. We heard Treasurer Keating say in the 1990 budget speech that we had entered an age of budget surpluses. In the same budget speech, he said, `The adjustment will occur without the misery of high unemployment and a savage recession.' This is precisely what we got. This time, it is the same old political glittering rhetoric—everything is going to be perfect, there is nothing wrong, we are in some new golden era of eternal high growth and eternal low inflation. The fact is that we have heard it before and we know what the government is up to. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —What a pathetic opposition this is. The day after the budget, all opposition members can do is rail about taxation in a budget which has no tax increases and in an economy which has the lowest taxes as a proportion of GDP of any country in the OECD. Opposition members are trying to attack this government on the grounds of taxation when it has not increased taxes in this budget and when it is running a country with the lowest taxed share of GDP of any industrial country. Can you believe the hide of the opposition in undertaking that, particularly given the fact that taxes and revenue as a share of GDP today are considerably less than they were when the opposition left government?

PARA.TAB: When the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) was Treasurer back in the dim dark days of the early 1980s, when we had double digit inflation and double digit unemployment—does he remember that?—what did we have in terms of a tax share? We had revenue as a proportion of GDP of 26.1 per cent. That was the contribution of the honourable member for Bennelong. What is it forecast to be in this budget? It is forecast to be 23.7 per cent. That is 2.4 per cent of GDP less than the honourable member for Bennelong was producing, and that equates to about $11 billion. In other words, if we were today to run the same tax revenue regime as the honourable member for Bennelong ran in 1992-83 in his last budget, then we would be raising another $11 billion.

Yet opposition members have the hide to stand here and say that this is a government which is absolutely ripping it off the Australian people with great swingeing tax increases when we are raising $11 billion a year less in tax than they raised in their last year in office. What incredible hide. What amazing gall for them to take this approach. What a pathetic response. What an absolutely bereft response.

Quite clearly, the opposition has nothing of substance to say about this budget. It is purely trying to beat up on the tax issue, trying to point to some increases in taxes which are largely coming from the fact that we have recovery, and trying to create some sort of scare campaign about swingeing tax levels being imposed on people when the people of Australia are living in the lowest taxed country in the western world. That is the reality for Australian people to realise, and they know that in this budget there were no tax increases at all. So, really, this whole gambit of the opposition is a last pathetic throw. It knows that in this budget it is cornered; there is nowhere to go because this government has got the economy back onto a substantial growth path and with an economy which is dramatically improved in its fundamentals from what it used to be.

Opposition members do not want to talk about anything of that because that is too difficult. They know there is nothing they can really criticise us on there, particularly when Australia is growing much faster than any other western industrial country. The rest of the industrial world grew by one per cent in 1993. What did we grow by? Four per cent. That is four per cent against one per cent, but opposition members do not want to talk about any of that because it is just too terrible even to contemplate talking about comparisons of growth rates. They cannot attack us on that. They want to beat up some issue on taxation. It really is the most pathetic attempt.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about east Asia?

—The honourable member for Higgins says, `What about east Asia?' I thought he wanted to compare their tax rates, because one of the favourite themes of the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) is that we have higher taxes than the east Asian countries. That is true. We also have things like age benefits, unemployment benefits and so on which, in substantial part, east Asia does not have.

PARA.TAB: If the opposition's policy is to give us an east Asian social structure, then we will be very interested to hear about that, particularly as opposition members want to parade themselves these days as some sensitive new age guys and gals who are going to be all warm and cuddly about the dispossessed and the disadvantaged in this country, while at the same time saying to us that our taxes are too high and that we should be slashing taxes and slashing the public sector. That would mean getting rid of the sorts of things the Asians do not have, such as social benefits for people who are disabled, unemployed, retired, sick and so on.

That is the position opposition members are painting themselves into. We look forward with great interest to seeing the further development of this because, as they spell this out, I am sure the Australian people will be exceedingly interested to see the detail and certainly to see how it squares up with the statements that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) is making about how the opposition is so concerned about social injustice and the need to be concerned about the disadvantaged. We look forward to all of that.

What should really be discussed today is not this beat-up issue of taxation in which the opposition has not one skerrick of credibility but, rather, what is happening to the Australian economy in this budget, why this country is in such good shape in terms of its fundamentals and why this country is performing so well economically. That is what I am sure the people of Australia are interested to hear about. They know that we have this much higher growth rate than the rest of the industrial world and that there is every reason to expect that growth rate to improve.

Australians can take great comfort from the fact that we have developed an economy which is much more efficient, competitive, dynamic and export orientated than the economy we inherited from the opposition, which gave us an economic structure which would take this country absolutely nowhere into the future. That economy has been transformed and we are now looking at an economy which is infinitely more capable of producing economic prosperity for the Australian people.

A look at the budget shows that prosperity is beginning to come through. It can be seen in terms of the three per cent growth in employment. We have already had three per cent growth over the last 12 months, and we expect to have three per cent growth in 1994-95. That will give us in the order of 240,000 additional jobs. That is coming not from the Working Nation statement but from economic growth.

The Working Nation statement is not about creating new jobs. There will be an incidental element of that—some addition—but it is not the basic rationale for it. The basic rationale for it is to make sure that the long-term unemployed and new entrants to the work force have a much better chance of getting the jobs that come on stream than they would otherwise have if no such assistance were forthcoming, as is encompassed in the Working Nation statement. That is the reality. So economic growth is producing jobs and prosperity in terms of increased real incomes. Real wages, real household disposable income and the profitability of companies are increasing. People can see that prosperity being spread across primary income receivers throughout the nation.

Not everyone is sharing equally in that. Those who are dependent upon commodities have to live with very low commodity prices. They will not share in that prosperity as much as others at this time, but hopefully commodity prices will continue to improve.

We wanted to ensure that in this budget steps were taken to address the circumstances of the socially disadvantaged, particularly those who were nominated in the budget such as the mentally handicapped, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples and homeless people—we are looking after the long-term unemployed through the Working Nation statement—so that we did look after the disadvantaged and made sure that the prosperity which the nation is now experiencing is spread across the rest of the community and we do not leave behind large segments of it. That is what this budget is about.

This budget does not impose swingeing taxes on people but brings about economic prosperity with the lowest tax regime in the Western world. It does it in a way which is producing great benefits for the Australian people. The comforting thing about it is that it is not boom and bust, as the opposition would have us believe, but something which is clearly and soundly based. It is based on fundamentals which are dramatically different from the past.

We now have two per cent inflation. At the beginning of the 1980s when the opposition was still in office, inflation was over 10 per cent. Through the 1980s, it averaged eight per cent. It gradually tracked down. Even though we had a boom at the end of the 1980s, it still remained at about the six per cent mark. But now it is down to two per cent. It clearly gives us a competitive edge. Our competitiveness has been improving because of low inflation, productivity improvement and falling real unit labour costs. Because we have been able to produce efficiently and bring unit labour costs down, we are able to be more competitive against the rest of the world.

That means that we are able to get growth in exports. We are seeing tremendous growth in exports. Since the mid-1980s, manufactured exports have been growing at the rate of 13 per cent in volume, not just value. Last year, they grew by 15 per cent. These are extraordinarily high rates of growth. It is true that they are coming off a small base, but it is rapidly becoming a much bigger base.

The export of services grew by nine per cent per annum over that period, and it rose 11 per cent last year. That is not happening by accident; it is happening because the fundamentals of the economy are just so much better and because we have been able to get into the minds of our entrepreneurs that the rest of the world is not a threat. We do not need to hide behind great tariff barriers as though we are scared of ever having to deal with the rest of the world. It is a challenge and a great opportunity.

As tariff barriers have come down, the whole mentality of Australian producers has changed. They are seeing opportunities and making great use of them, as the figures for manufactured and service exports show. That is enormously beneficial for us, because at the moment we are living with extraordinarily awful commodity prices. Those commodity prices are totally beyond the capacity of the government to control. They are determined by world demand and supply.

Had we not had this diversification of exports, we would certainly be facing a very bad balance of payments situation. That would be an enormous constraint on growth. But, because we have been able to have that diversification of exports, we are able to go on with the growth and contain the current account deficit to a level which we can live with. That demonstrates the enormous benefit to this nation of the fundamental changes which are taking place. We have every confidence that that will continue. It will continue because of those fundamental improvements.

Budgetary policy is playing its part in all of that. As we went into recession, we deliberately allowed the automatic stabilisers to turn the budget outcome around to limit the impact on the economy so that tax revenue fell and expenditure on unemployment benefits went up. We added to that some other measures to boost the economy. As the economy now comes back into strong growth, it is appropriate and proper that we withdraw that fiscal stimulus.

We are withdrawing that fiscal stimulus as rapidly as any other country in the Western world. I gave those figures at question time. I will not go through them again. The figures are in the budget papers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Belgium and Holland?

—I never mentioned Belgium or Holland. Those figures indicate that, of the industrial countries which have set out with a deficit reduction program and indicated targets, Australia has the most rigorous program. So we are making sure that the public sector is playing its part.

PARA.TAB: As the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) said at question time, outlays are being contained. That is the principal way in which the deficit is being brought down—not by increasing taxes. Revenue share goes up a few percentage points or by points of one per cent over the period. The deficit is contained by bringing down outlays. They will go from 26.6 per cent of GDP to 24.2 per cent by 1997-98. That is how the deficit is being brought down; it is not happening by increasing taxes.

As that deficit is brought down, we reduce the public sector claim on public savings, increase the net savings of the nation and reduce, therefore, the demand on other nations' savings. In that way, we limit the current account deficit. This is the appropriate policy for the nation. It is a sound policy of which the government is proud. This policy is producing the goods for the Australian people. I am sure they will recognise that this policy is exceedingly good for them and the nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The bottom line of this budget is as follows: the government takes more in revenue terms and as a percentage of GDP; the government will owe more at the end of this budget; government debt will be higher; and interest rates will be higher. All this is occurring at a time when the government would have the Australian people believe that we will have a run of growth unequalled since the 1960s.

PARA.TAB: When I woke up this morning and picked up the national newspapers, it seemed to me that just about every newspaper in the country had the word `gamble' on it. This government is gambling on a run of growth figures and on an investment figure, and it is hoping that business will do for it what it should have been able to do for itself. It could have done much better, but it failed. The tragedy for Australia is this: the government could have done better but it failed. As a result, it is gambling with the near and mid-term future of the Australian economy.

It is no wonder that the editorials of Australia's newspapers today spoke about a complacent budget of missed chances, pulling on the wrong levers or a high risk budget. They know that the fundamental underlying assumptions, forecasts and outcomes in relation to this budget could have been much better.

The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), has comprehensively gone through the revenue figures. He has shown that it does not matter whether one looks at company taxes, income taxes, sales taxes or fringe benefits taxes; the government is taking more as a result of this budget. It is taking more not only because it is growing but also because it is increasing rates.

Just one fact alone proves that point conclusively. Tax as a share of GDP was 21.9 per cent in 1993-94, 22.5 per cent in 1994-95 and 23 per cent in 1995-96. That tells us that even though GDP is growing, revenues and taxes are growing at such a rate that they will be a larger proportion this year than they were last year, and they will be a larger proportion next year than they will be this year. That figure shows conclusively that this government is taking more. It is unbelievable that even though it is taking more, it is owing more at the end of the day.

Coming out of the 1982-83 recession, we were producing real surpluses by 1987-88—within five years. They were not surpluses that were being padded out by notional asset sales. Coming out of the 1991 recession, we are still running a net financing requirement of $20 billion—four years after the event—on a deficit of $11.7 billion which is padded with asset sales. The effect of that is the government is ratcheting up Commonwealth-owned debt to new plateaus so that by the time the next economic downturn comes, it will come on a higher plateau, when the government is more exposed, when the government is more at risk. It is gambling on increasing its debt to new plateaus which will leave it in a worse position in the next economic downturn. Despite the growth, despite the fact that the government would have us believe that we are entering a golden age, it is ratcheting up debt.

The budget papers presented by the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) talk about a figure of $95 billion by the end of June 1995—about triple what it was at the end of 1991. When the minister was faced with that fact today, he gave us all the bluster; we got the whole Thomas the Tank Engine operation from him, but we did not have a fact—not one fact. There was lots of chuffing and chugging, there were wheels turning and there was toot-tooting, but there were no facts. There was no answer. It is obviously a matter of great embarrassment to him.

The honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) in today's Financial Review explains the minister's problem: in Freudian terms he is an oral expressive and he is running a department that is anally retentive. In other words, things are going in but nothing is coming out. It is a basic problem for the Minister for Finance. We have only to look at the charts in the budget papers to see that the problem is that Commonwealth own purpose outlays are still increasing.

The government is going on with all this talk about how Commonwealth expenditure and the fiscal stimulus have been withdrawn, but we have only to turn to chart 13 on page 6.24 of Budget Paper No. 1 to we see a line for Commonwealth own purpose outlays. Commonwealth own purpose outlays are increasing—and will increase again—and will hit nearly 20 per cent of GDP by 1993-94, which is about three percentage points of GDP higher than they were in 1982-83. This is at a time when the fiscal stimulus is supposedly being withdrawn and at a time when we have golden rates of economic growth—when we are still growing.

In all fairness, the government has been cutting the states in relation to outlays—it has been giving them the kind of medicine that it will not take itself—but Commonwealth own purpose outlays are growing. We can see it in relation to the budget aggregate outcomes—about 2.9 per cent in real terms in the following year. There is no talk here of the government actually applying to itself the kind of stringency that it asks of the states, or the kind of stringency that it has imposed on small business as a result of its high interest rate policy and the economic recession that we had to have under the prime ministership of Mr Keating.

This is a lazy, complacent government when it comes to outlays, even to the extent where the great boasts in this budget in relation to spending were measures that we know were rejected by the government's own ERC. The papers were full of how the government's own ERC had rejected some of the proposals that were trumpeted as great breakthroughs in the budget speech the Treasurer (Mr Willis) delivered yesterday. It is clear that this government is raising revenue and is mortgaging future budgets because it cannot deal with its own problem. It cannot deal with its own purpose outlays.

We notice in this budget that there is a $2 billion increase in public debt interest. The Commonwealth has to spend about $2 billion extra of the hard-earned taxes of Australians just to service the public debt interest—it is about a 36 per cent increase in the 1994-95 year. That figure will go up again because it will add another net financing requirement of about $20 billion in the 1994-95 year. The more Commonwealth owned debt is sent up, the more the servicing cost grows. The more the servicing cost grows, the less choices you have in the future in relation to discretionary expenditure because you are paying for past mistakes. This government is locking itself into lesser choices, lesser possibilities, lesser flexibility, as a result of its financial ineptitude over the last couple of years.

Peter Walsh would never have stood for this kind of performance. The one thing you could say about Walsh is that he really would have tried to make a difference, tried to do the job at both ends, and tried to make sure that the Commonwealth government got into a much better position during periods of growth. It is during periods of growth, if they are to be believed, that grain should be put into the storehouses, that we should lay it up for the lean years to come.

This $11.7 billion deficit is again padded out with things like the sale of Qantas. The sale of Qantas gets into just about every budget to pad out the deficit. The sale has already failed twice, but it is in there again to pad out the deficit and to try to give a headline figure to the financial markets—which had already taken their positions before the budget came down because they knew the truth. The truth is that because this government cannot get its act together, interest rates will be higher than they need to be. That rise will affect business. It will ultimately affect the taxpayers of Australia, who are already paying more through the tax system and who will get an even more raw deal as a result of this government's laziness, its complacency and its financial ineptitude.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Swan Mr W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition has an incredible hide to come into this House and complain about the higher tax burden supposedly imposed in this budget. This budget has something like $3 billion worth of tax concessions to the business community which will produce business investment and jobs. Is the opposition seriously saying that those tax concessions should be abolished? Is the opposition seriously saying that we should abolish the reduction in the company tax rate, which will cost the revenue $1.8 billion this year and $1.6 billion next year? Is the opposition seriously saying that we should abolish the accelerated depreciation allowance, which will cost the revenue $360 million this year and $490 million next year? Is the opposition seriously putting that forward?

PARA.TAB: Last week I had the honour to attend the annual dinner of the Australian Mining Industry Council. Who was the guest speaker at the dinner? One would have imagined that there would have been some leader from the conservative parties, some state premier, or perhaps somebody from the 56-strong opposition front bench. But, no, the council invited the Premier of Queensland. Why did it invite the Premier of Queensland? Because he and this federal government have an understanding of what is needed in this country to get private sector growth and private sector investment.

The business community does not talk to those on the opposition benches for three billion reasons. The business community does not talk to them because it knows they do not understand business. They do not understand the essential challenges facing the Australian economy. When the opposition comes in here and says the government is spending too much and we should reduce the budget deficit to $8 billion a year, is it suggesting we do that by abolishing the $3 billion worth of business tax concessions? Is it seriously suggesting that? I think it is because there is no other alternative. There has not been a blow-out in outlays.

The substantial change on the structural side of the deficit has simply been the $3 billion worth of tax concessions delivered to industry in the interest of providing long-term sustainable jobs in the private sector. Therefore, is it any wonder that organisations such as the Australian Mining Industry Council would never bother to invite a leader from the state or federal conservative parties to address them at their annual dinner? They simply do not understand the issues. Perhaps they have the same opinion as Malcolm Fraser, which was expressed in an article in the Weekend Australian some time ago:

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberal Party is in deeper trouble than at any time since its formation. Through 1991 and 1992 it tried to force Australians in directions they did not want to go.
Twelve months since the loss of the March 1993 election, we are as much in the dark about what the party stands for as we were the day Fightback was buried.
John Hewson has told us that he has the numbers. If there are real contenders, he could call on them to put up or shut up . . .

All the contenders were in the House today. I noticed that the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) actually had a larger audience than the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer). I also noticed that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) was not in the House. The only other person who was missing was the honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop). Perhaps that says something about the problems that the opposition has in developing any sort of policy, whether it is to do with business investment or framing a budget.

PARA.TAB: What is the opposition proposing as the alternative? If it is not proposing that we abolish the business tax incentives, is it proposing that we take away the personal income tax cuts that were given last year, or is it proposing an increase in taxes? Does the opposition support the jobs levy? Does it want an increase in the Medicare levy? Of course it does not—and neither does this government, which is why this budget was brought down with no new taxes.

In many ways the matter of public importance which we are debating here today is a compliment to the government. The opposition is conceding that we are reaping the benefits of growth. It is a commonsense observation to make that, if more people are in work and if business is making more profit, then revenue will increase, thanks very much. Those opposite have actually conceded the centrepiece of the budget strategy—that the government has balanced program for growth. We also know there is a need to give incentives to business so that we get business investment.

We all know that is coming, but we also understand the need to spend on programs for the long-term unemployed so that in the long term we have a healthy, productive and efficient work force without the wage pressures which would otherwise emerge. We have managed to do all that in this budget whilst, at the same time, bringing the deficit down to $11.7 billion—lower than was forecast and lower than the $13.6 billion deficit last financial year. We will bring the deficit in below target in 1996-97. That is what those opposite are jealous of.

The opposition's matter of public importance concedes the success of the government in economic management; we will bring the deficit down to about 0.9 per cent of GDP in 1996-97. The opposition is conceding that the economy is going to grow, that there will be more jobs and that there will be healthier profits. That is happening under a Labor government, which is why the business community of this country has deserted the opposition on the question of this budget. That is why the business community has deserted the opposition on the ludicrous propositions it put forward in the debate on the white paper.

What alternative has the opposition put forward? In the last 20 years or so, there have been two tax policies from the opposition. We had the Howard tax policy—the one where tax was optional for the rich but where the PAYE taxpayer paid all. As the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) said before in this House, if the revenues we have now had applied when the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) was Treasurer, the opposition would be raising $11 billion more in taxation. That is the opposition's record. It is a record of high taxation.

That brings us to the last example, Fightback, a policy of the Liberal and National parties which would have put a 15 per cent GST on all the necessities of life. It was a $23 billion tax grab. That is the policy those opposite have been trying to run away from ever since the last election. It is the policy that they stand for philosophically, even if they are not game to admit it. The conclusion of Fightback says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberal and National parties are proud of this program and confident of its success . . . It is, we believe, irrefutable.

How can it be irrefutable before the last election and dead and buried now? It is not dead and buried now. The opposition is simply not game to admit that its policy is the same as it was then. What it has got hiding in the cupboard is one huge GST; it cannot make the sort of expenditure commitments it makes in this House work unless it engages in massive taxation on the one hand or massive cuts in public expenditure on the other.

PARA.TAB: That brings us to the core of some of the opposition's recent statements on public policy. The honourable member for Mayo, with the support of the honourable member for Higgins, came into this House and said that we should have Asian levels of taxation. That would mean cuts to the revenue of this country of between $11 billion and $30 billion a year. That is the sort of alternative the opposition is putting forward—massive cuts in expenditure. The honourable member for Mayo is on the record as saying that. In a report entitled Australia—East Asia: comparison of economic performance, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Then he (the Prime Minister) will have to accept the fact that the level of taxation in Australia is far too high.
He went on to state:
Mr Keating should substantially reduce taxes.
He further stated:
. . . it is a fact that the tax levels in Australia are over twice as high as East Asia.

If the honourable member for Mayo wants to go down the road of east Asian tax levels, he should bear in mind that we will be explaining to the business community of Australia that there are no more tax incentives, and that we will be explaining what that means to social programs. For example, if we were to move to the tax level of Indonesia, we would be cutting revenue in this country by $12 billion. That is equivalent to cutting the complete assistance that this government gives to the aged. If cuts like that are not vicious enough, if we were to move to the revenue level of, say, Taiwan, we would be cutting expenditure in this country by $33 billion. That would mean cuts to veterans' affairs of $4 billion, cuts to assistance to families with children of $9 billion, cuts to assistance to the unemployed of $7 billion, and cuts to assistance to the aged of $12 billion. That is what a $33 billion cut in revenue would mean.

PARA.TAB: I have been very disturbed by the pessimistic outlook of the opposition. What this country needs more than anything is a good dose of optimism. The economy is turning around, inflation is low, interest rates are low, profitability is high and jobs are growing. What those opposite have to say to this community is that they are in danger of passing on to our children a degree of pessimism about this country's future which is absolutely destabilising to our future prospects.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The discussion has concluded.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: HMAS Cerberus technical training and other facilities, Westernport, Vic.

SPEECH.PARA: HMAS Cerberus is the major training establishment for the Royal Australian Navy. It is located on Western Port Bay, Victoria, some 60 kilometres south-east of Melbourne. Existing facilities and services date back to the early 1920s. A number of facilities are more modern or have been upgraded. The transfer of technical training from HMAS Nirimba to HMAS Cerberus necessitates the provision of additional facilities to enable effective training to continue. The proposal is to provide purpose built facilities for technical training, replacement of those facilities it is not economical to upgrade, expansion of facilities unable to cope with increased demand and new facilities for services operating from temporary and inadequate accommodation.

PARA.TAB: The scope of the work provides for continuous functioning of the base throughout the construction period and includes a health centre, accommodation blocks, galley, cafeteria, technical training classrooms and workshops, indoor swimming pool, gymnasium extension, motor transport compound and engineering services. The estimated total cost of the works is $45.5 million at January 1994 prices. Subject to parliamentary approval, construction work on the site is expected to commence in April 1995, with completion due by January 1998.

In its report the committee recommended that it be advised on the implementation of the recommendations of the energy audit conducted on HMAS Cerberus; that the Department of Defence undertake a review regarding the potential use of waste water on HMAS Cerberus, with the aim of including

SPEECH.PARA: it in the current project; that it be advised of the results of this review and the cost implications for the project; and that the Department of Defence forward section 30 referrals to the Australian Heritage Commission as soon as possible after referral of the project to the committee.

PARA.TAB: The Department of Defence advises that it has noted the committee's recommendations and provides the following comments: a report on the implementation of the recommendations of the energy audit conducted on HMAS Cerberus will be forwarded to the public works committee once action has been completed; a review regarding the potential use of waste water on HMAS Cerberus has been undertaken, and a copy of the report has been forwarded to the public works committee. I thank the committee for its report and I commend this motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walker The Hon F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Refurbishment of Australian Federal Police (AFP) College, Barton, ACT.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Federal Police training college—formerly Lawley House, a Commonwealth government hostel—was completed in 1946. Major extensions were added to the hostel in 1967. Apart from work in the west wing to convert it to use as a training college in 1978 for the Commonwealth Police, no major refurbishing work has taken place since the building was constructed. In its present state, the building no longer satisfies Commonwealth or contemporary AFP requirements for residential accommodation, office accommodation or occupational health and safety. The majority of services—such as wiring, plumbing and drainage—are part of the original 1940s installation and are now substandard and subject to extensive ongoing maintenance work. The building is not air-conditioned, and the kitchen does not meet health standards.

PARA.TAB: The public works committee tabled its report on 4 May 1994 recommending the project at an estimated cost of $10.5 million, subject to impacts associated with the law enforcement review having no significant bearing on the scope of the proposal.

In its report the committee also raised a number of issues to which the AFP provided the following responses. The Commonwealth law enforcement review, which was considered by cabinet on 23 March 1994, contained recommendations which will involve an enhanced role for the AFP investigative training. The impacts associated with the review will not have a significant bearing on the scope of the refurbishment proposal, as the training strategy encompassed in the review is consistent with the objectives of the refurbishment proposal: that is, development of an effective and functional training facility to meet Commonwealth law enforcement needs. Current assessments of college needs indicate that the refurbished building will be appropriate in size and amenity for the foreseeable future. The extent of the asbestos and cost of removal will be advised to the committee.

The ongoing process of consultation and coordination established with the ACT fire brigade will be maintained throughout the duration of the project, as will relations with the Australian Council for the Rehabilitation of the Disabled. Discussions will be held with the Australian Federal Police Association on child-care requirements and with centres in the area on the availability of spaces for children of personnel attending courses at the college, with a view to formalising arrangements prior to the college reopening. I would like to thank the committee for its report, and I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walker The Hon F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Relocation of the Salisbury Explosive Ordnance testing facilities to Port Wakefield, SA.

SPEECH.PARA: The environmental test facility, ETF, is an army unit that undertakes environmental testing of equipment and explosive ordnance to ascertain compliance with defence specifications. The existing facilities at the Defence Science and Technology Organisation, Salisbury are in close proximity to the civilian population and other defence units. This restricts the size and the nature of the testing programs undertaken. It is proposed that the explosive ordnance testing function of the ETF move to a recently acquired site adjacent to the existing proof and experimental establishment at Port Wakefield. The proposal will provide improved testing facilities and enhance safety measures associated with testing activities.

PARA.TAB: The proposal, which was referred to the public works committee on 14 December 1993, is to construct 16 buildings, including test buildings, small explosive storage magazines and administrative facilities on a greenfield site. The Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) has approved the use of army engineers as the primary construction agency for the project. It is anticipated that the construction will commence in June 1994 and be completed by December 1995. A commercial project manager will oversight the work, and local suppliers and tradesmen will have the opportunity to bid for work. The outturn cost for this proposal is $8 million.

In its report, the public works committee endorsed the need for environmental stress testing of explosive ordnance and noted that the effectiveness and efficiency of the ETF at Salisbury are limited by operating constraints and the age and nature of the existing facilities. The committee recommended the construction of the new facilities. I would like to take the time to thank the committee for its support, and I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall The Hon R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearly, the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker) is unaware of the stress and the public resentment about the siting of the proof range at Port Wakefield. I notice that this new facility, worth $8 million, is to be built adjacent to the existing proof range. This, of course, adds to the problem of disturbance which will occur and damage which will be done and is already being done in that part of South Australia in close proximity to the capital city of Adelaide.

PARA.TAB: The history of the proof range is one of growth—an incremental growth in regard to the development of new munitions and new guns—in a place where the proof range in 1928, when it was established, was secure in the sense that it was distanced from the capital city of South Australia. But since then, as I have said, there has been a growth in technology in relation to armaments, and there has been an increasing demand for a further expansion of the proof range. This has brought the proof range into direct collision with those who use the gulf for a recreation area and those who live in the northern areas of the metropolitan district.

I refer to a social and ecological assessment, an impact statement, of 1985 which was sponsored by the government, which at that time had put forward a proposal to acquire two settlements on the gulf to further extend the proof range south of Port Wakefield. This caused a great deal of disturbance, and so it ought to have.

At that time the impact statement assessed that approximately 5,000 people per annum make use of the approximately 140 holiday homes at those two settlements. Additionally, a recreation survey conducted for the purposes of the EIS indicated that approximately 32,000 to 40,000 persons could visit the areas of Parham, Webb Beach, Port Prime and Thompsons Beach in any particular year. Based on the survey data, it was also estimated that the total number of annual person-day visits is between 300,000 and 320,000 at all four beaches and between 220,000 and 240,000 at Parham and Webb Beach alone.

An immense protest movement evolved in the face of this demand by the army and the Department of Defence to acquire further territory on that gulf. I was working assiduously with and on behalf of that protest group and I am pleased to say that after a great deal of public discussion about and acrimony over this matter the then Minister for Defence, the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley), withdrew the demand for acquisition. Whilst he did not say it in plain English, one got the impression that the testing of the Howitzer 155 millimetre gun would not proceed at that site. We have found that in the last few months there has been a very intensive test of that gun, much to the dismay of fishermen and despite the fact that at that time the army said the tests could not proceed unless these two sites were acquired.

I view the army's attitude and involvement in this with deep suspicion. I believe that it is extremely conservative in regard to what it wants and that it treats the public with great disregard. It says very little publicly of what it is about and what its future intentions may be. In relation to usage, we find that the general area and kilometres involved were also given in the statement. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: If ranges of 40 km are obtained the OWR—
overwater range—
requirement would approach 30 km.
The guns have to be fired to at least 75 per cent of their maximum range to effectively test munitions. The statement continues:
This represents the limit of OWR which can be accommodated in water south of Port Wakefield for at any greater range the intertidal conditions are unsuitable.

In testing this gun the army has reached the usage limit of that range, yet we can expect the technology of munitions and artillery to further increase their range and to further increase the need for overwater recovery of test munitions. To invest another $8 million alongside a proof range which will become obsolete in the face of further technical requirements and which is unwanted by South Australian residents is very foolish. There is also the matter of waste when this or a future government has to shift this range.

PARA.TAB: There is a great deal of information in this statement which shows how polluted the beach is. I remind the House that this is a beach within a relatively few kilometres of the city of Adelaide and a very important recreational area. Proof facilities would simply not be tolerated in any other capital city of Australia.

A great deal of detail is given about malfunctioning explosives. The recent test has drawn attention to this because of one particular type of explosive. This type constitutes the majority of firings and there is estimated to be a 3.4 per cent failure in recovery. The statement which succeeds this one indicates that each unfound ordnance or munition would have to be marked by a buoy and people would be prohibited from proceeding within at least a hundred metres of that buoy. Local fishermen indicate that the high explosives create enormous disturbance of the seabed and, therefore, wherever these guns are used a continually increasing area of beach and sea cannot be used.

As well as this already heavily polluted beach south of the Port Wakefield range, which experts say will never be cleared and will not be safe for use by the public in the foreseeable future, we are faced with the expansion of the range and further significant pollution of sea and beach.

During the development of the impact statement, reference was made to options. I believe that in making this reference the defence department was extremely negligent in considering any suitable alternative that could be found for this range. It was said that ranges are used in other parts of the world in other forms, but the Port Wakefield range is supposedly one of the best in the world because of the sloping seabed and the retreat of the tide, which enables recovery of spent ammunition. What the defence department did not fully proceed to explain is why it is unable to create artificial water bodies which are sufficiently suitable for their purposes. It referred to pond use overseas and to the use of snow and other soft surfaces, but it has never said why it cannot create an artificial lake sufficiently large to receive shells used in target practice.

The statement is very delinquent indeed in examining an alternative arrangement. I do not believe the defence department or the army were serious at looking at alternatives. I do not believe they intended then, as they do not intend now, to take note of public opinion or of the opinion of the then state government of South Australia.

I believe there is something of a ruse involved since the then minister announced in 1986 that the government would not proceed with the acquisition. It was thought then that another range would be found or developed for the purposes of testing the 155 millimetre Howitzer. That is not the case and South Australia has just experienced a very vigorous test in its gulf. Main roads were closed to enable the firing of the guns and fishermen were irate that they were prohibited from fishing in some of the best parts of the gulf for a month.

The annual usage and the irritation of the moment is not the point. The point is that the development of a recreational area in the long-term future is being denied South Australians by the close proximity to the capital city of a very large testing range. It is simply unfair that the rest of Australia should impose this on my state, on the coast in this close-in area. Whilst it may be a separate test area in relation to the proof range, it is adjacent. To add to the general value of and investment in an area which is obsolete in terms of development is essentially a waste of money.

I warn the minister that public opinion will not allow this facility to remain in the long term. It is simply untenable, as we look forward to planning for the next 10, 20 or 30 years, to say, `Yes, we can go on polluting for all time a recreational beach for a million people.' It is nonsense and it is time the government of the day understood that. The government should have studied the problems that surrounded this impact statement and the proposals of 1985 and 1986. It should have gone to the Minister for Defence and asked him what his motives were and then retreated in the face of public opinion, as he did.

The government is indeed at fault in proceeding along these lines, in not acceding to public opinion. It will cost the Australian taxpayer just that much more when the facility being approved now is shifted within the next 10 or 20 years. There is not the slightest doubt that public opinion will prevail in relation to this area so close to the city.

This action is all part of the trashing of the gulf. It is all part of denying development of a recreational area of a rather vast dimension in our city. What other city in Australia would allow this to happen? What new technology will be incrementally introduced into this area?

I ask the minister: is it a fact that ammunition from overseas is being tested at this facility? It is a very pertinent question. Is this Australian beach being polluted by ammunition tested for a foreign power? Is that the case or is it not? If the ammunition of a foreign power is being used to trash St Vincents Gulf, I warn the minister that he is in for some long-term trouble. I do not want a cover-up on this. I do not want anyone to tell me that it is classified as to whether some overseas ammunition is churning up the fishing areas and the recreational areas of my state. I want an answer from the minister and, if he does not know the answer, I ask him to find out. No classified information should be denied to the public of South Australia on the basis of some deal we have with a foreign power.

A great deal of information about the position of this facility is available. The minister is adding to it. He will waste $8 million in the longer term. New technology will put further pressure on this area, and the public resents this and will not accept it. I believe there are alternatives which could be developed. However, the army and the Defence Force, in their conservatism and their safe feeling that they can ignore the public, have refused to develop and examine these alternatives.

If just south of that area thousands of hectares of salt ponds can be created artificially of about the same depth that the proof range requires to test its ammunition in a private salt-producing commercial venture, will anyone believe the army that it cannot can do likewise somewhere else to test its ammunition? The fact that the army cannot find and construct another facility in a more isolated space is a farce. I warn the minister that what he is now doing is wrong. It will be proven wrong and it will cost the Australian community a great sum to finally remove these substantial facilities out of the way of metropolitan development.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) to read the speech that the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) made in this chamber last week. This facility is in the electorate of the honourable member for Wakefield. He is a member of the Joint Statutory Committee on Public Works that made these recommendations.

PARA.TAB: There will be no extra explosives. The honourable member canvassed some issues about the Howitzer gun. The Howitzer gun was across the gulf. It was not from this range at all. The honourable member was being misleading in saying that it was from this range. I chaired the public works committee which dealt with this matter. Our inquiry was widely advertised. Everyone who appeared before the committee supported this project. The local council supported it; the local federal member supported it; everyone supported it. I have heard the complaints that have been made over the last month, but it is amazing that, even though this project was widely advertised, we did not have anyone appear before us who opposed it.

These groups have been complaining about what happened over there last month, but it was not from this range at all. They were testing from across the bay. Sure, it was a very loud explosive. This is a recreational area a few miles from Adelaide. I have been there and there are better beaches around Adelaide, believe you me.

As I said in my speech last week—and this is mentioned in our report—no extra work will be carried out there. There is no great secret about foreign orders. The facility is there to test foreign ammunition, as it always has been. We are only continuing what we were doing. We are taking it from a suburb of Adelaide and, instead of trundling all this equipment through the suburbs of Adelaide, which I thought the honourable member would be concerned about, we are putting it out in a relatively remote area.

The range has not expanded at all. The diameter of the range is exactly what it was before. The same amount of work will be carried out there. Only the ammunition will be stored out of suburban Adelaide. As I said, no-one came to us with these opposing views. It is not a recreational beach. The honourable member for Wakefield made all these points in his speech. That beach has been polluted for years and years. I am sure the army would invite the honourable member for Boothby out there and give him a demonstration of what it does, as it did for us. It shoots the shells out there and, as the honourable member knows, it recovers them in the low tide. All the shells that are being shot out there are recovered.

The honourable member for Boothby is right in saying that it is a polluted beach, but that pollution goes back to the period of the Second World War. The honourable member is correct in saying that that part of the gulf is trashed, but we did not trash it. The present facility did not trash it. It was trashed due to the tests that were carried out during the Second World War. That is the problem. The honourable member knows better than I that the beach is now closed. He was misleading when he said that it was a recreational area for one million people in Adelaide. Parham may be a recreational beach, but that area of the range, as the honourable member knows better than I do, is already closed and off-limits. It is off-limits because of the garbage that has been left there since the Second World War.

There is no better place to put this facility in Australia. I will make a bet with the honourable member that it will not be removed. There is no big secret about the foreign testing. We are all into earning a buck today. If they can earn a buck from that, that is okay. They have always done it. They will continue doing it. The honourable member should talk to his colleague and friend the honourable member for Wakefield who made an excellent explanatory speech in the House last week and put all of these issues on the public record.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—As the Minister for Administrative Services, my role is to facilitate the work of the Joint Statutory Committee on Public Works. The administrative services portfolio involves working with clients at times. This time the client is the Department of Defence. As I am not the Minister for Defence, I do not have available to me answers to some of the questions that the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) put to me during this debate. I have the greatest respect for the honourable member for Boothby and I will refer his questions to the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) for his response in due course. But I urge the House to support this particular motion.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Consideration resumed.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to question time this legislation was debated and there were two speakers, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) and me, from the coalition. During question time, the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) quite erroneously and, I think, maliciously chose to stand up in this place, when he did not have an answer to a question on government debt and expenditure, and claim that the coalition had attempted, by opposing the second reading of one of these bills, to stop government revenue.

PARA.TAB: I attempted during a personal explanation to say how wrong and dishonest that particular remark was. It is also, of course, now becoming a consistency with the Minister for Finance to misrepresent the very words and actions of members in this place in what I think is a most despicable way and one which does him no credit.

I remind the House of other occasions. The honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) stood up in this place not that long ago and made a speech attacking the then minister for sport and recreation. The Minister for Finance—he was not the minister then—attacked the honourable member for Higgins and claimed in words he had just spoken that he had used sexist remarks against the then minister for sport, which was totally untrue. It was reported in the media, nevertheless, as though it were the truth. There was not one word in the Hansard.

In regard to this bill I want to put on the record what was said here before question time. That simply was that, whilst we did not oppose the government's need for revenue in providing this service, and whilst we did not oppose the concept of user-pays, we thought the processes the government was using were, to use my words, silly in as much as it chose, for instance, to divide the number of submerged land leaseholders into a $10 million amount of money and therefore charge an equal sum—which I think is $100,000—to everybody. That was the thing to which the coalition was objecting to, and which the industry objects to also. We argued for a proper user-pays. We never at any time suggested in our speeches—and they are on the record—that the government should be denied $10 million of revenue, other than if it continued to proceed with what is a rather foolish means of collection.

This is the issue that the Minister for Finance knew well, and it is the matter I want to put on the record. This person knows what he hears, and if he does not hear he should not comment in this fashion. He is now starting to get this sleazy reputation of putting words in other people's mouths. I for one object. He may think he can get away with it with others; he cannot get it away with it with me. I know what I said in here. It is on the record and I want to make it very clear as far as this person is concerned, this Minister for Finance, who used to stand in his place at least as an opponent one could admire but who now continues to misrepresent people's words in a very foolish and unnecessary way. As such, I wanted to clear the record at this opportunity.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 2 March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to make minor amendments to the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 and the Maritime College Act 1978, and to repeal other acts relating to employment, education and training. The amendment to the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 provides minor adjustments to financial amounts. These adjustments flow from the transfer of responsibilities for funding the Institute of the Arts of the Australian National University from the ACT government to the Commonwealth.

PARA.TAB: The ACT government receives special revenue assistance as part of general revenue payments from the Commonwealth. The level of special revenue assistance has in the past made allowance (as assessed by the Commonwealth Grants Commission) for the cost of funding the Institute of the Arts so as to maintain the same level of courses as existed at the time of self-government. In accordance with the Commonwealth Grants Commission's 1992 update of relativities, the Commonwealth will provide the funding directly to the Australian National University through the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 with a consequential reduction in special revenue assistance to the ACT government.

Additional funding adjustments are required as a result of Senate amendments to the Higher Education Funding Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 which removed the provisions for a double rate of the higher education contribution scheme, HECS, on undergraduate students undertaking a second degree at the same or lower level.

As a result of the financial adjustments to the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 relating to the transfer of funding for the Institute of the Arts and the removal of double HECS, this bill will provide an additional $26.1 million in 1994, $31 million in 1995 and $30.2 million in 1996. The increase in outlays will be partly offset by a reduction in payments from the higher education contribution scheme trust account of $20.9 million in 1994, $20.5 million in 1995 and $18.9 million in 1996. In the longer term, Commonwealth outlays will increase by approximately $27 million each year due to the removal of the double HECS provisions. In addition, a reduction in general revenue payments to the ACT government of $3.3 million in 1995 and 1996 will be made to fully offset the payments for the Institute of the Arts.

It is usually convenient to include all the amendments affecting payments under the Higher Education Funding Act in a Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill implementing budget or additional estimates decisions about higher education funding. However, the current amendment affects amounts to be paid in calendar year 1994 and it is therefore desirable that the revised amounts be legislated as soon as practicable. This bill is the first available vehicle on the legislation program for this portfolio which can contain the amendment. The Attorney-General's Department has advised that there is no constitutional or other legal impediment to including the amendment to the Higher Education Funding Act in this bill.

The bill's provisions also include amendments to the Maritime College Act 1978. These amendments include appointing the chairperson of the academic board as an ex officio member of the Australian Maritime College Council. This will give appropriate representation on the council to senior teaching staff and leave one member of the council to be elected by the whole of the college's teaching staff.

Other amendments to the Maritime College Act include changes to gender specific references in order to reflect current drafting practices. This bill will also repeal three acts relating to employment, education and training. These acts have been superseded and are no longer required.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill and commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: 5.28 p.m.)—The bill before the House, the Employment, Education and Training Legislation Amendment Bill, is largely straightforward and the coalition will not be opposing the amendments it makes to the acts in question. In particular, we support the amendment to the Maritime College Act. It should increase involvement by staff at the college and appears to be a sound approach to the college's management.

PARA.TAB: The most significant section of the bill is part 4, which increases the maximum level of recurrent grants for higher education institutions, a consequence of the government's being forced last year to abandon its plans to double higher education contribution scheme charges for students undertaking second undergraduate courses at the same or higher level. This was as a result of the coalition's objections to the government's proposal as punitive, unfair and disadvantaging many groups.

The coalition's decision followed a long period of consultation with and representations from many groups in the community. The feedback was that such legislation would have disadvantaged women who need to upgrade their training after an absence from the work force, usually for family reasons; the legislation would have disadvantaged the disabled, who frequently need to retrain in order to re-enter the work force; the legislation would have disadvantaged those who are required to complete an additional degree as a prerequisite for a prescribed course; the legislation would have disadvantaged migrants who had completed their initial degree overseas at no cost to Australian taxpayers—such degrees frequently not being recognised by Australian institutions—and who need to upgrade their training to gain better jobs and more productivity. Finally, it would have disadvantaged those who were, at the time, completing additional training who had not budgeted for the additional cost.

Many students in the above categories would have been forced to abandon their studies at a time when the community expects and demands higher levels of training. The government's intention in introducing a double HECS was to discourage some students from continuing their tertiary study. It was a bid to create more places for those studying for their first degree. However, a likely outcome would have been to force people out of the university system only to go onto the unemployment queue. At the time, the shadow minister for employment, education and training, the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge) stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the legislation amounted to nothing more than sleight of hand to slug groups of students with a punitive charge by a Government intent on rationing higher education because of increased student demands.

The coalition's successful opposition to the Higher Education Funding Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 meant that the legislation failed to pass the Senate. As a result, those students who were either in the process of obtaining a second degree or considering the undertaking of a second degree will not be penalised, despite the government's plans for a double HECS.

PARA.TAB: Today, five years after the introduction of the higher education contribution scheme, there are indications that the scheme needs to be examined in detail to identify exactly how much money is being collected, how much is really in arrears and to more effectively measure likely future debts.

At time of the HECS introduction by the Hawke government in 1989, the assumption was that the federal government would recover most, if not all, the HECS debt. This assumption is steadily being disproved. Those concerned about the future of those undertaking tertiary education know that in the real world life does not always turn out as predicted. For example, the Australian economy's boom and bust cycles will mean that many of our future graduates' earning lives will be put on hold, with no lessening of their financial and personal commitments. Increasingly, the effort and sacrifices involved in their studies seem just a waste of time, with few job prospects at the end of the process. For many graduates, the achievement of a degree has turned into a hollow disappointment—a false promise of an assured future.

Last year, a university of Canberra study suggested many graduates, especially women, would carry their HECS debt late into life. The government had calculated that these debts would be repaid nine to 11 years after they had been incurred. Furthermore, the Commonwealth Actuary has classified as doubtful $376.5 million of the $2,300 million HECS debt as at the last financial year. The fact is that 16.7 per cent of graduates are unlikely to ever earn enough to repay their HECS. The Actuary's report—prepared for the Department of Employment, Education and Training—found that of the $2,300 million in outstanding HECS, 9 1/2 per cent of the debt owed by male graduates and 19.4 per cent of the debt owed by female graduates was unlikely to be repaid. In other words, a significant proportion of graduates will never earn enough money to pay back their HECS tuition fees.
