I remind the House that under Labor's HECS, full-time university students must pay $2,355 each year in tuition fees. Students can receive a 25 per cent discount by paying their fees up front, or they can repay the debt through the taxation system after they enter the work force. Graduates do not have to start repaying the HECS debt until they earn the average wage—$26,403 this year—when they must pay three per cent of their salary to DEET. The repayment rate rises to four per cent for graduates earning more than $30,000 and five per cent for those earning more than $42,000.

The Commonwealth Actuary's report that I have referred to makes a number of assumptions. One is that male graduates earn a starting salary of $27,000 and female graduates $25,000 and that it will take them at least 10 years to repay their HECS debts. Secondly, it assumes that as graduates grow older and earn higher salaries they experience higher rates of unemployment. This is based on the official unemployment rates for February 1983 with `allowance made for some expected improvement in future years'.

The Actuary's report assumes an unemployment rate of 8.7 per cent for 22-year-old male graduates whose earnings average $27,000 a year. For 35-year-old male graduates, average earnings are 50 per cent higher but their unemployment rate rises to 10 per cent. Twenty-two year-old female graduates' average earnings are $25,000 and they have an unemployment rate of 8.8 per cent—perversely, slightly higher than the male rate despite their lower average earnings.

The Commonwealth government's assumptions with respect to graduates' abilities to repay HECS nine to 11 years after graduation obviously needs to be revised. Some graduates are taking a long time before being appointed to their first job, and not all graduates are proving to have the earning potential that was originally assumed. Many have needed to take a much lower salary in order to get into the work force. So we have a situation of the government's theory not working in practice.

HECS is proving to be considerably less successful than was expected. What are the ramifications for tertiary education if a substantial minority of students—something of the order of 10 per cent to 20 per cent—are unlikely to earn enough to repay their HECS? Huge burdens have been placed on universities during the last decade, and these pressures show no signs of abating.

A substantial shortfall in the HECS component must mean a comprehensive rethinking of future funding policies. It may be that doubtful debts on the scale of 16.7 per cent will be inevitable and that this figure reflects future normal levels of graduate remuneration and/or unemployment. Decisions will need to be made in order to determine whether the salary threshold should be lowered further and repayment rates increased, for example.

Following last night's budget speech, new university graduates will experience even more government pressure. From 1 January 1995, graduates will be forced to repay their HECS sooner and faster after entering the work force. In future, HECS will be calculated on a pro rata basis so that employed graduates could be liable to pay HECS even if they work for only part of the year. We are told that this move will net the Department of Employment, Education and Training an estimated $5 million a year until at least 1997-98 but—here is the catch—the savings will do little to reduce the estimated $2,300 million in outstanding HECS payments.

Details as to how the change will affect casual and part-time employees are still to be decided by the government and the Australian Tax Office, which collects the fees through the income tax collection system. As I have said, the coalition is not opposing the bill. However, we think it is proper that the questions that are raised, particularly by recent reports, should be put on the record and consider it a matter of some importance that the government pursue these issues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sawford Mr R.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to spend much time debating the finer points of the Employment, Education and Training Legislation Amendment Bill but later in the debate I will canvass the more important, overall issues in employment, education and training facing this nation. This bill is mainly straightforward in nature and will not provide a major deviation from the government's current higher education policies. It aims to correct some inequities which have occurred as a result of a transfer between the Commonwealth government and the ACT government of funding responsibilities for the Australian National University. It also repeals the States Grants (Advanced Education Assistance) Act 1976, the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act 1984 and the States Grants (Technical and Further Education Assistance) Act 1989. These acts are spent and, therefore, no longer needed, and can be removed from the statute books.

PARA.TAB: The bill will make minor amendments to the Maritime College Act 1978 to provide minor changes to appointments to the college council to reflect current policy on accountability. This bill does not intend any major changes but is important as it is part of the ongoing process of good government in this country. I would, however, like to address some of my remarks on access to higher education and, perhaps more importantly, to quality education in general.

In just over 10 years, this government has achieved more in education than all of the post-war conservative governments put together. Their record is of failure to recognise this nation's greatest asset, that is, its people and the effect of intellectual and skill capability on increased productivity, higher standards of living and overall quality of life. In 10 years, this government has provided for an increase in higher education places well in excess of 60 per cent since 1983. Between 1989 and 1994, an additional 85,000 places in higher education have been created.

This increase has been achieved only through a solid commitment by Labor throughout the period. The opposition and some education bureaucrats, most because of self-interest, have opposed the changes which have taken place, but that is to be expected. These are the people who oppose change just for the sake of opposing change. These are the people who themselves do not wish to have their intellectual powers challenged by a changing world. Considering the response of members of the opposition to the white paper on employment, it is obvious that they too are still living in the past.

The facts on higher education are stark. Funding to institutions has grown from some $3.3 billion in 1988 to more than $4.7 billion in 1994—an increase of more than 40 per cent in real terms. The Austudy scheme also reflects the stark contrast between this government and the former conservative government. In 1983, when the Labor government inherited double digit inflation, double digit unemployment, an economy going backwards and an education system in a mess, a paltry $269 million was spent on Austudy payments. This is not surprising to members on this side of the House, because the words `equity of access' have never been in the vocabulary of the conservatives.

We on the other hand do believe access to higher education should be on educational merit, not on the financial ability of parents to pay their child's way through university. This country needs new talent and new ideas, not the preservation of old money and old ideas. That is why this government has increased the level of Austudy from $269 million in 1983 to $1.56 billion in this current financial year. Austudy and higher education funding together now total in excess of $6 billion—a major commitment by this government, particularly when it is compared as a percentage of total budget outlays.

We on this side of the House have the runs on the board. The opposition has scored a duck—a blank; nadir—and the critics have in the main been silenced. Considering that the higher education white paper was only produced in 1988, changes have been far reaching in a relatively short period of time. Of course, much of that credit can be attributed to the leadership and ideas of the former Minister for Employment, Education and Training, John Dawkins. However, with high profile ministers such as Ryan, Dawkins, Beazley and now Crean, who have held the education portfolio since the election of a Labor government in 1983, the importance placed on education by Labor cannot be seen as token. We on this side of the House do take education very seriously.

With much of the task of revitalising the higher education sector completed, focus is now moving towards vocational education—in particular, TAFE and schools. Signs of the growing focus are very evident in my seat of Port Adelaide. The new Port Adelaide college of TAFE, situated on the waterfront, is nearing completion and will become an important asset for vocational learning in the area. The Croydon Park college of TAFE has also recently been refurbished and upgraded to a standard of excellence. Both projects were fully funded by this federal Labor government and will complement the already world renowned Regency Park college of TAFE.

We promised to provide more places in higher education. We have done that. We are promising an increase in the number of places in TAFE. We are also doing that. The effects of these changes are quite apparent. Many more people in my area of Port Adelaide are now more attuned to the importance of getting a better education. Without this government's major financial commitment, many local people would not receive a chance of furthering their education. I believe their chances will only get better with the expansion of TAFE.

It is pleasing to see that people I have known for many years who have always had the ability but have never had the opportunity to further their education, because of financial restraints or the lack of access to education, are now studying. Parents are also more aware of the ability of their children to achieve a higher standard than they previously thought possible.

In recent times there has been a healthy increase in the number of people who have decided to better themselves by taking up studies, many on a part-time basis. They are achieving and will achieve what they should have been able to in previous years but for the shoddy policies of former conservatives governments. These outcomes are purely as a result of this government providing the programs, the initiatives and the capital investment in its own people, as well as creating a positive cultural change in the way we view the importance of education. This is an investment which will be returned to the government and the nation many times over.

I firmly believe the next barrier in education to be addressed by this government should be the inequities which exist in our school system. This is the next logical step to be taken to ensure that all kids, regardless of their background, are fully equipped to tackle the employment market into the next century. The school sector most in need of a major overhaul is our primary school system. I am pleased to see that this government, as part of its white paper initiatives, has allocated funding in this area to identify the extent of the problem.

The government has indicated it wishes to address the literacy problems at the school level. At the moment there is no reliable information about the literacy and numeracy problems in our schools. This is information which state education departments would sometimes prefer to ignore. This fact makes it difficult for the government to target resources or access the literacy and numeracy problems facing many students. As a result, the government will allocate funds to conduct a literacy survey on students aged seven, nine and 13.

In addition, as a white paper initiative under the national literacy program, the Australian Education Union and the Independent Education Union of Australia will coordinate an innovative program to train early literacy support personnel. This will be provided through a jobtrain program. If the pilot is successful, it could be extended. Although it is small, on a comparative basis with the major initiatives of the white paper, it will be a valuable benchmark for future gains in this area.

In the just over six years since I came to this place, I have never walked away from my belief that it is wrong to let kids fall by the wayside in their schooling, only to be left on the unemployment scrap heap later in life. I suspect that many of the unemployed whose problems we are now trying to solve through the white paper are those who had problems in early schooling. Early intervention in education is certainly the key.

Indications are that the gap between the top 20 per cent and the bottom 20 per cent is widening all the time. This will impact on the distribution of income in our society and has far-reaching consequences. If the gap increases as it has in developed countries such as the United Kingdom and the United States, where there is no safety net in existence like there is in Australia, major social dislocation will become very evident. The highly educated are highly successful. The poorly educated are chronically unemployed. If we allow this to occur in our society, it will lead to inevitable tension and friction between the haves and the have-nots. This is a challenge we need to address to maintain a well-balanced and coherent society.

The greatest stumbling block to the reform and revitalising of our schools is belligerent state governments which jealously guard their power in schools and, to a lesser extent, those individuals with vested interests in the higher education sector. Education is of national importance and, therefore, should have a national focus. The infighting between the states is not helping the education debate. Some in higher education see increased funding and resources in schools as competition and a threat to their own public funding base.

The funding gulf between higher education and schools—primary schools in particular—is appalling. Primary schools are the basic building block of education. Access to higher education and employment generally is indeed dependent on whether a child is successful in early schooling. We must not disregard those who under current circumstances would fall by the wayside at an early age when cheap and efficient remedial action at the time it was necessary could have prevented the problem in the first place.

The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, of which the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) is the deputy chair, produced a report entitled The literacy challenge. It received submissions that up to 20 per cent of primary school children may be at risk with literacy and numeracy. That is one in every five children.

In my own state of South Australia, when this was put forward to the education bureaucrats in Adelaide for their comment, I and other members of the committee were astounded at the apathy of their response. The response was along the lines of `at least we must be getting it right for 80 per cent; we must be doing well'. So much for excellence in education! South Australia is usually one of the better states, but these people appeared quite happy to accept that the outcome of one in five children was not worth committing resources to. Perhaps they did not know how to solve the problem. In either scenario, it cannot be tolerated. That is why the Commonwealth has a very important role in leading the challenge in this area.

What some education bureaucrats seem to care about is elitism in the school system. They evaluate educational outcomes on how well the top few per cent do. I am not against this per se, but I stress the point that it is important to measure outcomes by the quality of education received by all students, not just some.

I believe much of the failure in education outcomes stems from our institutions of higher education. They are interested in only the top 30 per cent of students in our schools who may go on to higher education. There is a reluctance to cater for the remaining 70 per cent. They have for so long dictated to the education bureaucrats what outcomes they expect so as to fit in with their own rigid structures and ideas.

There is little flexibility in delivery of education for those students whose career paths do not include higher education. When employers are demanding greater flexibility in the work force and more technical and more operative skills, it should logically follow that school curriculums would also be flexible to meet this demand. The failure to allocate resources when problems are in their infancy means that society must allocate more expensive resources later on to try to rectify these problems. These bandaid solutions are not cost effective and sometimes do very little to fix up the problem. I believe that, if we do not address this problem in the near future, the social and economic problems facing us today might look even insignificant. Prevention is always better than trying to find a cure, but I wonder how many of us realise what the cost is to the economy of not implementing such a plan.

If we take time to look at what political parties campaigning in state elections on the issue of law and order over the past 10 to 15 years have been saying, it is not surprising that it does nothing in real terms to lift the quality of debate. We have all heard of these few gems that keep coming up: more police, let us stop crime; crime control, let us get tough on criminals; more prisons, let us lock them all up; longer sentencing, let us throw away the key; and, of course, the ever divisive capital punishment debate. I am not trying to make a point for or against these issues but asking that the debate on social issues be raised a gear or two. They may appeal to some people's basic instincts, but they do little to improve the society in which we all live.

The point I am trying to make is that, if it were possible to change a person's direction in life at an earlier age with behaviour modification which often stems from a lack of numeracy, literacy and social and communication skills, would that not be better and cheaper? It is a fact that around 95 per cent of inmates in our prison systems have never successfully completed year 7. This poses an interesting point which goes to the heart of the problem. We as a community have failed to commit resources when they were critically needed. We in the community would complain about how bad things are rather than find real solutions.

We must also look at some of the other costs to our nation. It is appalling that Australia has per capita the highest teenage suicide rate in the Western world. This is something which is not so well known in the wider community and, if the average person in the street were confronted with this fact, I think most people would be shocked that Australia has an even higher rate of teenage suicide than the United States. It is a national shame. I am therefore pleased that the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) has flagged her intention to in the future seriously tackle the issues associated with teenage suicide. I am not saying that interventionist education would stop the occurrence of all teenage suicide, but it would go a long way to reducing it.

Another area of concern is drug abuse in younger people. As we all know, alcohol and substance abuse, coupled with boredom and a lack of self-esteem, can lead to dire circumstances. Again, I believe that intervention in education can play a part in significantly reducing this problem. As long as 20 years ago, the founder of Life Education Centres, which I am pleased to say are now operating throughout much of Australia, Reverend Ted Noffs—of whom I am sure you are aware, Mr Deputy Speaker—had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: After 10 years of never ceasing crisis counselling on drug and related abuse . . . that nothing would be ultimately achieved if the situation continued to be tackled solely at the dire and desperate end of the road stage; and that breakthrough of a positive lasting quality could only come through preventative education of all young children from about 4 and a half to 12 years of age.

I think Ted Noffs says it all. In concluding, I believe this government is totally correct in pursuing its current education and training policies. Opposition members are still as bereft of ideas and policies in education as they were in 1983, and I do not see any foreseeable hope for them with their current ideology. I do firmly believe that we have the responsibility to ensure that all children in this nation have the opportunity to achieve to the best of their ability. Quality education in the earlier years of schooling will complete the education jigsaw and complement this government's commitment to education in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to make a contribution today to the Employment, Education and Training Legislation Amendment Bill 1994. Amongst other things, this bill addresses the Higher Education Funding Act with an amendment. It makes provision for extra funding of $87.3 million over 1994, 1995 and 1996, which is the government's estimate of revenue forgone due to parliamentary blocking of the double HECS contribution for students undertaking second degrees.

PARA.TAB: This brings up a most interesting and challenging point, and that is the contribution of the higher education contribution scheme towards assisting Australian students to pay their component of their costs of higher education, assuming that there is benefit derived from the education by the student, the community and business, which will ultimately use these skills. The contribution of students at about 26 per cent of the total cost of their course is certainly reasonable and fair.

My understanding had been that our HECS system was one of the fairest, one of the most equitable and one of the most efficient mechanisms for allowing students to defer or delay expense—in other words, taking out a loan against future earnings to support their current education. It appeared to most observers that the default rate under the HECS system by allowing the Australian Taxation Office to collect those fees on earnings above a certain statutory minimum would work effectively. But we seem to have a few problems. We are addressing HECS in this bill. We will address HECS in another 45 minutes or so in the next bill before this House, being the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2), and we are addressing HECS in the budget bills that were tabled in this House last night by the Treasurer (Mr Willis). So at the moment HECS seems to be in a bit of a quandary.

The budget announcement that HECS repayments will reflect a proportion of the year during which those with a HECS debt earn above the repayment threshold has undoubtedly sent students in the universities and those intending to be students next year into a bit of a frenzy. Even this morning's newspapers trying to report on the budget announcement make it quite clear that the budget statement does not make clear exactly what effect this announcement will have on students in terms of their repayments.

The indications from the budget statement are that, instead of considering an entire tax year, the Treasury or the Taxation Office will, in effect, collect HECS on a week's earnings, a biweek's earnings or a month's earnings which happen to fall over what would constitute the minimum yearly threshold, which is equal to average weekly earnings. If we take that at its word, then we stand a chance that students who work for one week in the year and earn above the weekly wage, which would constitute being above average yearly earnings, will repay HECS for that one week's work, notwithstanding the fact that they are unemployed for 51 weeks of the year.

The budget statement will today have put in the minds of many students a great uncertainty as to how the scheme is to operate. That uncertainty will certainly do nothing to enhance their educational prospects or their love or gratitude for this government, which operates a student loan scheme. It is, in effect, a loan scheme operated through the federal government's Taxation Office, the funds of which are held in a trust fund by the Treasury. The budget announcement has today confused our nation's students. It has really not done much to contribute to quality higher education in this country.

In that respect, I note that, in his contribution, the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) waxed lyrical about the years prior to 1983. Remember that those on his side of politics have been in government for 11 years now. But he tried to blame all the problems in the education system on former coalition governments. It does not wash. It is getting to be a sick, tired old argument. This government, which is a tired government, is responsible for its own mistakes—and it has made a heap of them. Evidently it has made a few mistakes with HECS because the system, which supposedly worked so well, is now being torn apart and put back together again to the disadvantage of the students whom it was designed to help in the first place.

Shortly we will be considering Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2), which also deals with HECS. That bill says that since 1989, the required HECS payment for a student with a HECS debt whose taxable income was over a minimum level was shown as an adjustment on the income tax assessment for that year. I note that HECS has always been considered to be a debt and not income, notwithstanding the fact that the Taxation Office collects it.

We tend to confuse things a bit. The tax office meddles in what are otherwise social policies, one of which is associated with child support payments. The tax office has really messed things up with the child support scheme. I hope that the Price report, which is yet to be tabled, actively deals with the problems set out by the Child Support Agency that cause distress to so many hundreds of thousands of Australians.

It now appears that we will cause that same kind of distress to thousands of Australian tertiary students or intending tertiary students. Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2), which will be dealt with later this day—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—The chair would prefer it if the honourable member for La Trobe left the debate on the next bill to come before the House until it actually arrives.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank you for your advice, Mr Deputy Speaker. The fact is that HECS is being modified today, it will be modified tomorrow and some of the modifications will impact very heavily on employers.

PARA.TAB: Employers will be required under the act to collect the fees as part of their taxation obligations to the government. They will also incur heavy penalties and fines and may have to pay the HECS fees themselves if they make a mistake and fail to collect them. All this quandary does not really help encourage businesses to invest in new productive capacity, to hire new employees or to take on those graduates who have HECS responsibilities. It all adds to the bureaucracy and paperwork involved in trying to run a business. It does not enhance productivity or encourage employment. The government has made a mess of HECS, and I suspect that it will be some time before it straightens it up. I urge the government to act as quickly as possible so that students have some certitude as to their future responsibilities.

Austudy is dealt with in the budget. Austudy rental assistance, which will require the expenditure of taxpayer funds of up to $21 million per year, will now be introduced for those students on Austudy who can pass a test, who are declared homeless and who require rental assistance. I urge the government, when it frames that legislation, not to make the same kinds of mistakes that are apparent in the social security acts that deal with homeless youth.

I, like every other member in this place, have had many representations from constituents in my electorate complaining vociferously that the act encourages young people to leave home and seek government financial assistance because they declare themselves to be homeless. It either gives them a financial advantage over what they would have if they stayed at home or it is simply a mechanism for breaking up the family. I remind the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) and the government that this is the International Year of the Family. Some of our social security legislation works in a manner contrary to the best interests of families, and I ask them to keep that in mind.

The Austudy loan supplement has been increased from $6,000 to $7,000. A student who has an entitlement to a grant of $3,500 per year from Austudy may now convert that grant into a loan of $7,000 per year to be repaid through a system similar to the HECS system. That gives an additional $3,500 per year to students to take care of their living and general expenses while they are studying. It assumes they need this assistance because they are unable to get it from their parents or part-time work.

The government's loan system, as it has been brought in, was designed not as a compulsory measure but as a measure to attract students. It is my understanding from students that they have not warmed to the Austudy supplementary loan system. The take-up rate has been below that expected, and that is unfortunate. The budget papers reflect the fact that students have not taken up this opportunity. The increase to $7,000 might encourage more to do so. I note, however, that a student who takes up this option goes from a grant, which is not taxable—and that is the end of it—to a loan which has to be paid back entirely, not just half of it.

There is no doubt that if the higher education system in Australia expands we will need to find some mechanism to continue to pay for the expansion. If the government runs out of funds to support expanding higher education, we will run into an access and real equity problem. Already in the forward estimates the government is saying that it will freeze the expansion of higher education places.

It is already impacting on my state of Victoria. Victoria has been told that it will not receive additional funds or places—and funding for those places—beyond 1996-97. This is occurring because our participation rates in Victoria are the highest in the country. Why is that? The answer is quite clear. Long before the federal government took over the funding responsibility for higher education, the people of Victoria said, `We value tertiary education. We value university and colleges studies for our young people. We believe that it is to the benefit of the people, the state and the nation. So, we, the people of Victoria, paid for those universities and places.'

Now the federal government is saying to Victorians, `Because you have done such a good and terrific job at encouraging your people—you have the highest participation rates in the country—you will now be penalised. All the additional growth funds that there are—which are not much—will go to the other states which have lower participation rates.' The other states did not invest at the rate that Victoria did, but we Victorians will pay to let them catch up. It is surely inequitable, surely unfair and to the disadvantage of Victorians. I ask the government to think again on that important issue.

Another issue that is dealt with in the budget with respect to education is the funding referred to in a statement which was contained in the government's white paper, and which the government tabled in this place last week. It is called `A national survey of Australian literacy skills'. The project will receive funding of $700,000 in the next financial year, $1.2 million in 1995-96, $1.3 million in 1996-97 and that is the end of it. The white paper says:

SPEECH.PARA: The government intends to conduct a survey of students aged seven, nine and 13 to obtain reliable information about literacy levels in Australian schools.

I certainly hope that the information is reliable. For some 3 1/2 years I have consistently in this place been calling for the government to do something about instituting a system of national testing of literacy skills of young students in Australian schools, and for very good reasons.

PARA.TAB: Our committee—the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, which the honourable member for Port Adelaide referred to earlier—brought down in this place two reports dealing with literacy: Words at work in March 1991 and The literacy challenge in January 1994.

Words at work dealt with adult illiteracy. During our inquiry I took the opportunity to ask those who appeared before the committee if they believed that we were still growing the problem; that is, students entering the work force and entering the general life of the country with inadequate skills in reading and writing. The answer that I got from the teachers was, `No, we are not still growing the problem,' the answer from the education bureaucrats was, `No, we are not still growing the problem,' but from many private individuals, parents and some other active organisations the answer was, `Absolutely.'

I did support a dissent to the report which called on the government to institute a system of national testing of young students' literacy skills. Specifically, the first element of that dissent recommended that state and territory departments of education be encouraged to institute standard internationally comparable testing of all students' reading, writing and maths skills attainment at minimum stages, being the end of years 3, 6, 9 and 12, and that the results be reported.
In our inquiry resulting in the report The literacy challenge in January of this year, the committee found and stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It is unacceptable that 10 to 20 per cent of children are finishing primary school with literacy problems. It is also unacceptable that the actual number of children with such problems are not known.

The government members of the committee supported that statement, but failed to support me in calling on the government to institute a system of national testing so that we could get results and show what a terrific job we were doing or what mistakes we were making. If we are ever going to get the funding that the honourable member for Port Adelaide wants for his primary schools, we are going to have to find out what the problems are to convince the parents and this government to support his calls for increased funding for primary schools.

PARA.TAB: Again, in a dissent to the report, I recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: .the Commonwealth Government finance through the Australian Education Council national assessment of reading, writing and mathematics skills attainment of all primary school students prior to completion of Year 3; and
.results of the national assessment be reported.

I congratulate the government for finally agreeing to my call for some assessment nationally of the literacy skills of our young students. It is particularly important that that survey includes—hopefully—every child in grade 3 so that if there are problems we can repair them before it is too late. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak on the Employment, Education and Training Legislation Amendment Bill, particularly as it provides me with an opportunity, as it has to others this evening, to make a few comments on this government's commitment to education and training—as illustrated in last week's Working Nation white paper on employment and growth—and on the initiatives announced in last night's budget, all of which will go a long way towards helping young people and the unemployed become job ready. I, for one, applaud the Treasurer (Mr Willis) on last night's document and congratulate him on its presentation.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this bill before us this evening is to make minor amendments to the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 and the Maritime College Act 1978 and to repeal other acts relating to employment, education and training. The bill amends the Higher Education Funding Act to provide for minor adjustments to financial amounts flowing from the transfer of responsibilities for funding the Institute of the Arts of the Australian National University from the government of the ACT to the Commonwealth.

This bill also provides for funding adjustments as a result of amendments made to the Higher Education Funding Legislation Amendment Bill 1993, which removed provisions which would have doubled the rate of the higher education contribution scheme—HECS—liabilities for undergraduates who wished to study for a second degree at the same or at a lower level. The bill also amends the Maritime College Act 1978 to provide for a minor change to appointments to the council. These amendments will make the chairperson of the academic board of the college an ex officio member of the council of the college. The bill also seeks to amend a number of gender references in the act to reflect modern drafting practices and, we hope, present day attitudes.

The bill amends the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 to provide additional outlays of $26.135 million in 1994, $30.955 million in 1995 and $30.197 million in 1996. These increases in outlays will be partly offset by a reduction in payments from the HECS scheme trust account of $20.9 million in 1994, $20.5 million in 1995 and $18.9 million in 1996. In the longer term Commonwealth outlays will increase by approximately $27 million each year due to the removal of the double HECS provisions. In addition, a reduction in general revenue payments to the ACT government of $3.3 million in 1995 and 1996 will be made to fully offset the payments for the Institute of the Arts.

Clause 5 of this bill increases the maximum amount of grants that can be made to specified institutions for operating and limited operating purposes in certain years. The result of the amendments proposed by this clause will be to increase the maximum level of grants for 1994 from $3,474,260,000 to $3,500,395,000; in 1995 from $3,534,396,000 to $3,565,351,000; and in 1996 from $3,585,959,000 to $3,616,156,000.

Part 4 of the bill deals with the amendments to the Maritime College Act 1978. For the benefit of honourable members who may not be familiar with the operation and functions of the college, it is an autonomous institution located in Launceston which is governed by its own council.

I was pleased in the last parliament to have the opportunity to visit that college with a parliamentary committee. I am sure other honourable members who had that opportunity would recall the presentation that we received there and how well regarded that college is. This council's responsibilities to the college include policy making and administration of the college and its three schools of engineering, fisheries and nautical studies, and the centre for marine operations.

The functions of this college are to provide maritime and marine related education and training as the college council, with the approval of the minister, deems necessary to the education of people wishing to pursue a career in the shipping and maritime area. The students receive awards from the college in line with regulations. The college also liases with other institutions and authorities in Australia that are primarily concerned with providing maritime education and training.

The 1992 figures show that the college has 1,378 students. The college's principal source of income is parliamentary appropriations, and its operating grant for 1994 is $9.671 million. One of the aims of this bill is to change the appointments to the college's council. Clause 7 of this bill seeks to amend the definition of an `ex officio member' by deleting `Chairman' and substituting `Chairperson' or the `Chairperson of the Academic Board of the College'. Clause 8 seeks to change the act in relation to the constitution of the council. This clause inserts two new paragraphs into the principal act to make the chairperson of the academic board of the college a member of the council and to provide for one member of the teaching staff to be elected to the council.

Some aspects of government policy in regard to higher education may help to illustrate the importance of this sector of the economy and the government's commitment to it. At present, funding for higher education for 1994 stands at $4.7 billion. For the three-year period 1994-96, $14.8 billion has been committed. Honourable members may remember last December when the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) announced that funding for 1996 would increase to $5 billion, and this rise will include an additional 1,500 places in the higher education sector.

Such moves are, of course, very positive developments as they will allow more people to pursue studies that will enhance their skills and thus their attractiveness to employers. The government's commitment to this process is evident when one realises that this increase means that the funds available for higher education in 1996 will be boosted by more than $66 million over the allocation for 1995 and an increase of almost $1.6 billion, or 46 per cent, over funds provided in 1988, when the major reform of higher education took place.

The 1993 figures show that there are 580,000 students in universities in Australia. Since 1988 there have been large increases in Commonwealth-funded student places, resulting in a 25 per cent jump in the number of these places since 1988. Over the 10 years that this government has held office, more than 100,000 places have actually been created. This is a commendable effort.

We often hear from those opposite and the media that Australia does not spend enough on its universities and other higher education institutions. The figures show that this country spends 3.5 per cent of total budget outlays on higher education, in comparison to Japan—a country often used as an example in the debate—which spends only one per cent.

Another promising trend is the number of students taking up study in research at a postgraduate level. Since 1990, postgraduate research commencements have increased by 96 per cent and postgraduate study by course work commencements has increased by 30 per cent. Plans to increase postgraduate research by a further 31 per cent by 1996 are under way. The majority of the extra places are being allocated by institutions to students who wish to undertake further tertiary study either at postgraduate level or through further undergraduate study. More than 80 per cent of the additional undergraduate places have been taken up by students who have been or who are already in the system.

If this is not a ringing endorsement of this government's policies for education and training from the young people of this country, then I do not know what is. Honourable members opposite might not think that the government is on the right track as far as education and training goes, but we have the approval of those who matter—the students themselves.

In supporting this bill, I would like to think that the changes it proposes to make are very much in line with the government's aims in the area of education and training and reflect the government's commitment to these areas as outlined in last week's white paper and, of course, last night's budget. Members would be aware that one of the major platforms of the white paper is in the field of education and training. The many good initiatives in the white paper in relation to improvements to education and training are far-sighted and comprehensive and will contribute towards employment growth in the future.

For instance, the youth training initiative, the YTI, will ensure that young people gain access to the skills and education they need to become well qualified and therefore attractive to employers over the coming years. Given the fact that more than 25 per cent of the long-term unemployed are aged between 15 and 24, the measures in the YTI are certainly necessary. Under the scheme, young unemployed people will get intensive case management so that they have early help in finding a suitable job or, alternatively, suitable education and training, soon after they become unemployed. They could also receive a place in a labour market assistance program or vocational training and placement with accredited trainers if they are still unemployed after six months. In addition, they will benefit from the new income support arrangements to encourage young people to participate in education, training or work experience activities.

These new YTI measures are aimed at taking early action to prevent young and relatively unskilled unemployed people from becoming long-term unemployed. Under the YTI package more than 50,000 15- to 17-year-olds will be assisted every year—a major increase on the current level of 26,000 starts in labour market programs by people under 18 years of age.

Young people are the future of this nation. All Australians should applaud the initiatives in the white paper designed to improve education and training opportunities for young people. Young people will appreciate these measures, as will business and the broader community, in the longer term. The business community will benefit a lot from these measures and I am sure that it is smart enough to take advantage of the opportunities that will arise from them.

In relation to tourism, we have already seen a positive response to Working Nation's initiatives from the Australian Hotels Association. Honourable members might be aware that last week the association's national executive director, Richard Mulcahy, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The tourism industry is one of the best placed sectors to restore employment throughout Australia, and the hotel industry is prepared to throw its weight behind the Federal Government's plans to reduce unemployment.
Mr Mulcahy also said:
. . . estimates by the Department of Tourism have confirmed that there will be sufficient demand to create up to 300,000 extra jobs in the industry between now and the end of the decade.

It was pleasing to hear him say that his association would work closely with the federal government to ensure speedy accreditation of training programs in order that trainees would have the chance to develop long-term careers in that industry. It is encouraging that an industry such as this one will come forward and stand up and be counted on this matter. A lot of the initiatives in last night's budget rely on a large participation by the private sector. That is important, because it is only if we can get the private sector really moving that we can achieve a lot of the goals that are in the interests of the Australian people.

PARA.TAB: Last night's budget continued and extended those reforms and initiatives that are important for Australia's future. The budget includes wide-ranging improvements to the delivery of student assistance—a very important area. It also includes targeted programs for literacy and numeracy, which was mentioned by the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), and a focus on one of the crucial aspects of Australia's future in literacy and numeracy—the need for a work force of tomorrow to be fluent in Asian languages. The Treasurer committed the government to a $48 billion budget on Asian languages alone, and that is very important if we are to continue to pursue our opportunities in the Asian region.

Languages often present communication barriers but encouraging our young people, particularly, to take on Asian languages is one way of breaking down those barriers. The government rightly sees this as a high priority as it will play an important role in developing closer links with our Asian trading neighbours. This government is committed to doubling the number of year 12 students studying Asian languages to 25 per cent of the year 12 population by the year 2006. It will follow on from the Council of Australian Government's decision to have all children in years 3 to 10 study a foreign language—preferably Asian.

Last night's budget, as the majority of the nation has made clear in its response today, is truly a wonderful piece of work by the Treasurer. I have already acknowledged the Treasurer's efforts last night. It was very pleasing to see him smiling so broadly last night. It was obviously a great delight for him to bring forward such an important document for the benefit of Australians.

Despite what must be said were some pretty poor attempts to discredit the budget by some members of the opposition last night and others today, the fact is that it will undoubtedly improve training and education in this country. As the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) said, strengthening this sector is at the heart of the budget. That reflects the difference between this government's attitude to the future and the attitude of those opposite. It is only by putting a big emphasis on our employment, education and training opportunities, which both the white paper and the budget have focused on, that we can assist Australia's development and hence the jobs that Australians need.

Instead of lifting the national skills level, instead of keeping young Australians at school and university longer and instead of helping the unemployed find work or training, what were we going to get from those opposite? They wanted full tertiary fees. This afternoon there has been a lot of talk about the HECS program. I suggest to the honourable member for La Trobe that the HECS program offers much greater assistance to students than the opposition had in its Fightback package and its long-term philosophy about full tertiary fees. Full tertiary fees are not the way to go and it would take us back to the bad old days of denying many Australians the opportunity to have a tertiary education. I think many of us, particularly those of my age, can recall the opportunities that were lost by many people in our day where, as a result of the financial constraints, people were unable to get tertiary education because of the high tertiary fees. But, whilst HECS is a longer-term commitment for people, it does give young people, and older people in some ways, the opportunity to go on to tertiary education which would have been denied them if they had to pay up-front fees.

So the old philosophy coming from those opposite is of full tertiary fees, cut off the dole after nine months and, of course, part of it was slave wages for young people. We will continue to hear a lot from those opposite about how Fightback is no more, but it obviously is still an underlying factor in a lot of people's minds on the other side. Make no mistake: I suppose the policy's name could be changed, but the next one could probably be called `Comeback' instead of Fightback. No-one really believes that those opposite are members of the caring, sharing Liberal Party that they seem to think they are.

In contrast, look at our attitude as exhibited in the budget and also the white paper—the commitments we have in both those very important documents for Australia's future. Those opposite have tried to make some mileage out of the fact that we have introduced a training wage. They are going around saying that we have stolen their idea. But I suggest that the Australian traineeship scheme has been around for some time. The Australian traineeship scheme has been an extremely successful story for people who have had the opportunity to participate in it. Young people have spent 12 months under that traineeship scheme, with the unions being prepared to negotiate agreements to give the young people a go in gaining some experience in the workplace.

How many times do we hear the story about a young person going along for a job and the employer asking, `What experience have you had?' They cannot get any experience if they are straight out of school. But, under the existing traineeship scheme, they can. They can then go to an employer a lot more job ready than they would otherwise have been if it had not been for the opportunities to participate in a traineeship scheme. I think this is a great initiative by the government and should be applauded by all sectors of the community. As I have said, those opposite suggest that we have stolen their idea. But the traineeship scheme has been around for a long time under this government.

There is a huge difference between our idea and the idea of those opposite. The training wage will combine formal and on-the-job training—a huge difference. While it may be below award rates, you can rest assured that at the end of the period on the wage the young person will be job ready and attractive to employers.

Look at what we have done. In last night's budget, there was an astonishing $1.5 billion for vocational training and education for the period 1993-97, guaranteeing that Australia maintains an equitable and accessible tertiary education sector of high quality. The vocational training initiatives in the budget will ensure that the system is world class. An extra $70 million in 1997 reflects this government's long-term commitment to the sector. This level of vocational training is necessary if we are to ensure that the labour market has the right balance of academic and technical skills required.

The student assistance measures announced in the budget are another part of this government's commitment to ensuring that our young people are given all reasonable help in pursuing for themselves an education and a brighter future. From 1 January next year, as has already been mentioned, homeless students who are in receipt of Austudy or Abstudy will also be eligible for rent assistance of up to $34.20 a week. The honourable member for La Trobe asked before—I really wanted to pick up on this before I ran out of time—`What about families in the International Year of the Family?' We are going to address that by having family mediation referrals for Austudy and Abstudy homeless rate recipients. It is a private program and will be established certainly to assist those families. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always a pleasure to follow the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) in debates in the House. It certainly is a pleasure again this evening where we are debating the Employment, Education and Training Legislation Amendment Bill 1994. It was interesting to listen to some of the comments being made by the honourable member for Oxley with regard to the white paper and the focus the government is putting on, and the spending the government is injecting into, all aspects of training. I think the exact words the honourable member used were `to help make unemployed people job ready'. That is quite correct. I agree that it will help train unemployed people to get them job ready, and it will certainly improve the level of skills we have in the community today. But, at the end of the day, the big question being asked not only by those of us in this place but also by those people outside around the nation who are ultimately going to foot the bill for the $6.5 billion worth of packages in the white paper is whether there are going to be any more jobs. I think that really needs to be addressed.

PARA.TAB: The government cannot answer that question because the focus is completely on training, on the improvement of skills. That is fine, but we are going to end up with a highly skilled and highly trained band of unemployed people in Australia. We had many questions today and during this week about where the projected unemployment levels will end up. The government is projecting a five per cent unemployment level by the turn of the century. So we are not really getting any definite answers or positive moves from the government in creating meaningful employment for the people we are training.

The bill before the House tonight makes minor amendments to several items of higher education related legislation in the employment, education and training portfolio. It also repeals three expired acts, makes some funding adjustments under the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 and also amends the Maritime College Act 1978. The bill adjusts university operating grant amounts in the Higher Education Funding Act arising from the transfer of funding responsibility for the Canberra Institute of the Arts from the ACT government to the Commonwealth. The institute is now an integral part of the Australian National University. The bill provides that Commonwealth funding formerly payable to the ACT for the institute will henceforth be incorporated into the ANU's funding under the Higher Education Funding Act. The opposition is opposing none of these amendments, although the debate has given the opportunity, as we have seen here this evening, to members of the opposition to comment on a fairly wide ranging number of issues involved in this portfolio.

The financial impact of the Higher Education Funding Act amendments on outlays over the three years is expected to be $27 million, based on the government's estimates that the extra direct funding will be offset by reductions in payments from the HECS trust fund. In addition to a number of language modifications to remove masculine references, the bill will amend the Australian Maritime College Act 1978 to make the chairperson of the academic board an ex-officio member of the college council. A further member of council would be elected by college staff. A number of states grants acts are being repealed, namely, the States Grants (Advanced Education Assistance) Act 1976, the States Grants (Tertiary Education System) Act 1987 and the States Grants (Technical and Further Education Assistance) Act 1989. As I say, the opposition does not propose to vote against this legislation, but the debate certainly affords us the opportunity to talk about a number of different areas of higher education.

As you would be well aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, some fairly unique circumstances have developed in my electorate. My electorate is located in a part of the mid north coast of New South Wales that is rapidly growing. In fact, I would venture to say that it is one of the more rapidly growing areas both in population and economic activity in Australia. In my electorate there are two TAFE colleges, albeit rather large TAFE colleges, which are very diverse in the streams of education that they supply to the region. We have two open access learning centres which are used extensively—one in Port Macquarie and one in Taree. I forget the number of students that they are servicing but they number in the thousands. The pressure is there, and we are looking to the Commonwealth government and the New South Wales government to develop a university campus in Port Macquarie. It is pleasing to see the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) entering the chamber. I am sure he has received correspondence from my electorate in this regard.

An interesting exercise is taking place in Port Macquarie in that consideration is being given to privately funding a university campus there. As I understand it, Mr Deputy Speaker, you have an innovation in your electorate of Cowper in that you have a campus of the Southern Cross University being developed in conjunction with a TAFE college on the same site. There is a very concerned and interested group of people in Port Macquarie who have been lobbying for a number of years—it probably goes back to the years when Port Macquarie was actually in your electorate—for the establishment of a campus at Port Macquarie.

This particular group of people has now gone past the initial stage and is looking at the prospect of privately funding the capital works to establish that campus. On that basis, a consortium has been formed and land has been identified to develop a university at Port Macquarie. What the group is really looking for now is some commitment from one of the existing universities in New South Wales or, indeed, in Australia that may be interested in establishing a campus at Port Macquarie.

There have been discussions with the new vice-chancellor at Southern Cross University and they are continuing. I believe that the group in Port Macquarie is also going to seek expressions of interest to develop this idea further and to see whether the prospects are viable. I will read from a media release that was sent to me by the spokesperson for the consortium which is looking at this possibility. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Plans were announced today for the establishment of Australia's first privately funded public university campus.
Senior government officials are working with a Port Macquarie based investment syndicate in developing the concept.

I emphasise that at this stage it is a concept. I do not know whether this subject has been broached anywhere else in Australia, but certainly it is rather unique in my electorate. The media release continues:
An initial expression of interest has been sought from Southern Cross University and this will be considered by its Governing Council.
I am sure that this particular group of people has been, through my office, in contact with the relevant ministers in the state and in the Commonwealth. The release goes on:
Within the 400 acre precinct will also be a privately funded international research centre, a regional shopping facility, student housing and sporting facilities as well as several technology parks.

Located at the junctions of the Pacific and Oxley Highways, less than ten kilometres from Port Macquarie, the greenfield site is considered to be ideal for the proposed development. The catalyst for the huge development is an adjacent $10 million highway service centre, presently under construction by the Ken Mathews Group of Sydney.
A spokesman for the company undertaking the university development, Mr Graham Linn, said that it was no accident that Port Macquarie has been chosen for the huge project.
`Governments everywhere are calling for private sector participation in the provision of public infrastructure. Our initiative—
that is, the initiative of the consortium in Port Macquarie—

will result in Port Macquarie becoming the leading economy on the north coast of New South Wales' he said. `Only a few weeks ago the Port Macquarie region was identified by the NSW Department of Planning as a regional centre with huge potential.'`We already have international support to develop the proposed private research centre adjacent to the University campus. Expressions of interest in participating in the project have already been received from Asian investors based in both Indonesia and Singapore'.

`This is an opportunity for Port Macquarie to obtain a public university facility well ahead of any that may be supplied from the public purse. It will also result in a clean, technology-based industry program which will be totally compatible with the city's existing tourism infrastructure. Further, resource sharing opportunities for support services such as sporting, convention and accommodation facilities are sure to create viable long-term partnerships between the public and private sectors' Mr Linn said.

Mr Graham Linn is the spokesman for the consortium that is progressing with the idea of the establishment of a privately funded university campus at Port Macquarie. I appreciate the difficulties, as far as the Commonwealth departments are concerned, with the establishment of university campuses in Australia, with the massive decentralisation of population and the rising demand for educational facilities based on higher levels of unemployment in regions such as the one I represent.

PARA.TAB: I would urge the minister to seriously consider what possibilities there are for the government to participate in such a venture. It does require a degree of lateral thinking and is getting away from the idea of everything being provided by the Commonwealth, everything being provided by the taxpayer. It would help alleviate the ever increasing demand on resources as far as the Commonwealth is concerned—which we are made aware of on a daily basis by the government. This is certainly one area that I think we could look at—the possibility of a joint venture between the Commonwealth and the private sector. I am sure that the minister at the table is aware of the situation and the interest in the Port Macquarie area for the development of a university campus. Hopefully, over the coming years, that will progress further down the track.

Recently I had the pleasure of hosting a visit by the shadow minister for rural and regional development, the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott), to my electorate. We had discussions on regional development with a number of interested groups throughout the electorate. One of the groups that we did have discussions with in Port Macquarie was the group that is proposing the privately funded university there. It is interesting that when you discuss matters pertaining to regional development a lot of members of the general public have a fairly narrow view of it and think that it is basically about economic development of an area and trying to get industry to decentralise to an area to provide more jobs. Certainly, that generally is the hub of the regional development argument.

The government's white paper which was released last week, for all intents and purposes, probably paid only a bit of lip-service to genuine regional development across Australia. There was $150 million to be allocated, of which I think at least 50 per cent was going to be allocated to Badgerys Creek. What came out of the discussions that we had with the group that is proposing the building of this university in Port Macquarie is that education really is an integral part of regional development.

As I stated at the start of my address this evening, we do have in my electorate quite good educational facilities, to the level of TAFE. As most members would be aware, TAFE now is looking at structuring a lot of its courses, a lot of its curriculum, so that they can be integrated with higher levels of tertiary education and can be used as a stepping stone to higher education in universities. The natural progression in the development of educational facilities in my electorate now seems to rest on the development of a university campus.

I know that we cannot have one in every town up and down the coast; they must be strategically located. A campus has been established at Lismore—it is not in your electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker, but it is not far from it; further down the coast there is one at Coffs Harbour, and then there is a fairly large gap between it and the Newcastle University. That is why the private consortium is putting forward this proposition for Port Macquarie, which I am sure the minister will give serious consideration to.

To go back to what I was saying before, education is an absolutely vital part of regional development. There is nothing that government can do to try to manipulate the flow of people into regional Australia, particularly along the eastern seaboard of New South Wales. We must identify the fact that we have to provide the services. If we are looking at getting industry to relocate and develop in regional Australia, we have to look at what attracts them: it is infrastructure, lifestyle and economic imperatives.

If an industry is considering relocating into a regional area, people will say, `Where will we educate our children? Will our children go through a secondary school system and then on to higher education? Will they then have to leave and go back to some of the major metropolitan areas?' It certainly is a disincentive for the executives of those companies looking at moving to regional Australia when the educational resources, particularly with respect to higher education, are a little thin on the ground. On that basis, I implore the minister to seriously consider the proposition that has been put before him.

The minister was invited to attend the Tertiary Education Association annual dinner and graduation night that is being held next month, but unfortunately he cannot attend. I am sure he would have made every attempt to be there if it were possible. Higher education is very high on the agenda of everybody concerned in Port Macquarie. I certainly support what these people are trying to do. As I said, it is lateral thinking. If we could get more of that across Australia, then we might get a bit further down the road with regard to servicing the needs and easing the burden on the resources of the Commonwealth.

We have heard in the media and in this place a lot of criticism of the government as far as assets sales are concerned. I suppose it is fair enough to say that sometimes one might agree with the view that the government should not be involved in a lot of government business enterprises or trading enterprises and that maybe they should be sold to the private sector. My attitude is that, if the government is going to sell a capital asset, that income should be rolled over into some other capital asset. I put it to the government that, if it is going to sell $2 1/2 billion worth of Commonwealth assets this year, instead of throwing the money into a spending program or reducing the budget deficit in the short term, that money should be rolled back into other Commonwealth government capital assets. Why not roll that money back into capital assets in the education system? Why not roll it back into capital assets in the health system? We saw increased funding in a couple of health programs. We did not see any increase in funding for the building of capital assets to provide health services throughout Australia.

In the last couple of minutes of my speech, I would like to get across another issue which has caused concern in the community, and that is higher education and Austudy. At the end of last year and early this year my staff spent a lot of time with students from my electorate. They had made all the inquiries about Austudy last year and had sent in their applications. Everything was right. Then, all of a sudden, at the start of the university semester this year, we were getting phone call after phone call from students, particularly in Sydney, whose Austudy had been cut off because of anomalies that had arisen due to the changes that were made.

Previous speakers on the other side were waving the flag and saying what a fantastic job the government was doing in this regard. However, there have been some gaps in Austudy. This year in particular students have been caused a lot of problems because of the way the department has dealt with those changes to Austudy.

Last night's budget was highly rhetorical and probably a bit low on substance. The government plans to tighten up eligibility for Austudy, costing students $10.7 million in 1995-96 and over $11 million in the following two years. This will be done by basing the income test on known income for the financial year rather than for the full calendar year. All parents should be concerned that the government is widening the poverty trap for students by increasing the Austudy supplementary loan to $7,000. This creates an added inducement for the most disadvantaged to trade in grants for loans, leaving them more disadvantaged at the end of their courses than when they started. The government expects to make $7 million out of the poorer students in this way in 1994-95, rising to $1.5 million in 1997-98.

The government is spending a mere pittance on funding for early literacy. The government is spending less than $3 million in 1994-95, divided up amongst almost one million of the nation's children from kindergarten to year 3, yet it is spending $21 million on its teacher union mates. Expenditure is up from $9.1 million last year in the guise of professional development. So there are still a lot of questions to be asked. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I wind up the debate by thanking those honourable members who have taken part: the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile), the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) and the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott). This has been a good debate, albeit wide ranging. It has gone well beyond the matters dealt with in the Employment, Education and Training Legislation Amendment Bill. But that is fine. I always welcome wide ranging debates on education. People discussed the pressures associated with the higher education sector, the higher education contribution scheme in general and changes to the Austudy program announced in the budget.

PARA.TAB: Bearing in mind the time, I should concentrate on those matters which directly concern this bill. The opposition should be aware, if it is not already, of the effect of what it did in the Senate in refusing passage of legislation to institute a double rate of higher education contribution scheme, or HECS, contributions for those pursuing second degrees at the same or lower rate than the degree already held.

The honourable member for Moncrieff made reference to representations from those allegedly disadvantaged by this step. Disadvantage in these matters often tends to be a matter of self-definition and, more often than not, involves such groups seeking other people to pay for benefits that they are to receive. I am informed that over 11,000 people were likely to be affected in this academic year by that measure which was defeated in the Senate. The opposition ought to realise that, by doing what it did in the Senate, it has displaced up to 11,000 school leavers from higher education. In other words, the opposition ought to realise that it has been contributing to what the honourable member for Moncrieff referred to as huge pressure on universities.

Frankly, if people are joining the queue for a second degree and are displacing people leaving school who intend to go to university but who cannot because their places have been taken by those who have been accepted to do a second degree and there is no disincentive, as was proposed by the government, I think those responsible for removing that proposed disincentive have to bear the responsibility. So every time we hear a remark in this place about unmet demand from school leavers for higher education places and every time we see a story in the newspaper, as one frequently does around January and February each year, about qualified school leavers unable to gain higher education places, we will be reminding both them and the public in general that the opposition has made a contribution to this by its defeat of that measure in the Senate.

I listened to the honourable member for La Trobe and the honourable member for Lyne. The honourable member for La Trobe is very proud of a university campus which is opening at Berwick in his electorate. The honourable member for Lyne is very keen to see a university campus develop at Port Macquarie in his electorate. I think it is great that members have an interest in promoting the development of post-secondary education in their electorates. But those two honourable members in particular should remember that their contribution as members of the opposition to the pressure on higher education places by what they did in defeating the double HECS measure is making those developments and the placement of higher education places in their electorates less likely.

Like the honourable member for Lyne, I am a firm supporter of decentralisation of higher education, as I know you are, Mr Acting Deputy Speaker. You and I would have grown up and perhaps attended university at a time when university places were centralised largely in the capital cities of Australia, as a consequence of long years of conservative government. I well remember when, under the Menzies government I think, Sydney's third university, Macquarie University, was established at Ryde, when quite clearly it ought to have been established in western Sydney. It took this government and the Labor government of New South Wales, with the support of honourable members like the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott), to right that wrong and establish the university of Western Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —And yourself.

—I am too modest to claim any credit for that. It took far too long and it came a generation too late. So I support the efforts of the honourable members for La Trobe and Lyne equally in what they are doing to achieve a better distribution of higher education places in the region. But they ought to recognise that their respective parties ought to be making a contribution towards this. They are not doing that; what they are doing and what they did last year has the effect of locking up higher education places in the capital cities. No number of visits from the shadow minister for regional development to the electorate of Lyne—I forget who the shadow minister for regional development is—will achieve that. They ought to think these things through.

PARA.TAB: I should take this opportunity to underline the government's commitment to provide opportunities for Australians wherever they live to have access to university study. We can all be proud that, since 1988, higher education places have increased by 25 per cent. In the decade 1988 to 1998 the government will have created 100,000 places. But the problem is that during the period 1990 to 1993 opportunities for school leavers in higher education actually fell by 8.1 per cent. More than 90 per cent of the additional undergraduate places created up to 1993 have been taken up by students who have been or who already are in the system. So all of that effort has not served to open up the system to school leavers as we had intended. As a result, the government introduced school leaver targets this year to address the problem. But it ought to be recognised that half the student population is made up of mature age students who are entering study for the first time or who are seeking to upgrade their skills.

The honourable member for Moncrieff referred to the government actuary's report and a study by the University of Canberra about the anticipated level of unpaid debt for male and female graduates. I suggest that the honourable member for Moncrieff has missed the point. HECS, the higher education contribution scheme, is an equity based scheme. People do not pay until they reach average weekly earnings. Women leaving the work force because of family and caring commitments will not pay until they re-enter and their income once again reaches that first income threshold.

Those changes introduced in the budget last night, to which honourable members refer, bring forward the commencement of repayment of the HECS debt. I think the point here is that it is reasonable to expect that people who have a HECS debt should repay that debt once their salary exceeds average weekly earnings. The change announced last night complements last year's budget decision to collect HECS repayments through the provisional and pay-as-you-earn tax systems. The change does not increase the size of the debt but it does bring forward the repayment.
