I am advised that administrative arrangements are being finalised by Treasury, Finance and the Department of Employment, Education and Training.

The honourable member for La Trobe, in referring to a freeze on higher education places and in seeking to defend the higher participation rate in Victoria, I know is aware of and ought to have referred in his remarks to the broader government agenda on post-school education and particularly the government's commitment to the vocational education and training sector. I know he is aware because he was present at an opening in his electorate recently which I was also attending. I know that he is very proud of developments in the TAFE system in Victoria which have been possible only through increased commitment by this government to the vocational education and training system.

We will be considering over the next couple of months funding for higher education in 1997. As the House would be aware, no decisions on allocations beyond 1996 have been made, but we will be considering the most efficient and effective use of funds that we will be setting aside for this purpose.

I should in closing refer to the remarks of the honourable member for Lyne in his pursuit of a university campus at Port Macquarie. While saying how grateful he was for what this government has been able to achieve in the development of TAFE in his electorate, he tended to regard TAFE as a stepping stone into the higher education system. I think it is wrong to do this; TAFE has value in its own right. TAFE qualifications these days more frequently lead to well paid, interesting, challenging and rewarding jobs than do university degrees of many kinds.

I think the honourable member for Lyne ought to realise that he should value the TAFE colleges in his electorate as quality institutions of learning in their own right and not simply as back doors into a university campus, which I hope he achieves in the fullness of time and which I hope, if he does achieve, involves some shift of resources from those universities located in the capital cities of this country. I am pleased that the opposition is not opposing the legislation. I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommendation appropriation announced.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Free) read a third time.
Consideration resumed from 24 March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elliott Mr R.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: In doing so, I am pleased to speak on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 on behalf of the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear). This bill will amend the taxation laws in a number of respects, giving effect to several previous announcements, including one measure announced in the 1993-94 budget. It will also make a number of amendments which have not previously been announced.

PARA.TAB: On 12 January 1994, the government announced proposed amendments to the capital gains tax provisions. This bill gives effect to all but one of the proposed amendments. The amendments relating to the assignment of prospective shares of interests in partnerships will be included in a bill to be introduced later this year.

The proposed amendments fall into three broad categories:first, measures directed at emerging capital gains tax avoidance practices that, if left unchecked, would have posed a significant threat to the revenue at the expense of taxpayers generally; secondly, measures directed at reducing the capital gains tax compliance burden on taxpayers; and thirdly, measures directed at redressing certain unintended consequences of the capital gains tax provisions.

I wish to express the government's gratitude to representatives of the taxation profession for their suggestions as to how the proposals could be implemented to reduce the compliance burden on taxpayers and yet ensure that tax avoidance opportunities were closed off. Although the government has not accepted all of those suggestions, I am pleased to announce that it has accepted many of them. This has meant that some of the proposals announced have had to be modified. Full details of all the modifications at the initiative of the profession or the government were included in a press release issued when this bill was introduced into the parliament. I turn now to the principal measures themselves.

The bill will counter certain arrangements that involve the avoidance of capital gains tax through the payment of rebatable dividends. The disposal consideration for shares in a company or the amount of capital treated as paid back on shares will include distributions made by the company that are treated as funded out of certain share premium amounts or revaluation reserves. Any capital gain computed having regard to the disposal consideration or the amount of capital paid back will not be reduced by the amount of the distributions that are treated as rebatable dividends. The amendments relate to:
liquidators' distributions;
off-market share buybacks;
other disposal of shares; and
amounts of capital paid back on shares.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment will apply to disposals of assets after 12.00 midday eastern summer time on 12 January 1994. This measure has the potential to prevent a significant future loss to revenue.

PARA.TAB: The bill will deny any part of a capital loss to a controlling shareholder or associate that is attributable to distributions of pre-acquisition taxed or untaxed profits of the company in which the shares are held. The amendment will apply to disposals of shares made on or after 24 March 1994. This measure guards against a significant future loss to revenue.

The bill will remove certain capital gains tax advantages of value shifting transactions involving shares. The amendments will apply to material shifts in value between shares held by the controller of a company and associates. A value shift will be material if the value shifted is at least the lesser of five per cent of the value of the shares or $100,000. The amendment will apply to material shifts in value of shares effected after 12.00 midday eastern summer time on 12 January 1994. This measure will protect the capital gains tax revenue base and prevent a significant future loss to revenue.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Disposal of assets without a change in beneficial ownership

PARA.TAB: At present, a change in the legal ownership of an asset without a corresponding change in beneficial ownership does not constitute a change in ownership and hence a disposal within the meaning of the capital gains tax provisions. The bill will ensure that this is so in only two situations:

first, on the establishment of a trust other than a unit trust over property previously owned by a person where that person, as beneficiary of a trust, remains absolutely entitled to it or would remain so if it were not for a legal disability; and
secondly, when there is a change in trustee without any other change in the ownership of the trust property.

SPEECH.PARA: Transfer of assets to a unit trust will constitute a change in ownership and so a disposal. The amendment will apply to changes in legal ownership of assets after 12.00 midday eastern summer time on 12 January 1994. This measure has the potential to prevent a significant future loss to revenue.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Transfer of assets within company groups

PARA.TAB: At present, a requirement for obtaining rollover relief for transfers of assets within a wholly owned company group is that the transferor and transferee companies are group companies for the whole of the year of income in which the transfer takes place. The bill will alter this requirement so that the transferor and transferee will need to be group companies only at the time of transfer. The amendment, which will be to the advantage of taxpayers, will apply to disposals of assets in the 1993-94 income year and later income years. This measure will have a small, but unquantifiable, cost to the revenue.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Transfer of assets within company subgroups

PARA.TAB: The bill will ensure that rollover relief on asset transfers between group companies will not be recaptured if, in broad terms, the asset has remained in a company subgroup and the subgroup was disposed of by the parent company. The amendments, which will be to the advantage of taxpayers, will apply to disposals of assets after 16 December 1992, the date of application of the relevant section. This measure will have a small, but unquantifiable, cost to the revenue.

The bill will ensure that adjustments are made to the cost base of shares in a group company to which a loss is transferred and for subvention payments. The amendment, which will be to the advantage of taxpayers, will apply to agreements to transfer losses against capital gains derived in the 1993-94 or later income years, even if the loss was incurred in an earlier year. This measure will have a small, but unquantifiable, cost to the revenue.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Assets used by non-residents in Australian permanent establishments

PARA.TAB: Capital gains tax is payable on disposals of assets used by non-residents in permanent establishments in Australia. The bill will ensure that capital gains tax is paid by reference only to the gains that accrued during the period of use of the asset in the permanent establishment in Australia. Likewise, the bill will allow a capital loss only to the extent to which it accrued during that period.

The amendment will apply only if the asset does not qualify as a taxable Australian asset under any of the other categories of taxable Australian assets. This amendment will apply to disposals of assets after 12.00 midday eastern summer time on 12 January 1994. This measure will represent a cost to the revenue of less than $1 million per year.

The bill will ensure that division 19A of the capital gains tax provisions does not apply to in specie distributions made by the liquidator of a company to shareholders if the liquidation is completed and the company dissolved within a period of three years after liquidation proceedings commenced. The Commissioner of Taxation will be authorised to allow extensions of time in appropriate cases. The amendment will be to the advantage of taxpayers and will apply to disposals of assets after 6 December 1990, the date of application of division 19A. This measure will result in an insignificant cost to the revenue.

The bill will exempt from capital gains tax the reimbursement or payment of certain expenses under Commonwealth, state or territory incentive schemes as prescribed by regulation. The amendment, which will be to the advantage of taxpayers, will apply to all reimbursements and payments of expenses made under the prescribed schemes. The estimated cost of this measure is less than $1 million per year.

The bill will ensure that the time limits normally applicable to the making of amended assessments do not apply to amendments that give effect to the time of acquisition or disposal of assets under a contract or the time of disposal of assets that are compulsorily acquired. The bill will also ensure that the time limits normally applicable to the making of amended assessments do not apply to amendments that give effect to the finding that a contract was a nullity from the beginning.

Generally, the amendments to the law will apply to assessments made at any time. However, they will not allow an amendment of an assessment that would increase a taxpayer's liability if the Commissioner of Taxation was prevented from amending the assessments as at the end of 11 January 1994. This measure will result in an insignificant gain to the revenue. In addition to the capital gains tax changes, the bill makes amendments in a number of other areas.

The amendments being made by this bill to division 16E of part III of the Assessment Act will remove unintended tax deferral advantages of some securities covered by the division. Tax deferral occurs because division 16E in its current form includes the fixed component of the return on variable return securities in assessable income by spreading it evenly over the term of the security. That form of accrual is inconsistent with economic reality. For declining balance securities, more income is earned in the earlier years and less in the later years. The greater the fixed component of the return from a security, the greater is the income deferral.

The bill will amend division 16E so that all returns—both fixed and variable—from variable return securities will be brought to account under a compounding accruals accounting method. This solution is already adopted in division 16E in relation to fixed return securities. The proposed amendments to division 16E will apply to qualifying securities issued after 27 January 1994. They are expected to result in revenue savings of $10 million in 1993-94, $18 million in 1994-95 and $26 million in 1995-96.

The bill will also amend the secrecy provisions to let the Commissioner of Taxation tell the Health Insurance Commission whether or not a registered carer or an applicant for registration as a carer under the new child-care rebate scheme has a tax file number. The amendment, which will not impact on the revenue, does not let the Commissioner of Taxation give the carer's tax file number.

PARA.EMPHASIS: HECS: Inclusion in provisional tax calculation

PARA.TAB: This bill also contains amendments to include higher education contribution assessment debts in calculating provisional tax for the 1994-95 and later years of income. This measure, announced in the 1993-94 budget, complements the inclusion of HEC assessment debts in the PAYE arrangements and will bring forward revenue by approximately $12 million in 1994-95, $3 million in 1995-96 and $2 million in 1996-97.

The offshore banking unit, OBU, concessional tax regime has now been in operation for over 18 months. While the government does not yet know precisely how successful the new measures have been in establishing Australia as an offshore banking centre, the number of registrations and requests for advice suggest a reasonably high level of interest.

There has been extensive consultation with the banking and finance industry and its advisers ever since the government first announced its intention to tax OBU income at a concessional rate. As a result the government has now decided to extend the scope of possible borrowing and lending activities to include gold borrowings and gold loans. The measure will further promote Australia as a viable offshore banking centre.

However, the government also recognises the need to balance the development of a viable offshore banking centre with the need to protect the revenue. The bill will also amend the OBU provisions to make it clear that a guarantee, letter of credit or performance bond must be in respect of activities of offshore parties and outside Australia in order to attract concessional tax treatment. The opportunity has also been taken to correct some minor technical deficiencies. The amendment is likely to have a positive but unquantifiable revenue effect.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Foreign investment funds and foreign life insurance policies

PARA.TAB: The foreign investment fund measures, which took effect from 1 January 1993, are part of Australia's comprehensive system of taxation of foreign source income. Changes in the foreign investment fund measures were announced by the Treasurer on 22 December 1993. Some changes provide a holding company exemption for certain indirect investments in foreign companies which carry on general insurance, life insurance, real property or certain multi-industry activities.

In addition, activities in connection with construction will be excluded from the general non-exempt list of activities. This means an investment in a foreign company which is principally engaged in construction activities may qualify for the active business exemption. Australian taxpayers who have an interest in the company will not be subject to taxation under the foreign investment fund measures because of that interest. The amendments will have minimal effect on revenue.

Recently introduced rules limit the general income tax deduction for expenditure by employees on non-compulsory uniforms and wardrobes that do not comply with the occupational clothing guidelines. Currently, a deduction may be denied under the rules for expenditure on what may be called occupation specific clothing—for example, nurses traditional uniforms—merely because the uniform could be linked with a particular employer, perhaps by a logo. The proposed amendments will exclude occupational specific clothing from having to comply with the guidelines. The amendment will be backdated to the commencement date of the new rules.

The government has also decided to extend and modify the transitional arrangements for non-compulsory uniforms and wardrobes. A transitional arrangement operates to generally allow deductions for expenditure incurred before 1 July 1994 on clothing approved by the Commissioner of Taxation. The transitional arrangement will be extended for an extra year so that it will now apply to expenditure incurred before 1 July 1995. This will allow clothing manufacturers to use up existing stocks of clothing approved by the commissioner. The transitional arrangement will be modified to let the commissioner give deductions for expenditure incurred before the actual approval was given. The impact on revenue of these measures is negligible.

The bill will amend the gift provisions of the income tax law to allow deductions for gifts of $2 or more made, during limited periods, to the `Weary' Dunlop statue appeal and to the Sandakan memorials trust fund. The `Weary' Dunlop statue appeal will raise funds to assist with the erection of a statue in honour of the late war hero and humanitarian Sir Edward `Weary' Dunlop. The Sandakan memorials trust fund will raise funds to assist in establishing memorials in various places throughout Australia in memory of those Australians who died at Sandakan prisoner of war camps during World War II. The impact of the amendments on revenue is not expected to be significant.

Property used by a taxpayer mainly to provide certain amenities in the workplace for employees and their children qualifies for a high minimum rate of depreciation. The amenities must be used mainly for the benefit of the taxpayer's employees or children of those employees. This can cause difficulties where employees of other companies within a wholly-owned company group share the use of the amenities. Accordingly, the law is to be amended so that the concession will apply on a wholly-owned company group basis. The amendment will apply from the commencement of the 1993-94 year of income in relation to existing and future property. This measure was announced on 29 November 1993. The impact on revenue is unlikely to be significant.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Development allowance and general investment allowance

PARA.TAB: Two amendments announced on 29 November 1993 are to be made to these allowances. One relates to the use of property within wholly-owned company groups so that a taxpayer may qualify for the allowance even where the right to use the relevant property has been granted to another wholly-owned group company. The revenue cost of this amendment is unlikely to be significant.

The other will extend the allowances to property for use in the transport of minerals and quarry materials. The cost to the revenue of this measure is unlikely to exceed $20 million per annum over the term of the allowances. A third measure, not previously announced, will simplify procedures for a leasing company to transfer its entitlement to the development allowance to a lessee. This amendment is revenue neutral but should reduce the compliance costs of leasing companies.

The first two changes apply from the time when the allowances commenced; that is, 27 February 1992 in the case of the development allowance and 9 February 1993 in the case of the general investment allowance.The third amendment will apply to leasing arrangements entered after the day on which this bill receives royal assent.

The bill proposes to exempt from tax all income derived by certain state public sector superannuation funds that are constitutionally protected from tax on any of their receipts. The amendment will ensure that benefits in a

SPEECH.PARA: constitutionally protected fund are not taxed partly in the fund's hands during the accrual period and again on payment out of the fund following the decision of the High Court of Australia in the State of South Australia and Anor v. the Commonwealth of Australia and Anor, 1992, 105 CLR 171.

PARA.TAB: The amendment will apply with effect from 1 July 1993. However, if a constitutionally protected fund has not paid income tax on the assumption that all its income was exempt from tax, the amendment will apply from 1 July 1988. The amendment has been developed in consultation with the state governments and is expected to have a minimal financial impact.

SPEECH.PARA: Entertainment expense payments

PARA.TAB: As part of the 1993 budget measures, amendments were made to the fringe benefits tax and income tax legislation so that certain benefits provided by an employer to an employee or an associate of the employee in connection with entertainment would become liable to fringe benefits tax. The amendment made by this bill will ensure that the method of payment of the entertainment expenses does not change the amount of fringe benefits tax payable on that entertainment. The impact on revenue of this measure is negligible.

Under the existing fringe benefits tax law, a loan fringe benefit arises when an employer makes a low interest loan to an employee. The amount of that benefit will be the difference between the lower interest payable and the interest that would be payable using the market interest rate. At present, this market interest rate is based on the lowest rate of interest offered by the Commonwealth Bank on a housing loan at 31 March preceding the fringe benefits tax year. This rate includes any capped rate available at that time. However, as capped rates are lower than normal market rates, the taxable value of the benefit understates the real benefit of the low interest loan. The bill will provide that the market rate will be the standard variable rate for owner-occupied housing loans of the major banks as determined by the Reserve Bank of Australia. The financial impact of the amendment will be a gain to the revenue of $60 million in the 1994-95 year and $45 million in the 1995-96 year.

The bill also makes minor technical amendments to update relevant references to provisions of the United States internal revenue code in order to ensure the technical accuracy of Australian income tax law and will have no practical effect on the application of the section. There is no impact on the revenue. Full details of the amendments are contained in the explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable members.

In relation to the measures that I have outlined to the House, the government will be moving some minor amendments during the committee stage of the bill. The amendments are mainly of a technical nature and minimise the compliance costs of some of these measures. I will be providing further details of these measures in the committee stage. I commend the bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Sharp) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., I propose the question:

PARA.TAB: That the House do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are all delighted and satisfied that South Africa has moved to become a truly democratic nation. President Mandela is to be admired and applauded for the manner in which he has conducted himself throughout the campaign, reassuring the whites on one hand that their assets will not be confiscated and that law and order will prevail, while dampening down the radical left in the ANC on the other. He has done this skilfully and at all times performed very impressively and without rancour or bitterness for the past. I for one hope that, despite his age and failing health, he is able to carry on for at least a second term in what will be a very difficult transition period and a period of high expectations.

PARA.TAB: Vice-President de Klerk is also to be congratulated on his role in dragging his doubting supporters into a complete democracy in the country. It is always very hard to go against those on one's own side. There are to be 400 members in the new assembly. The ANC got 62.6 per cent of the vote; the National Party, 20.3 per cent; and Inkatha, 10.5 per cent. Of the nine provinces, the ANC won seven, the National Party won one, the Western Cape, which includes Cape Town, and Inkatha won the KwaZulu Natal province, which includes Durban.

As a strong believer in freedom, including the freedom of the individual, it is my hope that we can now pursue with at least equal vigilance the goal of full democratic elections in the rest of the African continent in all its states and territories. It has always intrigued me that those who come from the left wing in Australia have pushed for freedom and elections only in South Africa and not elsewhere. They would no doubt claim that it is because racism was institutionalised in South Africa, as if they expected us to believe that it did not exist elsewhere on that continent.

Of course, a dead black is just as dead whether it be from a racist cause or another cause. Racism is rife in Africa and is usually based upon tribal lines. Usually the dominant tribe rules and rules ruthlessly. Even in countries as moderate as Zimbabwe, after the first election there the Shonas, led by Mugabe, killed about 70,000 Matabeles down in Matabeleland and dumped them down mine shafts. That hardly raised a paragraph in the Australian press.

In recent days, we have seen the horrific killings, amounting to hundreds of thousands, in Rwanda, based purely on racism, and there has not been a demonstration in the streets of Australia. We only have to look at the latest map put out by Freedom House of the African continent to see that there are not too many states that are classified as free. There is only Namibia, Botswana, Zambia—which I think is a very generous interpretation—Mali, Benin and Gambia that are classified as free. All the others are classified as not free or partly free. I think we have to recognise this and push forward to eliminate racism in all its forms.

I dug out an old speech of mine from 1988 about Burundi, which is next to Rwanda. The Tutsi minority was ruthlessly slaughtering the majority Hutu tribe and had killed 200,000 people purely on racist lines. There it was a case of a black minority of 14 per cent ruthlessly ruling the others. They had claimed all the power and everything else, but there was not a protest in the world from the United Nations, the Organisation of African Unity, the BBC, the ABC, the World Council of Churches—all these organisations were mute. The Commonwealth Conference never listed it on its agenda. There was no anti-apartheid movement or anything like that. I believe that, now that we have seen what can happen in South Africa, we have to push ahead and overcome that.

I believe we need consistency and logic in our approach. We should not judge the rulers of another country on the colour of their skin, whether it is white oppressing black, black oppressing black or whatever. It is patronising to select one side and not the other. We should not excuse oppressors or tyrants simply because they may espouse a socialist philosophy. We should condemn them equally whether they are capitalists, socialists or whatever. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following a number of comments that were made by the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter), who is a National Party member from northern Queensland, Gerard Henderson in the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday made reference to those comments. I apologise to the honourable member for not having had the opportunity this evening to advise him that I would be making passing reference to that matter.

PARA.TAB: Gerard Henderson is a commentator of substance. There are many elements of the general point that he makes in that article with which I would agree. But the particular paragraph to which I want to make reference is a paragraph in which he refers to my immediate predecessor in the electorate of Hunter, Bert James, and the honourable member for Kennedy. Mr Henderson said:

Katter's abuse of parliamentary privilege is among the worst although, as I recall, Labor's Bert James was wont to use parliament to dispatch a few hard hits. However, almost every week there are examples of politicians using privilege to score points against others to which there is no right of reply.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that Gerard Henderson has not said in that statement that Bert James was wont to abuse parliament to dispatch a few hard hits. I do not believe and I hope that that was not what Gerard Henderson meant. If he meant that Bert James, as a courageous representative of the people of his electorate of Hunter and of the wider concerns in the Australian community and as a courageous representative of justice, used parliament to dispatch a few hards hits to pursue those objectives, I agree with him. I am pleased to have the opportunity, if it is necessary, to defend Bert James.

PARA.TAB: Bert James was outspoken on injustice and he used parliamentary privilege, not as a means to attack people but as a means to correct injustice essentially for people who could not afford the expense of litigation processes that may otherwise have been involved.In fact, one of the last achievements of Bert James as a member of this parliament was in saving a Chinese national about $7,500 in solicitor's fees on an immigration matter. The whole institution of parliamentary privilege is an extremely important institution. It should never be abused. I do not agree with Gerard Henderson that it has reached its use-by date. I think it is an important element of this place and I think it is important that members, whoever they are, have an opportunity to raise questions and to pursue issues which they, in conscience, believe should be pursued.

Bert James never had to appear before a privileges committee. He never had to apologise for any matters he raised, and the matters that Bert James raised in this parliament were always well researched. As the president of Bert's federal electorate council in the old Hunter electorate, I was very conscious of the reports that he gave, the reports that he went around the branches to give. He always took up questions of justice and fairness, and they were the types of things that he pursued here.

For example, Bert was the person who introduced me to Clarence Darrow and his first publication entitled Attorney for the damned. Clarence Darrow took up a great number of issues. The very fact that Bert James almost carried that book in his hip pocket indicated the sorts of concerns that motivated him.

Bert did not court popularity in connection with these issues. He courted and demanded justice. As a result of the issues that Bert James pursued, justice that would not possibly have prevailed under other circumstances very often did.

Bert was a member of the national parliament representing the electorate for 20 years. He was never opposed in preselection. His father before him represented the electorate of Hunter for 30 years. Between them, they represented that electorate for half a century. People with a record of that kind do not offend or abuse the privileges which are made available to them.

Bert James chaired the committee which guided the Northern Territory to self-government. He was an important and courageous member of this parliament. I am delighted to have the opportunity to defend him, if in fact that is necessary. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak about the Child Support Agency. As the House is no doubt aware, there is an inquiry under way into the operation of this agency. This inquiry has probably been one of the most popular inquiries of all time in terms of public response. Sadly, it is not necessarily a measure of the popularity of the agency.

PARA.TAB: I know that in the past five years the Commonwealth Ombudsman has received more than 5,000 complaints about the CSA. In addition, at least 45,000 signatures have been collected from petitions around Australia which call for the scrapping of the Child Support Agency.

I often feel as though my electorate office is a branch of the agency. I have no doubt that this is the experience of many electorate offices. My office has been required to act as a go-between for the Child Support Agency and parents, mainly due to the agency's distance from regional Australia.

In the regions, the Child Support Agency is a faceless organisation. Its offices are city based. Contact can only be made through a 131 number, which usually means that callers must wait on the line for 20 to 30 minutes. Parents are frustrated because they cannot speak with an officer of the CSA face-to-face. That is why I have written to the Treasurer (Mr Willis), the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin), the Child Support Registrar and the parliamentary committee inquiring into the CSA to request that agency representation be established in regional areas.

The Child Support Agency has a sensitive role to play in dealing with broken relationships and often distraught families. Its clients are often, understandably, angry and upset. This mood is only exacerbated by the fact that they cannot easily visit a Child Support Agency office.

The agency was established in 1988 to assist custodial parents collect maintenance payments from non-custodial parents. It is estimated that the agency receives 7,000 new cases each month. I can only say that many of these clients will only be new victims of the agency's sometimes illogical and often unfair responses.

I bring to the House's attention the circumstances of one single mother in my electorate that I met recently. Until about a month ago, she was receiving child support payments from her ex-husband, as was her right. Her ex-husband was employed, and the Child Support Agency had determined a fair amount for him to contribute towards his children's welfare. However, her ex-husband was retrenched, and this is where the trouble began.

Given the news of the retrenchment, the Child Support Agency recalculated the amount of maintenance the ex-husband was required to pay. The agency worked strictly according to the financial year. Therefore, the ex-husband's new lower income was backdated to June. It was then deemed that the maintenance payments which the single mother had been legally and rightfully receiving were overpayments. The Child Support Agency asked her to pay the money back.

My constituent appealed against this decision. While the agency did decrease the debt, she was still required to pay some money back. She was made to feel like a criminal simply by accepting the money which government legislation required her ex-husband to pay. Even her ex-husband disagreed with the move and, like his ex-wife, has appealed against the agency's decision. This is only one of many examples of unfair treatment which my constituents have experienced.

When constituents visit my office to resolve a matter with the agency, quite often we find that the agency has made a mistake in its payments system. There are some who, after a long and bitter experience, have begun to believe that tax is the motive rather than the support of children. This often results in families, usually single mothers with young children, going without. The reality is that the agency's convoluted legislation means that children, the very group which the government purports to help through the agency, are suffering.

I believe that the parliamentary committee is due to publish its report by mid-June. Like many thousands of parents around Australia, I look forward to the completion of this inquiry. I encourage the government to act quickly to look at improving the operation of the CSA.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take a few moments of the House's time tonight to correct what might seem to be not a misrepresentation but an inaccuracy in a debate that occurred earlier on the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1994. During that debate, the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) tried to persuade me and the House that the Gold Coast is really a poverty-stricken ghetto on the east coast of Australia. I said at the time—you might remember, Mr Speaker, because you were in the chair—that I found that hard to believe, as what the honourable member was asking me and other members of the chamber was to not believe what our eyes tell us when we fly over the Gold Coast.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Moncrieff was quite persuasive in her remarks. I went out of the chamber thinking that perhaps what my eyes saw was not the reality. But it seems that the honourable member for Moncrieff might not have been as impeccable in her research as she probably should have been. I have looked at some of the statistics which she enjoined me to during that debate. It is important to realise that the old story about statistics—that once you get them down, you can do anything with them—is pretty much pointed out by the intervention of the honourable member for Moncrieff in that debate.

The honourable member quoted a series of statistics providing comparisons of 1991 census characteristics as they relate to Commonwealth electoral divisions. She argued that I had misrepresented her and that families in Moncrieff were worse off than families in Watson. I remind the House that at the time I was talking about families who needed the government's child-care payments.

The honourable member for Moncrieff pointed out correctly that the number of families in Watson earning over $60,000 per year is 4,143 while in Moncrieff there are only 3,176. But what she failed to tell the House was that she was not comparing families with children or without children—just total families. On the other hand, I was examining the child-care issue and was talking about families with children.

It is appropriate to look at what the statistics in the material that the honourable member for Moncrieff was referring to say about families with children, because that is what the debate was about. If the honourable member for Moncrieff cared to recast her eye on her electoral profile, she would find at table 31b, which is entitled `Parental income families-families with offspring', that 8.8 per cent of the families with children in Moncrieff have incomes over $60,000 per year. In comparison, in Watson, only 6.9 per cent of families with children earn an income over $60,000 per year; that is, 1,536 in Moncrieff and 1,470 in Watson. But the honourable member for Moncrieff compared instead table 30b, and incorrectly surmised that she had more families with children that earn less money than those in Watson.

The honourable member for Moncrieff should be a little more careful with her research in the future. I raise this matter only because the honourable member for Moncrieff was so insistent in making her point. She took the bill into consideration in detail, and there were two or three exchanges across the chamber on it. In order to set the record straight, the honourable member for Moncrieff, when quoting statistics in future, ought to quote statistics that relate to the matter we are discussing, not some red herrings, as she did the other day. I thank the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bring to the attention of the House this evening the establishment of a branch of the Combined Pensioners and Superannuants Association of New South Wales in Port Macquarie. As its name indicates, this organisation is a representative body of that section of our community. It is certainly a growing pressure group within the community. It is vitally interested in a number of issues that are being addressed by the government today, including, in particular, those which form part of the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 that was debated in the House earlier this day and on which I had the opportunity to speak. I want to take this opportunity to make a few further comments on that bill on behalf of the local branch of the Combined Pensioners and Superannuants Association.

PARA.TAB: At the inaugural meeting in Port Macquarie—more than 100 people were involved in establishing this branch of the association—a number of issues were discussed. There are two that I will mention. The first is the issue of managed investments and the treatment of the unrealised capital gain on managed investments as income, which is certainly having a disastrous impact on pensioners and part-pensioners throughout Australia. Today the government partially backed down from the policy it introduced prior to the last election. We support and were pleased to see that and urge the government to go all the way and eliminate it completely.

The other issue the Combined Pensioners and Superannuants Association is vitally concerned about was also addressed in the legislation debated in the House today; that is, the pensionable age for women being moved from 60 to 65. We heard a lot of rhetoric about whose policy it was at the last election and whose it was not. Certainly the government has turned 180 degrees on that issue. I bring the parliament's attention to the fact that the Combined Pensioners and Superannuants Association opposes the proposed changes to the legislation to take eligibility for the age pension for women to the age of 65 years over a period of 20 years.

It should be noted that the federal government has still not enacted legislation allowing persons aged 65 and over to remain in the work force. Even more serious is that workers over the age of 65 years in some states do not qualify for workers compensation. The fact that the government has seen fit to introduce a mature age allowance for males aged 60 years and over who have been unemployed for more than 12 months reinforces the argument that males now have access to a de facto age pension at age 60, yet the government is intent on moving the pensionable age for women out to 65 years.

A serious anomaly apparent in the legislation relates to the sunset clause which comes into effect on 30 June 1996, exactly one day before any woman could be eligible. As things stand, the mature age allowance provisions are irrelevant to women because at the moment women qualify for the age pension at 60.

Another anomaly lies in the fact that a dependent woman who is married to a pensioner qualifies for a wife's pension provided she is over the age of 21 years. The obverse does not apply; that is, a female pensioner's husband under the age of 65 does not qualify. Surely this is an example of blatant sex discrimination, yet the minister does not appear to be worried at all—far different from his preoccupation with bringing the female pension eligibility age on par with that of men in the interests of equality.

There is no level playing field. The Combined Pensioners and Superannuants Association believes that the proposed changes to the legislation actively discriminate against women for the following reasons. Firstly, women do not have the same access to superannuation benefits as do men because most women are only in the work force part time or have long interruptions to their career paths because of child-bearing and nurturing responsibilities as well as domestic responsibilities. Housewives are certainly still far more numerous than househusbands.

Secondly, women do not have the same earning capacity as men even when they are in the work force full time. They have not achieved equal pay and earn only 84.5 per cent of male average weekly earnings. It follows then that women will not have the same capacity to arrange as attractive superannuation deals as men and, furthermore, are disadvantaged in that in many cases their superannuation benefits do not flow onto their spouses and dependents.

Since women spend on average 17 years in the paid work force as opposed to 39 years for men and have more discontinuous work force participation, they are disadvantaged compared with men. There are many women who work, for example, in rural industries and on family farms for very low wages and sometimes no wages. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the attention of the House to the proposed private label agreement and complementary terms and conditions of purchase being circulated to suppliers to Coles Supermarkets by Coles-Myer Ltd. This is the second draft of these documents, the first draft having been put out in March of this year. The driving force behind the proposed agreement is Mr Brian Beattie, the managing director of Coles Supermarkets.

PARA.TAB: These proposed agreements have gone out to at least 150 suppliers ranging from major corporations to private companies and sole traders. In practice, the proposed agreements are unenforceable against foreign companies, publicly listed companies and cooperatives; that is, they are only enforceable against private companies and sole traders.

The burden of the proposed agreements thus impacts essentially on Australian-owned small to medium businesses. Suppliers are meant to comply with the proposed agreements by 27 May, with the implicit threat of withdrawal of business from any supplier not agreeing to the terms of the proposed agreements.

Essentially, the proposed agreements seek to reduce the business to business relationship of Coles supermarkets and their various suppliers to one where the suppliers effectively become subcontractors of Coles-Myer Ltd. The proposed agreements are certainly predatory, and interim legal advice to some suppliers suggests that the private label agreement in particular contravenes sections of the Trade Practices Act. However, even the proposed terms and conditions of purchases for Grocery Holdings Pty Ltd, GHPL, of Coles reflects the bureaucratic arrogance of Coles-Myer Ltd. Clause 1.2, for example, means that no matter what arrangements a supplier thinks it has with Coles supermarkets, the price of goods supplied on any individual order can be arbitrarily altered by Coles.

The accompanying private label agreement is primarily concerned with Coles defending its position in respect of its own Farmland brand name and the goodwill arising from any development of business involved with that label. This has a surface logic but overlooks a number of pertinent factors. Firstly, if the label Farmland has a tangible goodwill value, this is a company asset and, as such, could be sold by Coles at any time it chooses to, say, Woolworths, for instance, without any reverse obligations upon it towards the manufacturers or suppliers affected. Clauses 6.3 and 6.4 respectively lay out the formula for payment of a fairly onerous goodwill factor to Coles and then a cumbersome dispute mechanism to supposedly resolve subsequent difficulties between Coles and its suppliers.

Secondly, in all known Farmland cases these are not products developed by Coles but rather are existing products repackaged under its label. Moreover, it is not uncommon to find that such branded products are effectively prevented from competing in Coles stores alongside the very same product under the Farmland label, thus resulting in a diminution of the manufacturer's branded market share.

Thirdly, Farmland in any case does not exist as a separate corporate entity, that is, it has no stores or warehouses, et cetera, but it is a marketing strategy of Coles to differentiate its stores in customer perception from those of its competitors. Nevertheless, in defence of the non-existent Farmland corporate entity, clause 6.1 of the private label agreement seeks to prevent the sale of a private label business unless a supplier has written consent from Coles GHPL. This is an extraordinary intrusion by one business into another.

The proposed private label agreement and the accompanying document are not only predatory but are corporate business bureaucracy gone mad. The Trade Practices Commission should investigate them without delay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neville Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes remaining I would like to bring to the attention of the House a matter that has been before it on a number of occasions. Members on both sides have spoken about the unrealised capital gains on shares being a very unjust and inequitable imposition on those Australians who have provided, at least in part, for their own retirement. Just recently I received a letter from one of my constituents, whom I will not name, but I think it is worth reading into the record:

SPEECH.PARA: I again refer to the gross injustice that occurs when pensioners suffer a reduction in their pension when shares they own rise in the market value but are not sold. On 21 January the Commonwealth Department of Veterans' Affairs advised me that my part pension had to be reduced following a review of my shares. It showed that Austoft Holdings had given me an income of some $2.30 per fortnight. It was again reduced on 4 March when Austoft shares had increased in price and supposedly had given me an income of $23.80 per fortnight. On 7 April they advised my Austoft shares were earning me $36.43 per fortnight. About a week ago I discovered that my dwelling needed new guttering and spouting all around the building. So on the 20th instant I sold my Austoft shares to fund this expense. My net gain will be $721.60 on which I will have to pay capital gains tax. Isn't this a case of being penalised several times for the one gain? As I have previously advised, the gain because of the rise in share prices was a paper profit and should not be taken into account.

What I am saying is that, even though there is a review pending in September, what we are doing to many Australians is demoralising them. We are depriving them of dignity. We are eroding their income.
